column8: The game is relaxing and enjoyable, perfect for those who love interior design and decorating.
column9: The snapping and placement mechanics are frustrating and inaccurate.

column8: The game has a lot of potential and is expected to improve with future updates.
column9: The game has numerous bugs and crashes frequently.

column8: There are some bugs and optimization issues, but they are manageable and expected in early access.
column9: The game is not optimized well, leading to performance issues.

column8: The game offers a variety of customization options for furniture and room design.
column9: There is a lack of customization options for furniture and room dimensions.

column8: The story mode includes interesting puzzles and tasks that keep the gameplay fresh.
column9: The controls and user interface are not intuitive or user-friendly.

column8: The sandbox mode allows for creative freedom and extensive customization.
column9: The game feels incomplete and lacks content.

column8: The graphics and lighting are aesthetically pleasing and add to the overall experience.
column9: The story mode and mini-games are not engaging or fun.

column8: The game is compared favorably to other interior design games like The Sims and House Flipper.
column9: The game is not suitable for realistic room planning due to restrictive mechanics.

column8: Players appreciate the ability to mod and the potential for future content through updates.
column9: The graphics and visual design are not appealing to many players.

column8: Some players have experienced issues with controls and UI, but overall find the game intuitive and fun.
column9: The game has potential but needs significant updates and improvements.

column8: This game geniunely sucks so fucking bad in so many ways, leaving aside the mandatory EA account you need to even play this hot garbage, it also has DRM, so im not even sure ill be able to own this shitty ass game forever because EA might snag it away from me, now lets talk about the game in question,the game is in low resolution and the graphics are as low as possible and horrendously ugly, when i go to options to change the graphics and resolution nothing happens when i click the mouse, thats right, im stuck with the shitty graphics and 800x600 resolution, the story is horrible, but i dont play games for their story, i want fun, well, this game also lacks in fun, with core elements like base building and resource gathering is GONE, an incredibly simple combat system, an incredibly small unit limits to the point it feels like im leading middle school gangs rather than armies, what pisses me off the most isnt the fact that this game is utter dogshit, but the fact that this is  the last command and conquer game in the series (if you exclude a remaster and a mobile game), this is the ending to the legendary tiberium storyline that has been gradually building up since 1995 just to be concluded like this, if you're new to command and conquer dont play this as your first game in the franchise, it WILL leave you with a bad taste of this elite franchise.

column9:
[h1]Professional beggars in the review section don't deserve any help.[/h1]

(That's the gist of it, but CNC4 is so bad you can't find a single beggar in the reviews.)

[hr][/hr] Let me start by saying the nice things I can think of: If this were the first game made by a new studio, and all the campaign text and cutscenes were removed, I think it would be a good game. Thanks to EA for providing an excellent resource library for various mods. Okay, enough with the nice things, let's get to the rant.

[hr][/hr]

[h3]If you want to feel as decent as the beautiful Command & Conquer series you remember, don't play this game.[/h3] EA's madness, [b]a half-baked product hastily delivered to end the CNC series and the hopes of CNC players[/b]

In this game you can see:

>EA employees have to clock in [b]twice[/b] before they can start work.

>Want to experience the complete unit types? Please level up first.

> To simplify gameplay, we've optimized away the most crucial aspect of RTS games: the economy.

> Two (or more) different colored turtles crawl around creating a mess of units pieced together from unknown materials, which then either grind against each other or get instantly killed.

> Campaigns where the protagonist is sacrificed for the sake of sacrificing the protagonistâ€”classic "Wow, the protagonist/important character is here, I'm so touched!" type of storyline.

> You won't see more than 10 people in the entire public chat channel in a day (this game deserves it).

> There are other surprisingly good optimizations and settings. >(This contains spoilers) [spoiler]In our CNC series setting, Kane is actually an alien who wants to escape. Everything he does [b]is not for any other nobler reason[/b], but to escape with his followers[/spoiler]. I got tired of typing halfway through, and this game isn't worth writing a longer review.

[h1]No rating[/h1]

The following is personal opinion, not something that will make you happy, you can skip it.

[hr][/hr]

"Then why do you play?" "Because I'm the biggest idiot."

[i]The Command & Conquer series is one of the few good memories I can bring back from my childhood. I remember that playing games was one of the few times my father was emotionally stable. He wouldn't hysterically force me to practice his "all other professions are inferior except for studying" philosophy, nor would he try to belittle me to maintain his family status. He would discuss with me how to defend against AI attacks, how to strategize on the battlefield, and how to achieve victory. Unfortunately, those precious memories are gone, ruined by EA's Command & Conquer 4. EA isn't some entity "existing to create something wonderful"; it's just "another game company that exists solely to make money." This "CNC4" thing is like my life: "I don't know what it's describing, I don't know what it's accomplishing, I don't know how I survived, I don't know how it was delivered, but it's something, it's passable, and that's it." I don't know how to continue writing now; I'm numb. Let's just pretend this isn't a CNC game, but a prototype made by some unknown small studio; at least that way, we can both feel a little better.

column8:
Big C&C fan, played every game in the series except the last couple Tiberian parts including this one.

Very first thing, I couldn't play this Singleplayer game, because EA's online servers were messed up and you are FORCED to create an account and log-in to play this SINGLEPLAYER game.
So, I had to pirate the Game I purchased. Great.

Ever since the very first C&C, the staple features were resource gathering (and their scarcity forcing you to manage what you build) and the unlimited unit count.
With C&C 4 EA thought to themselves "We have a winning formula that worked for over a decade. Let's... not continue doing any of the good stuff"
Resources, don't exist. Poof.
Resource scarcitiy, doesn't exist. All units are free. Poof.
Unlimited unit count? Nah. You have a 50 point limit, with the good units costing 6 points. So you spend most of the time with just 8 units. Sometimes you even have to destroy your own units so you can build some specific unit the campaign requires you to use.
The big fun of turtling up and then just overrunning the enemy with a huge army? Nope, not a thing.

Oh and also, the enemy can have multiple bases, giving them higher unit limits than you.

I didn't understand the point of Offense/Defense/Support roles.
I just played Offense and didn't care about any of that.

Resource scarcitiy, doesn't exist. All units are free. Poof.
Unlimited unit count? Nah. You have a 50 point limit, with the good units costing 6 points. So you spend most of the time with just 8 units. Sometimes you even have to destroy your own units so you can build some specific unit the campaign requires you to use.
The big fun of turtling up and then just overrunning the enemy with a huge army? Nope, not a thing.

Oh and also, the enemy can have multiple bases, giving them higher unit limits than you.

I didn't understand the point of Offense/Defense/Support roles.
I just played Offense and didn't care about any of that.

column8:
Yeah, what needs to be said that hasn't? 
This isn't c&c, at least not in any way that it's been made in the past. I'm not sure you can even call it an rts in the traditional sense given how limited you are with the lack of base building, limited units, and so forth. Just because they tried to continue the tiberium story line and slapped in the videos doesn't make it a c&c game when they completely changed the way it's played. 
In short, this is kind of garbage. . .not the quiet no smell garbage, but like a flaming paper bag of s**t that stinks up the whole neighborhood. No clue what the devs were even thinking by ruining a classic rts like they did here.

column8: At the age of 42, I wanted to finally play this game as C&C was a part of my childhood. However, when I installed this game and tried to play, I had to spend time finding my EA account password. Then I had to enter the password twice (once to start the game and once to play the game). This was the last game in the franchise and I can see why. It's a total disaster! The name is C&C but the gameplay is anything but! You only get a crawler that pumps out units and there's a limit. WTF is this?! No base building or strategy involved.

column8:
Sorry not sorry, but this is the crappiest command and conquer game I ever had the displeasure of playing. Nothing in this game screams command and conquer at all. It's as if this game tried to mix elements of command and conquer, StarCraft, and MOBA, and miserably failed at capturing beloved elements from the 3 games.

Gameplay is horridly restrictive, forcing you to choose between offense, defense, and support MCVs, each with their own unique unit lineup, and any change of tactics requires you to stay incapacitated until the new MCV arrives. 

Units just pump out without the need of any resources, and you need to progress your levels to unlock said units.

Attacks don't feel impactful at all, you can have 50 units worth of airships hammering down on a single infantry and it still takes forever to eliminate them.

Unless you play defense MCV, there's no such thing as building a base in this game.

I know this has been released for a long time already, but EA should've made another franchise instead of sticking this experimental crap to the Tiberium series. 

If you're reading this, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME solo, unless you're purchasing the command and conquer bundle on sale.

column9:
[h1] This is an absolutely awful and utterly stupid game.[/h1] I've played many RTS games, but this is the worst one I've ever seen. I recently bought the entire C&C series, and I didn't expect to be eating pure garbage so soon! First of all: the resources downloaded from Steam are faulty and cannot be opened directly; the gameplay and quality of the game itself have huge problems. The removal of resource gathering and power, but only the population cap, is a design that surprised me from the very beginning. Can you imagine? The only difference between building a super-giant tank and an engineer is the time difference; the unit upgrade design is very similar to Warcraft and Starcraft [b]but the stupid EA can't even copy properly[/b]; the game server itself is extremely unstable, frequently disconnecting, and disconnecting means I've wasted my campaign time; the game dialogue has no subtitles, no simplified Chinese (only traditional Chinese), making the tutorial feel like a fairy dialogue; the CGs feel cheap, like something out of 2010. The game's CG in 2000 is inferior to that of Red Alert 2 in 2000. The costume and background design are incredibly cheap and simplistic (and the feel of it being presented in a poorly written way is ridiculous). [strike] The unit art style is strange (this is purely a subjective opinion).[/strike] Upgrading and unlocking technology is like StarCraft 2's cooperative campaign, but StarCraft 2's cooperative campaign is PvE! Who the hell came up with the idea of â€‹â€‹locking technology in PvP?! Do you think that upgrading and unlocking units through campaigns is much smarter than locking technology in each level? Wow, that's ridiculous! I wasted 6GB of my campus network downloading this garbage. [b]It's not even 2062 yet, and thankfully, the parents of all EA employees are on the verge of extinction![/b]

[h1]Kuso Game, Fxxk you EA, stupid EA, go eat shit.[/h1]

column8:
Most of the reviews about this game are around having to make an account to launch and play, it's 2025, every major publisher requires this. It's daft, but them's the breaks.

I have chosen to leave a negative review of this game for a few reasons:

1. When you want to change the graphics settings, the game will crash. It doesn't just hang and take a minute to change them, it straight-up CTDs. So you're stuck playing the first mission in 800*600 and minimum graphics, even if you change them using driver suite software.

2. The new mechanics force you to choose a class. Support, Offence, or Defence, and build units. Wouldn't be an issue but you only have a limited number of swaps per instance. So if you're playing solo and are new to the game, this will get you caught out at least once.

3. Camera zoom is way too high. This is personal preference, of course, but it doesn't allow you to really see much going on outside of the immediate zone of control, severely hampering tactical awareness.

4. Story writing is bad. Just poorly written, badly acted, and not immersive in the way the older games were.

Overall, pick this up on sale, have a laugh for nostalgia's sake, then forget you own it. Never buy at full-price.

column8: This game is awful. First you have to enter you EA account password twice every time you switch in on and then you're playing something that is called Command & Conquer and has Kane in it, but it nothing like C&C. No tiberium, not refineries, no structures to build anything. You get a crawler, that spews out units (5-6) until it reaches limit. Enemy usually has several crawlers and they spit out units quicker than you can kill them... C&C was all about building your base, slowly builidng up defences and units and then killing off the enemy. There is none of that here.

column9: Well, I've seen paid characters that are much stronger than free characters, but even the worst competitive mobile games usually give me a fairly complete starting build with low-level technology and high-level islands. Regardless of whether they're strong or not, at least everyone is equal in terms of quantity. This game makes me feel like I'm playing an MMO. The level-unlocking system means that if you're low-level, you have fewer items than others. Do the developers think that grinding for levels is fun?

column8: c&c serisinin en boktan oyunu amk

I couldn't do it. I bought the complete C&C collection during a steam sale and have been slowly making my way through the other games, but this one was just......why? The acting felt forced and sub-par, who the hell is Gideon, why are we changing up the MCV and unit deployments on the supposedly last game of the series when it has been (mostly) the same for the whole series? Seriously, different classes for MCV and only able to have one at a time? Yeah, sure it speeds things along but that's just forcing everyone to play a rush/blitz style. I made it through the GDI campaign, but I can't go through with the nod campaign. Everything feels so wrong and I need to just uninstall and move on to Red Alert 3.
column9: I couldn't do it. I bought the complete C&C collection during a steam sale and have been slowly making my way through the other games, but this one was just......why? The acting felt forced and sub-par, who the hell is Gideon, why are we changing up the MCV and unit deployments on the supposedly last game of the series when it has been (mostly) the same for the whole series? Seriously, different classes for MCV and only able to have one at a time? Yeah, sure it speeds things along but that's just forcing everyone to play a rush/blitz style. I made it through the GDI campaign, but I can't go through with the nod campaign. Everything feels so wrong and I need to just uninstall and move on to Red Alert 3.

column9:
It's 2025:

- I'm forced to log in to launch the game, but the "create an account" button leads to a page that doesn't allow account creation.

- After finding my login details, I log in, and the game launches (in 800x600 resolution, lol).

- Cutscene
- Login screen in the game, with the same login details... why?

- I go into the options to change the resolution: the game crashes every time.

EA is showing its true colors once again with this game that simply won't launch.

column8: HONTEUX

Back in the day I purchased the physical version of the game, and played a lot.

I can't deny that this entry in the game series differs a lot from the classic C&C formula. I can't deny it and I'll not attempt to deny it. If you can't stand such difference, then go away. This game is not for you.

I can recommend this game, however, because I liked it. Yes, it's different, but in some twisted way, I liked what I saw. I played and finished the physical version of the game a couple of times. That's why I can recommend it even when I haven't played much in Steam.

[h1] Command & Conquerâ„¢ 4 Tiberian Twilight[/h1]

[b]I know it's not you Commander, but whoever is responsible for this treachery will feel my wrath! In the meantime, obliterate what remains of GDI. Nuke them, if you wish![/b]

Of course I could not have planned for an ambush BY MY OWN FORCES! Of all of Kilian's offenses, and they are legion, her proclamation that the Visitors are a greater enemy than GDI is an affront for everything. 
I have planned for the Brotherhood! 
For this sin she must be punished, you will take a team of your best soldiers and storm our Australian base. Kilian is dug in there, capture her alive if possible but spare no one in her charge.[/b]
Kane Lives Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars.

    [*][b]Star Wars tÃ£o simples quanto isso as unidades parecem quase todas equipadas com lazer,(ridÃ­culo) para parecer mais futurista do que nunca depois mesmo os sons e movimentaÃ§Ãµes,[u]parece uma cambada de trapalhÃµes com lazer por todo o lado[/u].[/b]

    [*][b]Jogabilidade simples e fÃ¡cil utilizaÃ§Ã£o, menus acesso rÃ¡pidos.[/b]
    [*][b]Cada faction, GDI & NOD tem 3 tipos The Crawler (officially named the "MCV Mk VII) pode oferecer diferentes tipo de combate e tÃ¡ticas: Offense Class, Defense Class & Support Class.(nada de especial podes alterar a tua estratÃ©gia durante o combate a qualquer momento.)[/b]
    [*] [b]Worldbuilder para quem quer construir o seu prÃ³prio mapa.[/b]
[/list]

[b]You are all so... fragile.
Kane[/b]

[h2] Pontos Negativos: [/h2]
[list]
    [*][b]RenovaÃ§Ã£o total e o abandono da base building agora temos The Crawler que constrÃ³i sÃ³ unidades & defesas, depois somos acompanhados por um progresso de XP para desbloquear novas tropas que funciona para a Campanha & Multiplayer.[/b]
    [*][b]Star Wars tÃ£o simples quanto isso as unidades parecem quase todas equipadas com lazer,(ridÃ­culo) para parecer mais futurista do que nunca depois mesmo os sons e movimentaÃ§Ãµes,[u]parece uma cambada de trapalhÃµes com lazer por todo o lado[/u].[/b]
    [*][b]Outra em relaÃ§Ã£o as unidades e o seu tamanho sÃ£o muito maiores do que os anteriores jogos devido ao facto de ser menos e poder ter menos unidades, visualmente nÃ£o e atrativo nem em design, os avatares (NOD) sÃ£o tÃ£o estÃºpido para dar um exemplo.[/b]
    [*][b]Estruturas, sem sentido visualmente nÃ£o sÃ£o atractivas assim como as unidades um dos problemas graves neste jogo.[/b]
    [*][b]Ambientes & CenÃ¡rios: vira o disco e toca o mesmo nÃ£o tem animais selvagens ou pessoas muito vazio e repetitivo, nÃ£o hÃ¡ diversidade entre cenÃ¡rios.[/b]
    [*][b]Enquanto a banda sonora mais fraca de sempre parece muito espacial do universo Star Wars.[/b]
    [*][b]Skirmish pela primeira vez podes ganhar sÃ³ a controlar as Tiberium Control Network atÃ© fazeres um limite de pontos.[/b]
    [*][b]Outra em relaÃ§Ã£o as unidades que demorar muito mais tempo a disparar a realizar disparos e tem algumas unidades que tens de fazer reload mas  automÃ¡tico claro.(parece que estas a jogar em Slow motion.[/b]
    [*][b]Resources nÃ£o hÃ¡, agora tens de controlar o Tiberium Control Network (TCN) controlas estas zonas ou torres como quiseres chamar Tiberium Control Network (TCN) [/b]
    [*][b]Always-online: sim estÃ¡ aqui tens de fazer login antes de abrires o jogo e dentro do jogo, depois se te acontecer perderes a ligaÃ§Ã£o durante uma missÃ£o da campanha (offline) e nÃ£o salvas-te antes de acabares a missÃ£o podes perder tudo e voltar a fazer, mas atenÃ£o es avisado que perdes-te a ligaÃ§Ã£o.[/b]
    [*][b]Cutscenes sÃ£o fracas comparado com os antecederes os actores nÃ£o tiveram a altura do desafio e nÃ£o deixam a sua marca e sÃ£o genÃ©ricos, Louise James acaba por ser a personagem por detrÃ¡s da lendÃ¡ria faÃ§Ã£o GDI sem carÃ¡ter sempre com a mesma atitude nÃ£o cumpre o seu papel sÃ³ procura vinganÃ§a e faz de tudo para alcanÃ§ar, depois temos do outro lado Gideon Nod Separatists que tambÃ©m querem se vingar contra o falso Profeta kane e por se juntar a GDI, nÃ£o consegues te simpatizar com ninguÃ©m a nÃ£o ser kane porque ninguÃ©m os outro sÃ³ passam no ecrÃ¡ rÃ¡pido e fui embora, outra coisa os cenÃ¡rios das cutscenes nÃ£o mudam sÃ³ as cores de fundo nada mais e os logotipos nas roupas GDI o fundo e azul e Nod Ã© vermelho, roupas bÃ¡sicas e maus atores e mal penteados (exemplo: Chavra NOD) com falhas nos pequenos pormenores.[/b]
[/list]

[b]Aconteceu vÃ¡rias vezes situaÃ§Ãµes de loop comigo e nÃ£o saia daquilo era atÃ© um desistir daquela posiÃ§Ã£o e abandonar depois tinha uma unidade contra mim [u]Cyborg Commando[/u] que tinha o poder de apoderar-se de uma unidade tua e assim sucessivamente, tornava-se complicado elimina-lo devido a distancie e as unidades demorava tempo as disparar.[/b]

Devido ao facto de ser um jogo triste e inacabado, nÃ£o Ã© digno do seu nome e legado.
Tenho e vou ter sempre respeito por C&C o meu 1 jogo na sega saturn e um dos melhores jogo de estratÃ©gia ainda nÃ³s dias de hoje difÃ­cil de igualar, uma franquia lendÃ¡ria no coraÃ§Ã£o dos fans.[/b]

column8:
tl;dr: Is it worth to play for the story? barely yes, just because of Kane's existence, though there is no new revelation. Otherwise absolutely no, not worth it. Don't expect new lore details, everything is new and unrelated to previous lore.
---
Finished the campaign recently on both sides. I was about to uninstall twice during that, but i really wanted to at least see the "story". I finished the campaign without using high end tech like super weapons because it's all locked behind rank ups. It's just bad. For anyone who is wondering if it's worth playing just for the story, i'd say "barely yes" and that's mainly just because of Kane, might be nostalgia, idk.

There is nothing interesting about the story, no new relevant lore pieces or discoveries except the portal, which is sadly totally out of place, in it's appearence and it's purpose in the story (no purpose). Everything that appears in C&C 4 is "new" and absolutely has no ties to previous lore, again, except Kane.

This is such a fun game, gotta trick more people into playing it.

Like many others have said, this game has had everything that made C&C what it was gutted from it.  Even looking at the gameplay itself, removed from all the baggage of being an incredible letdown to the end of the Tiberian Timeline, it's just not fun.  The XP system sucks, the gameplay is no fun, the story is nonsense, and it still remains the only C&C game I've played that I have decided to not finish.  I just couldn't do it, it is devoid of the ability to entertain.

column8:
I want to kill myself after seeing the bug that kept the game running while it bugged out and I can't close it with Task Manager or even trying to AltTab back to the game. This is definitely suicidal...
The Command Screen, they don't even let me zoom out to the better angle we have in the past series where we can see a larger portion of the map. Every time you play, you have to log in and play online even for a single player campaign...Nope, I want to kill myself when I see the bug where the unit stuck in middle of nowhere with nothing around it...it just stuck. I PRESS DELETE TO KILL IT and myself.

Absolutely killing my passion for RTS games. This is an amazing disaster that kills passion and dream. I am calling my local suicide hotline, thanks EA.

column9:
I rarely criticize a game.

Even less often do I buy a game specifically to criticize it.

But C&C4 did it.

As the final installment of the Tiberium series in Command & Conquer, it successfully cemented one of the greatest RTS series, a classic IP on par with Warcraft, StarCraft, and Age of Empires, in its final resting place.

As a Command & Conquer title, it removed resource gathering and added population limits. I play Command & Conquer precisely because it has no population cap. Besides, isn't the power system another strategic element? Command & Conquer 4 is a complete mess. I'm not playing StarCraft, I'm playing Tiberium.

What were these guys at EA thinking? As a 2010 game, its quality isn't even as good as Red Alert 3 (2008), Tiberium Wars (2007), or even Command & Conquer: Generals (2003).

I really don't understand. I really can't understand why EA always manages to take the dross and discard the essence.

A tribute to the legendary IP destroyer, EA.

column8: This game is ridiculously complicated to start. Mostly EA's fault. Signed into my EA account after having a difficult time installing and getting it to run in the first place. I was forced to make a username for multiplayer before I could play the campaign, then I was prompted to sign in again after it randomly closed. I made a username again and was prompted to sign in yet again but this time I was told the password was incorrect. After all of this and the fact that it was super wonky after install in the first place I decided it wasnt worth the effort. What a disgrace to the as a follow up to Tiberium Wars. Dont even bother. As a side note, companies should be sued for forcing you to make an account or sign into it in order to use a product you already purchased AFTER you purchased it. You should have to go through the effort of making an account so its clear that is a requirement for the use of the product. Its making me question ever buying an EA game. This might be the final straw. I dont know if I could possibly recommend a game less.

column8:
Only rating the single player campaign

â€œTiberium Twilightâ€ is the last instalment of the famous Command & Conquer real time strategy series. Officially dubbed â€œC&C 4â€, itâ€™s actually number 9 if counting all the main games bearing the title (including the first-person shooter â€œRenegadeâ€ and excluding add-ons). Looking back at a long history and tradition of fast-paced base building, resource gathering and amassing big armies, at least in the 2D isometric games. The latest ones were trying to bring more of the â€œrock-paper-scissorsâ€ mechanics into the gameplay, with C&C Generals Zero Hour and Tiberium Twilight as the highest form of it. That also meant reducing or even eliminating the base-building and resource-gathering components. Generally speaking, C&C 4 is hence somewhat the last (yet in my view unfinished) step in a journey to adjust the series to a different play style with a potential reboot that was being discussed around the time of the release in 2010. The latter was dropped quickly after the commercial failure of C&C 4 and the demise of RTS in general.

The plot of the game continues and concludes the alternate future time line in which the world was dominated by two factions, Nod and GDI, picking up right after â€œC&C 3 - Tiberium Warsâ€ quite well. Otherwise, unfortunately, the game itself feels incomplete and unbalanced on several accounts as well as falling short again on long-needed improvements on year-old problems such as a limited graphics engine and very low unit AI. Additionally, all the fans of the series who have loved the game especially because of the traditional mechanics might have their issues because of the new play styles. 

After about 13 hours of play time in a normal approach, hereâ€™s my pros/cons list:

Pros: 
+ seamlessly continues story after C&C3 and its add-on
+ high quality cutscenes and good quality actors
+ last and final appearance of Kane
+ interesting conclusion of the timeline, Tiberium infestation, the Nod cult and the legendary figure of Kane
+ great graphics
+ new strategic elements of mobile bases (= crawlers)
+ mutant area mission level design well done and detailed
+ interesting story in general
+ 3 tactics styles to choose from (offensive, defensive, support)
+ great unit detail
+ generally kept look & feel of C&C series

Cons:
-	Game mechanics feel like they were geared towards teams of up to 3 players cooperating in multiplayer matches against others, especially since some units and tactical advantages are missing when playing as single player
-	Kane by now definitely had many more lives than a cat
-	Apart from Kane, his cult and Tiberium conclusion, the plot remains shallow and rather bland
-	Rock-papers-scissors mechanics not working in single player missions due to missing variety in units available by only being able to choose 1 tactic at a time, limiting options drastically
-	Level-up to unlock higher units in most cases unobtainable and hence a player would choose a different approach --> balancing issue
-	Stealing big units from the enemy NPC can become main tactic in winning the single player campaign
-	Command points (= max unit number) limitation too low in single player missions to be able to stand a good chance against the enemy early on in many cases --> balancing issue
-	Missing option to tilt crawler position --> unfinished game element
-	Many missions are trail & error of each of the 3 tactical choices --> balancing issue
-	Unfair nuclear rocket behaviour in last GDI mission --> balancing issue
-	Super overpowered Arcus GDI enemy unit in last Nod mission making it nearly unbeatable --> balancing issue
-	Very unfair Nod pre-order bonus mission â€œNight Movesâ€ --> balancing issue
-	Game is missing explanation of what the advantages are to capture some buildings on the map, players need to find out by themselves
-	Graphics engine is fixed to 30 fps due to necessary internal game speed regulation
-	AI of units still super low which requires lots of micromanagement (they canâ€™t even pick the enemy which they are the strongest against or move in formations without blocking each other all the time)
-	Micromanagement of units decreases real tactical orders and behaviours to be expected of a modern RTS
-	AI still has wayfinding issues on the map
-	Despite resource gathering and base building eliminated, funny enough, the gameplay feels much slower compared to predecessors
-	Campaign missions rather boring and uninspired which is very sad compared to the super fun, varied missions of Red Alert 3
-	Tedious campaign missions, especially because of re-spawning crawlers (= mobile bases)
-	Soundtrack without any C&C characteristics, sounds more like a mix of Star Wars, Indiana Jones and psychedelic Japanese singing
-	Missing detailed explanation of 3 tactics, including differences in units etc.
-	Graphic bugs appeared several times, persisting throughout whole missions
-	Some game crashes
-	Annoying double login forced on player before game start and just before the main menu without option to save login information
-	Story ending of Kane somewhere between stupid (GDI part) and well done (general conclusion)
-	The protagonistâ€™s wife is such a silly damsel in distress, unlike all the other strong women in earlier instalments

Conclusion:
Although C&C 4 wraps up the Tiberium timeline quite well, the plot is very shallow and boring. The new mechanics introduced appear to be unfinished and badly balanced, making many missions very tedious and sometimes even highly frustrating. I generally liked the look & feel of the game and was eager to try out a new tactical approach to the game play, but the downsides tainted my experience quite a lot. Hence, I can only recommend the game to anyone who wants to know about the conclusion of the series from a plot standpoint. From an RTS perspective, the game is rather disappointing, especially after an amazing Red Alert 3. 

Rating: 4/10 points

column8:
[h1] DO NOT PURCHASE - UNPLAYABLE DUE TO BUG [/h1]

I bought the C&C Bundle with the interest of trying out the classics and C&C:4. 

I tried to boot up C&C4, same problems as other C&C games thanks to E.A scuffage of the IP - requiring online access and an EA account at all times with no offline option. Requires 2 separate login screens - the 2nd login screen is where the game-breaking bug occurs.

According to the Community, C&C4's 2nd login screen only accepts E.A Account passwords under 7 characters. Passwords over 8 characters will fail, and there is also a Character limit of about 14 characters.

There is no known bypass or fix for this bug.

I hope there is a fix, because I doubt this is the only C&C game affected by E.A's blasted logins and online-only enforcement.

Maybe a cracked version somewhere on the high seas exists without the Online requirement and E.A's nonsense.

[h1] DO NOT PURCHASE - UNPLAYABLE DUE TO BUG [/h1]

column9: I wanted to try the game because I'm a big fan of this series. Unfortunately, after installation, registration is mandatory, which I wouldn't mind so much (on the other hand, why bother the player with that, right?), if it worked normally. First, I tried registering via Steam, which logged in, an ad for other EA games popped up, but I didn't get the login details for the game. OK, try no. 2 via email. Registration via email already exists - fine, I'll enter the password, that's even correct, however, we'd rather send a code to the email (which didn't come). I think OK, I don't really care what email I'm going to play it on, so I registered again on a new email. There (after about 30 minutes of unnecessary registration) I got to the "riddles" that I'm human. It took me a while to understand in broken Czech (the best thing is when the AI â€‹â€‹generates a verifier to verify that I'm human, I consider that a real goal), what the goal is, after clicking away I had to complete two more similar puzzles and finally I learned that I'm not human. Well, I don't have to play everything either. There are so many tragedies in EA that it's hard to believe. :-( The last game from EA that I bought (even if it was in a bundle).

you need some extra account to play it.
you need to input your password multiple times per game start.

it crashed as soon as I tried to change the resolution from potato to post-1995. 

i want my 0.4h back and even though I did not technically buy this game, but rather buy a bundle with C&C Games, I feel kinda scammed, that this was in the bundle.

I wouldnt even recommend to give it a go if you get it for free.

column8: I started playing it because I wanted to see why it was being called such a terrible game.  After about six hours of playing it, I said to myself, "I have only played a few levels, how has six hours gone by already?" Turns out that I was taking multiple breaks because playing this game was almost like working.  I felt like I was just playing it, just to get through it.  It has fairly good graphics seeing as how it came out 15 years ago but unfortunately, they were just wasted.  I was trying to enjoy it but to no avail.  I literally realized that mid-way through doing the dishes (during one of my breaks) that I was enjoying doing dishes more than this game.  Unfortunate.

column8:
This entry in the Command and Conquer series is just a boring slogfest that has either taken away or worsen every element  C&C is comprised of.

- The FMV-scenes are even shlockier than Tiberian Sun, at least that entry had charme.
- Ressource management is non existent, Tiberium is no a power up to be collected in individual crystals.
- Your choice of Crawler (HQ) only gives you a subset of units, so adapting to your enemy is a hassle as you have to scrap you HQ to build a new one.
- It's just boring, boring, boring. Even the level design is mediocre at best.

column8:
Estamos ante otro de los RTS hechos por EA Los Angeles (que tomo la continuacion del antiguo Westwood Studios) mas concretamente con la ultima entrega tanto de EA LA como de los juegos de esta indole (hubo otros 2 Command &Conquer pero que no tenian mucho que ver con este) y desde ya no incluyo la remasterizacion de Petroglyph del 2020 porque no es nueva.

Que nos ofrece el titulo? Algo un poco mas en la linea de jugabilidad similar a un Warhammer 40k Dawn of war 3, tiene elementos de RTS pero mas simplificados en lo que respecta a construir bases.
mantiene si el estilo visual ya marcado en la ultima entrega, que se aleja de la guerra tradicional para ir a un enfoque mas futurista, Estilo Starcraft, Dune y en menor medida Warhammer.

Tiene 2 CampaÃ±as, la GDI y NOD, cada una progresa de acuerdo a como va la historia del C&C, podes hacer misiones cooperativas, lo cual esta bastante interesante Y tiene workshop y editor de niveles.

Lamentablemente no posee ni logros ni Cromos y tiene algunos temitas para poder loguearse, pero sacando eso es un gran titulo, hay que saber disfrutarlo.

6.5/10 - Pudo ser mejor claramente, pero da sus horas de diversion.
column9:
We're looking at another RTS from EA Los Angeles (which took over from the former Westwood Studios), specifically the last installment from both EA LA and the series of games of this type (there were two other Command & Conquer games, but they weren't very similar to this one). I'm not including the 2020 Petroglyph remaster because it's not new.

What does the title offer? It's a bit more in line with Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War 3 in terms of gameplay. It has RTS elements, but they're more simplified when it comes to base building.
It maintains the visual style established in the last installment, which moves away from traditional warfare towards a more futuristic approach, reminiscent of Starcraft, Dune, and to a lesser extent, Warhammer.

It has two campaigns, GDI and NOD, each progressing according to the C&C storyline. You can do cooperative missions, which is quite interesting, and it also has a workshop and level editor.

Unfortunately, it doesn't have achievements or trading cards, and there are a few login issues, but aside from that, it's a great title; you just have to know how to enjoy it.

6.5/10 - It could have been better, but it provides hours of fun.

column8:
Wasted Potential, Poor Execution

â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜†â˜† (1/5)

Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight had the potential to be something unique, but the execution is missing something crucial. Instead of refining classic RTS mechanics, it replaces them with a limited, shallow system where strategy takes a backseat. The removal of base building and resource management leads to restrictive, small-scale battles that lack depth. The mobile base (Crawler) concept could have been interesting, but in practice, it makes everything feel constrained rather than dynamic.

The campaign doesnâ€™t help. The story is rushed and unsatisfying, and the characters are bland with lifeless performances. Even Kane, usually a commanding presence, feels dumbed down and uninspired. Thereâ€™s no real emotional weight to the narrative, and none of the characters leave a lasting impact.

I have tried the multiplayer, but it made the game a bit less boring. If the core gameplay is this flawed, no amount of online play can fix it.

This game could have been something fresh and exciting, but instead, it feels incomplete and uninspired. Even on its own, it just doesnâ€™t hold up as a good strategy game.

column9:
A decent game, but EA is totally screwing you over.

You launch the game.
You have to enter your EA login details.
The game starts.
You're asked for your EA account password again once you're in the game.

And this happens every single time you start the game (it's incredibly annoying).

Plus, a little extra: if you switch windows in the game, you can't switch back for some unknown reason; the game screen disappears, only the sound remains. Absolutely brilliant.

The worst part is that the game itself isn't bad, but this is just ridiculous. A game from 2010 is more secure than my banking app.

Fuck you EA! It's utterly ridiculous that I have to now go and pirate a game I paid for but its not functional because these fucks just don't care... they were fine taking my money though, and they have zero accountability for any of it.

column8:
So, got the game some time ago... felt like meh. i'll play it.. It requires an EA account to get into the game.. fine.. whatever.. I created one.. Then you error trying to log in.. most forms tell you to you know,.. just keep at it.. or do a command for it to be admin only.. went to systems files and did allow for admin.. kinda crazy.. it loads...

Then when you load into the game.. a new promt for the logan info you just did and what not.. okay.. cool-. The game itself is kind of a steep learning curve but its also different.. i thought i'd be able to keep playing.. turns out.. admining the game so you can actually play is against EA policy and the game thinks your cheating- so i got my EA account banned-... Dont recommend buying unless you want your EA account at risk

column8:
This is by far one of the worst Command & Conquer games that is in existence, besides the garbage that is the mobile games. The way this plays is like anything but the previous titles that came before this abomination. It is fully deserving of having the negative review score that it does along with just never being mentioned about in the C&C fan base as an official game. Allow me to list as to why this is one of the worst RTS games I have ever played.

The leveling progression system:
Unlike the previous titles, where the way you unlocked more units and structures throughout the campaign, the way the progression system works is what I would expect to see in a MMO RPG game like World of Warcraft, not in a RTS game. In order to unlock more units, structures, and upgrades, you have to earn XP in game and level up to unlock more. Which makes this game outrageously difficult starting at the beginning. Especially in the campaigns, where AI enemies are absurdly strong having everything unlocked in the first missions, while you're stuck with the most basic of units that can barely do anything. This ultimately turns the game into a grind fest for the campaign missions and skirmish matches, just to be able to unlock more units and tech to make the game easier. And of course, levels you gain through NOD and GDI are earned separately, so you're having to grind as each faction to unlock more tech.

Unit cap and game play mechanics:
The unit cap in this game is absolutely obnoxious and unnecessary, especially since none of the prior titles ever had unit limits integrated into them (except for the console versions of RA3 and Tib wars 3 & Kanes Wrath due to hardware limitations on Xbox and Playstation), which makes the game feel smaller since you're now commanding only small squads of units instead of whole armies. The most you'll ever get for unit cap is around 50-60 unit points for campaign, and up to 90 unit points in skirmish or online matches. And it is horribly small, especially since a lot of the units take around 6-8 unit points, so you don't get to really build much of an army, as much as you get more of just a large squad of units instead. Of course, this can easily get broken if you get the husk repair upgrades while playing as Offense crawlers.

Speaking of which, instead of MCVs, you get a production unit/structure called a "crawler" instead. These just build all your vehicles, infantry, and aircraft instead of traditional productions buildings in prior games. This mechanic is one I hate the most, as I enjoyed having like 8-10 barracks or war factories just pumping out a massive army of units. Instead, you only get to build one unit at a time, with a max of five being able to be stored in your crawler while it's mobile. And the only crawler that can even build any sort of structures is the defense crawler, but that only builds bases defenses and nothing else.

Game play experience:
The fact that C&C 4 is an always online game means that you have to log into an EA account in order to get online and play this game. It doesn't matter how or which platform you use to play this, you still need an EA account just to be able to even fully launch this game. Even then, good luck trying to get on, as I've had multiple times where I'd randomly get forced out of a game due to connection issues and be forced to log back in, losing any experience that I gained during the middle of a match or campaign mission.

Overall summary:
I wouldn't consider this even an official C&C game. The way it plays and functions strays so far away from the C&C game series that it shouldn't even classify as one. The game play mechanics aren't enjoyable and generic at best, the level progression system makes this game grindier than it ever needed to be, and there's so many technical issues that it makes it honestly difficult to play. This is a game I would honestly recommend any C&C fan to steer clear from.

TL;DR
If I was given the choice to watch grass grow for a week or play this game for an hour, I'd rather watch grass grow.

Spiel via Sammelbox im Angebot erhalten.

Nach der Installation musste ich mir erstmal einen EA-Account erstellen.

Nachdem ich nach ca. 2 Stunden endlich schaffte Ã¼ber den Launcher hinaus das Spiel zu starten,
durfte ich mich erstmal 4 mal hintereinander mit betrÃ¤chtlichen Ladezeiten bei EA anmelden.
Dazu kam, dass das Spiel danach mehrere male abstÃ¼rzte.
Das 4 malige Anmelden bei EA war jedoch nicht vergÃ¤nglich und musste bei jedem Neustart erneut durchgefÃ¼hrt werden.

Die LÃ¶sung des START-Problems liegt mir Ã¼bringens nicht vor. Kurz bevor ich es aufgeben wollte versuchte ich es noch ein allerletztes mal ohne jegliche Ã„nderungen. Das Spiel selbst lÃ¤sst sich Ã¼brigens ohne Internet-Zugang nicht starten.

Als ich dann zum allerersten mal das MenÃ¼ zu sehen bekam,
erinnerte es mich ein wenig an eine komplett abgespeckte Version von C&C-Generals, nur in richtig billig.

Ein riesiger trostloser Chat, permanent aktiv, am unteren Bildschirmrand, angebliche Spieler die darin durchgehend angezeigt werden, aber keiner schreibt noch reagiert.

In den Optionen musste ich erstmal die Grafikeinstellungen hoch drehen.
Denn das Spiel schien mein FullHD-Display mit einer AuflÃ¶sung von 860x640p und komplett minimalen Einstellungen als empfehlenswert zu betrachten. Danach wurde es aber auch nicht schÃ¶ner.

Um rein zu kommen wollte ich zuallererst mal ein Gefecht gegen die KI starten,
bis ich die Option fand vergingen Minuten. Die Struktur des MenÃ¼s wechselte plÃ¶tzlich von Hoch/Runter nach Links/Rechts.

Es gibt augenscheinlich keine richtigen Einstellungen fÃ¼r Gefechte,
ist aber auch egal, denn mehr als einen 3 Minuten "Bitte Warten" Timer bekam ich Ã¼ber eine Stunde Wartezeit nicht zu sehen.
Gefechte gegen die KI lassen sich einfach nicht starten.

Also startete ich den Story-Modus,
bei dem die ersten 3 Missionen scheinbar das Tutorial sind, waren mega schlecht, und waren gleichzeitig eine Einleitung in die Geschichte. Die Zwischensequenzen kommen in der gesamten Breite in QualitÃ¤t nach C&C-1.

Die Grafik des Spiels ist absolute Katastrophe und schaut aus wie an C&C-Generals angelegt,
aber um mehr als 80% reduziert. Die Effekte und Bewegungsanimationen der Einheiten sehen so dermaÃŸen schei...., billig aus, dass niemals das GefÃ¼hl aufkommt man wÃ¼rde mit schwerer Kiregsmaschinerie Ã¼ber das Schlachtfeld ziehen.

Wie bereits bekannt der nicht existierende Basisbau,
Gott sei dank gibt es keinen Basisbau, ich glaube ich hÃ¤tte bei dieser schlechten Grafik/Animation das kotzen bekommen.
Nein ernsthaft... WO IST DER BASISBAU ???

Da es keine Bau-Voraussetzungen via "baue DIES und bekomme Zugang zu DAS" mehr gibt,
mÃ¼ssen Einheiten jetzt im gesamten Spiel, wie bei einem Multiplayer-EgoShooter, via Prestige-Ranking freigeschaltet werden.

Zusatzoptionen wie Untertitel funktionieren auch nur Just for Fun.

Ich hab nach nicht mal 3 Stunden das Spiel wieder aus gemacht.
Davon habe ich rund mehr als die HÃ¤lfte im MenÃ¼, in den Optionen, am meisten in Warteschleifen und ein wenig im Chat verbracht in dem ich hoffte mal jemanden zu erwischen der auch mal auf meine Fragen reagiert.
Bis auf eine Hand voll fragwÃ¼rdiger Reaktionen auf Englisch, gehe ich davon aus das es sich wohl mÃ¶glich um Bots handelt.

Fazit: Absolut kein bisschen zu empfehlen, nicht einmal ansatzweise. !!!!!!

PS: Ich suche immer noch die Funktion das Spiel wieder auf normalem Wege vom Rechner zu DEINSTALLIEREN.
column9:
I received the game via a bundle deal.

After installation, I first had to create an EA account.

After about two hours, I finally managed to get past the launcher and start the game,

but then I had to log in to EA four times in a row, with considerable loading times.

On top of that, the game crashed several times afterward.

The four logins to EA weren't permanent and had to be repeated every time I restarted the game.

I still don't have a solution for the startup problem. Just before I was about to give up, I tried one last time without making any changes. The game itself can't be started without an internet connection.

When I finally saw the menu for the very first time,

it reminded me a bit of a completely stripped-down version of C&C Generals, only really cheap.

A huge, dreary chat window, permanently active, at the bottom of the screen, supposedly showing players, but no one was typing or responding.

In the options menu, I first had to crank up the graphics settings.

The game seemed to consider my FullHD display with a resolution of 860x640p and completely minimum settings as suitable. Even after that, it didn't look any better.

To get started, I wanted to start a battle against the AI,

but it took minutes to find the option. The menu structure suddenly changed from Up/Down to Left/Right.

There don't seem to be any proper settings for battles,

but it doesn't really matter, because all I saw for over an hour was a 3-minute "Please Wait" timer.

Battles against the AI â€‹â€‹simply won't start.

So I started the story mode,

where the first three missions seem to be the tutorial. They were incredibly bad and simultaneously served as an introduction to the story. The cutscenes, in terms of quality, are on par with C&C-1.

The game's graphics are an absolute disaster and look like they're based on C&C Generals,

but reduced by more than 80%. The effects and movement animations of the units look so incredibly cheap and awful that you never get the feeling you're driving heavy military machinery across the battlefield.

As already mentioned, there's no base building.

Thank goodness there isn't; I think I would have been sick of such terrible graphics and animation.

Seriously though... WHERE IS THE BASE BUILDING???

Since there are no more building prerequisites like "build THIS and get access to THAT,"
units now have to be unlocked throughout the entire game, like in a multiplayer first-person shooter, via prestige rankings.

Additional options like subtitles only work for fun.

I turned the game off after less than three hours.

I spent well over half of that time in the menu, in the options, mostly in queues, and a little in the chat hoping to finally get someone to answer my questions.

Apart from a handful of questionable responses in English, I assume they're all bots.

Conclusion: Absolutely not recommended, not even remotely. !!!!!!

PS: I'm still looking for the function to uninstall the game from my computer the normal way.

column8: This game is just terrible. It is completely unplayable in both a literal and figurative sense. It bears not even a passing resemblance to any of the other C&C games. No base building, no resource gathering, but they added minuscule supply caps so that you can engage in exciting...12 unit battles? I tried my best to make it through this game but there are constant crashes and login issues. Just absolute utter trash.

column9: I recently finished playing the CNC trilogy. Although I'd heard that the fourth installment was awful, I didn't expect it to be this bad after playing for a few dozen minutes. This game is like a pseudo-human, a half-hearted attempt to pass itself off as CNC. Some parts seem to echo the previous games, but they're just clumsy imitations. The game system is completely nerfed and has been condemned to death. Besides, while the unit models are cartoonish, they don't improve recognizability at all. The units are so huge that you can't fit several on screen at once. The navigation is terrible; you can't even navigate manually when there's a traffic jam. Entering the game requires entering your account and password twice, and after playing for forty minutes, it suddenly crashes and asks me to log in again. To make such a awful game and still put it in such a classic series as a legitimate sequel is truly appalling. I have nothing to say to EA. This game is an insult to my library.

column8: Kal, eto ne C&C

Do I have to say anything about why this game was the worst? Besides completely changing how the game is played, how this was supposed to be a spin off game but EA made the decision to make it a Triple A game, how they ruined the story of the Tiberium series with one of the worst CnC stories along with one of the  weakest endings to a series/ franchise ever, from ruining Kane's character, from having to level up to get better units, from having to log in and play online even on single player. From even releasing a broken version of the game on Steam that you have to find a workaround to even play the game. There's a reason as to why people don't acknowledge this game nor ever mention it, this game is the embodiment of EA, greedy ba****** who ruin any franchise they acquire for making quick cash. Taking something that was successful and running it into the dirt for what? A little more profit? In the end they lose more money for making this POS rather than making a real CnC 4. With the steam workshop update along with the source code being released, maybe, just maybe EA will attempt to make a proper CnC game after all these years but never hold your breath for EA.

This game is bad, the launcher is a mess and getting the game to work/start was a huge hassle between it not starting, it took at least five tries, plus having to register and you have to log in twice through the launcher, then again login in-game which at any point either logins could fail to connect to the server. Once or if you finally get to play, it requires an online connection at all times including single player, even if you have excellent internet, the server may fail at any given point in which your progress will not be saved. The worst is yet to come, there is no real skirmish, it is all based on sort of missions that are beyond boring and basic. the server lost connection on mission 2 and even though I completed it, I would have to redo it. This game is not fun and no wonder it was the final straw to killing the Command & Conquer franchise.

If you want to try an RTS with gameplay that's different from the classic base build, give it a look, perhaps taking advantage of a discount.

column9: I guess you have to be a mobile "gamer" to give this miserable abomination a thumbs up. And don't worry. I played both the third and fourth installments off Steam years ago, but I recently decided to return to the series here. Third and its expansion were truly wonderful. For the past two weeks, while playing Third, I felt like I'd returned to the glory days of gaming... and now it's time for this. It's not even an RTS. It's a lousy clicker for people with an IQ as high as my stinking, week-old sock. Poor unit limits, minimal base and unit management, poor cutscenes, and so on. I really wonder what motivated the people who designed this thing, let alone those who released it after verifying its "quality." Even free is too much for this game. Don't waste your time or disk space.

column9: Nobody likes this installment, and rightly so. After the awesome Tiberium Wars and Red Alert 3, this is simply sad. Few missions, boring gameplay, and this supposedly major new feature sucks. Missions have a time limit, and the cutscenes are more cringeworthy than anything else. Even though practically everything was done wrong, the ending sequence has a certain something. Thumbs up because the game runs without errors and can be fun for non-veterans. Still, it's a disappointment for me personally.

column9:
Reasons for purchasing

1. You want to know the ending of the game series.

That's all.

Cons

1. The gameplay itself: now you have no money, all troops are free, but everything is tied to a troop limit.

2. You need an internet connection, and you have to log in twice each time you launch the game!

3. I logged in on day 1 and played fine. Day 2. I got some kind of error, but the game launched. Day 3. The game returned an error about an inconsistency and decided not to launch anymore! Awesome! Windows 11 is official.

4. Monotonous plot. We essentially play the same missions, but from different sides, and the ending for the main character is the same... That is, for us and for the plot as a whole... (We supposedly have a body, but the plot is the History of Tiberius and Whitewasher, it hasn't changed!)

5. You won't want to play this online, and you're unlikely to find opponents. Online games are just capturing points, that's all. (I played the entire game using a pirated version on an old PC about 10 years ago, according to the script.)

The worst game in the series!

column8:
Many users report issues with the EA login system, such as "General System Error." This could be due to server problems, outdated compatibility settings, or restrictions on password formats, Some players speculate that EA may have shut down servers for the game, making it unplayable for both single-player and multiplayer modes.
The game may not run properly on newer operating systems like Windows 10 or 11. Adjusting compatibility settings or running the game as an administrator has helped some users. Beyond technical issues, the game itself has been criticized for its departure from traditional Command & Conquer gameplay, which has left many fans disappointed.....

column9: I bought the game as part of a bundle and had my doubts about whether it would actually be playable. It does require an EA account, which I already have due to several other games. Otherwise, you have to create an account on the EA Games website. My login details were accepted immediately, but I kept getting a "system error" message during the login process. After what felt like 5-10 consecutive attempts, the game finally started. I set all the settings to Ultra and adjusted the resolution to my monitor. With a little patience and perseverance, you can get the game running, and I think the negative reviews regarding this are exaggerated.

I bought this game on major discount and I payed too much for the opportunity to confirm the validity of the poor reviews for this game.

What kind of game dev decides that instead of playing into all the things that make a game franchise fun and popular they would rather remove and minimize all of those great qualities to leave buyers with a game no one wanted to play from the start.

Mission design is terrible.  Graphics feel worse than C&C3.  Unit pathing is worse than Starcraft ONE.

And did you enjoy resource extraction, unit build ups, and base building?  Well this game has none of that.

Did you enjoy being able to starve your enemies of resources and steal their buildings?  Yeah, cant do that in C&C4.

I've never seen such a huge miss on such a simple assignment.  Check out the end story on youtube.  Its not that good either.

column8:
I played this game when it was first released back in 2010

Steam would only allow me to review it once i installed and try to play the game.  I bought the C&C collection as I don't have to use a cd/dvd to play any of the games.

I forgot you had to login twice to play this game.  I just remember playing this game for 2 weeks, completing it and never playing it again.

so from C&C 1 to C&C 3 and generals, the games basically got better and the best game I found was the Red Alert series, but this game was so bad there was no C&C 4 Red alert.

so back in 2010 when I had bought this game, I was angry, I had completed this game, never wanted to play the game again and at the time, it was possible to sell games on the 2nd hand market, but this game I was stuck with.

All I remember this game was a completely new concept at the time, it was a shame it was not tested, but it was no longer building a base, but having a mobile control station and having a defence and offence command post and you no longer had to build a base, or gather resources.

so one of the best C&C games was generals and this game basically was the sad death of command and conquer.

If it was a good game, I might have been able to tolerate the digital rights management, but I basically played it for 2 weeks from release.

The only reason I have this game on steam is because it came with the complete C&C collection.

this game in the series is universally hated.

It is a real shame that EA did not go back to the tried and tested C&C, but just stopped the franchise dead.

I can't remember in 2010, if I had to install the physical game from DVD and there was a massive update that was needed to be installed before I even got to play the game and I think I needed to have the disc in my pc drive, log in to the EA account and maybe a further login, well this was at the time of really slow broadband.

The positive I can say about the game is, I managed to complete it and if I played it now, I probably still hate it, but my new pc would be able to run it at full graphics.

I still play Command and Conquer Generals and Red Alert 3, it is just disappointing that the multiplayer has been switched off due to the games age, but I have not played this game after completing it when it was first released.

column9:
Pros: Good quality, good art, good music; made to AAA standards.

Cons: Everything else is bad.

1. Optimization is terrible. The resolution is still not fixed, causing various game crashes. A simple windowed mode or a launcher settings option is much better. Stop hiding the keys in treasure chests!

2. Gameplay: Overall, it's a pseudo-high-skill game that relies on skillful maneuvering. It forces you to quickly assemble a dozen or so mutually reinforcing and countering aircraft and tanks, then combine various attribute skills to capture towers or collect gems, requiring precise micro-management. Too niche, difficult to learn, and you won't understand it in less than two months, deterring 99% of players.

3. The most ridiculous thing is that unit types and skills require experience to acquire. It's utterly absurd. Otherwise, you'd be playing as a machine gunner against various enemy warships and fortresses.

Similarly, RA2, from the same company, look at its lifespan. Don't be reckless; innovation is a double-edged sword. Far more companies die from innovation than from stagnation.

Of course, receiving overwhelmingly negative reviews isn't something that happens easily, and this game is the king of kings.

column8:
This game isn't in itself very bad, but it should have never been marketed as a singleplayer game and given the name of C&C4. It should have been a spinoff like Generals etc.

It's a really interesting attempt at RTS without base-building and with a class-based approach. It's very far from being a great RTS, but there's something fun here. It takes a very rock-paper-scissors approach to the problem and you can have a decent skirmish match in this game.

The game was initially conceived as an esports title called C&C Arena and was built off C&C3, and you can tell. The campaign, the story and the FMVs are disastrously bad. This is weird, because RA3 had great FMVs and a fun story. It seems like there was a fundamental problem with the singleplayer design, probably not enough time was given to the team.

Unfortunately this game ended up killing the franchise. That honor normally would go to Generals 2/C&C2013, but if I'm being honest, the hit this game did to the credibility of EA C&C (until 2020) was absolutely horrible. The team transitioned to doing browser/mobile C&C and Generals 2 was arguably as poorly managed as this game. It's a shame. Anyway, try this game out if you're curious.

column8:
EA made ASTONISHING work to make sure you won't enjoy it:
1. You need EA account to play this "game".
2. You need to enter EA account credentials TWICE, EVERY time you launch the game.
3. Changing game screen resolution is a quest!
4. If you alt+tab, say good buy to your game session. You can't restore game window and have to kill the process in Task manager and restart it (Enjoy second point again).
5. On startup, game occasionally goes into alt+tab state by itself (hello fourth point!).
6. In average, after single mission, next mission you will enjoy solid pink textures flooding your screen (issue with loading textures properly). (You must be already a top EA fan if you still wish to continue..)
7. After completing campaign missions you see the panel of obtained EXP, which is... always(?) zero! You know why? Game never tells you. Hint: but be so kind and go play skirmish to get EXP.

So, after playing for ONLY 2 hours I formed a well-based opinion that the ones who praise this game (all 2.5 people) and say the game would be great if it weren't a direct C&C series follower, must be smoking some serious stuff.

column8:
Horrendous!
After 15 years of this game being launched and it having the recent source code release (Feb 2025), this game is still a PITA to get running.

It STILL expects you to log into an EA account to play it, multiple times, then tells you that your credentials are invalid! I can't even get to the main menu! Instant uninstall, no game is worth this amount of pointless and arbitrary hoop-jumping.

I hear that it's also only online, not that I'd know!
Until someone mods out the EA Login requirement, which I doubt is possible, avoid this 'game' like the plague!

column8:
You have to make an EA Account and login to play at all. No offline mode with optional online login. 

The 'Skirmish' mode you can't turn off the time limit or adjust things as freely in the options.

They basically turned it into some mishmatch of Mechwarrior Online or CoD but in C&C where you unlock things and have a profile that has performance history.

I don't like it. And i had to go through trouble to play it since it wouldn't run without a specific dot net runtime.

on top of that, asides from my personal opinion of the game itself, this also is another negative for EA, who won't even let me login with my own password to change my email and they want bank info that i dont have to change the old email.. it's trash. straight burning garbage of trash. i hope their company collapses in 2025 so i can dance on the grave of it's failures.

column9:
Paying for nostalgia, the game has no flaws, negative reviews are to call for attention.

We need Westwood Resurrection, the gameplay, controls, and interface are compatible with modern computers. We need Chinese language support, cloud saves, and achievements. EA games should be sold cheaply, EA and Steam should merge into Steam. Ubi and GOG too.

This is all for now, more to come later. Brothers, I strongly suggest not buying from small shops on third-party platforms, especially those reselling items through the Steam Market. Buying through these channels, like cosmetics, has a high probability of getting a red letter or even having your account banned. Proceed with caution.

column9:
After the initial download and installation, don't rush into the game. It's best to restart your system first, otherwise you might not be able to log in.

Forced account login is available, but connection is often unsuccessful.

Although released after Red Alert 3, the graphics feel like a step backward; even the live-action cutscenes are inferior to Red Alert 3.

Texture errors; building units either don't display or only partially show up.

Besides making up for lost time, it's completely not worth buying.

column8: NÃ£o funciona.

How do you get everything so wrong?!

Functionally, you have to mess around to get the game to work.
Story wise it is drab and may as well be a radio play for the boring indoor visuals.
Game play wise you can't get to the end of the tech tree just playing the campaign.
Strategy wise - you can just play everything with the same strategy and units and there's never the time to develop a more nuanced build.

Positives: 

Doesn't have loot boxes or endless daily quests...

column8:
Most of what the reviews are saying is true. EA tried to do something different this time and it didn't please everyone. My verdict is that this game is probably more fun for casual gamers and not serious RTS players. The gameplay was definitely watered down from the previous installments. I am a loyal C&C fan, so I wanted to play it to keep up with the overall storyline and check out some of the units.

PROS:
1. I did not think the units were that cartoony. I was impressed to see how they advanced. 
A. TITANS are back. Got to love mechs! Everything is bigger and more mechanized than before.
2. Excellent graphics that don't require a super expensive graphics card.
3. Classes can be fun to play and less stressful if you are a casual player. The whole game is very relaxed for a C&C game. I realize this is not the intent of most RTS games. Lol

CONS
1. Acting is awkward and stiff. Eg; Commander's wife.
2. While I like the soundtrack somewhat better than C&C 3's, it will never measure up to Frank Klepacki's backing tracks.
3. Mobile MCV game style is annoying. I miss building bases.
4. Female voice overs are annoying. I think it was clear the devs are trying to boast girl power, which I dislike and am strongly against having this kind of undertone in one of my favorite games.

5. The plot is interesting enough, but not great. It is all about the containment of tiberium on Earth and Nod forces are cooperating with, but also betraying, GDI forces. This is sort of a repeat of some of the last game's storyline. There are no scrin in this game because they had been pushed out and retreated in the last game. Still, it would have been more interesting to see them return. I guess this leaves room for a potential C&C5.

column8:
Always online, always glitchy graphics, always crashes.
Braindead gameplay, base building is gone, energy is gone and tiberium is gone. Units are free and there's a unit cap now, it's extremely low, so you're just throwing a handful of units at each other to see who wins.
Units are also separated into 3 classes for some reason, you can only build one subset of all units.
The damage model is confusing, heavy weapons do less damage to light vehicles than light weapons? I don't get it.
The story is so bad it's just taking the piss, just referencing random things and persons from the games without much care about previous lore.

column8:
This game likely wouldnâ€™t have received so much hate if the developers hadnâ€™t included the "4" in the title. It should have been treated as a spin-off rather than a direct continuation of the series.

I wonâ€™t lie, I actually like the gameplay concept. Itâ€™s fun and less stressful, which is about the only thing I genuinely enjoy about this game.

What Doesnâ€™t Work for Me?

1. Cringeworthy Storyline
The storyline is painfully awkward. Was it really necessary to add a romance subplot? Every time I see a cutscene where the commander (player) interacts with his wife, I cringe. The worst moment comes at the end of the NOD campaign when she cries over her hubby's death. It just feels so forced and unnatural.

2. Disappointing Music
The soundtrack is a letdown. The GDI music is passable, but the NOD tracks completely miss the mark. Instead of capturing NODâ€™s signature dark and intense vibe, it sounds more like tribal chanting from some random village in Kuvukiland.

3. Strange Unit Scaling
The proportions of some units are way off. Certain vehicles are unnecessarily large.. take The Forgotten's "school bus" for example. Itâ€™s somehow the same size as a Mammoth Tank, which is just ridiculous.

4. Weak Sound Design
The weapon sounds are underwhelming. Guns, cannons, rocketsâ€”none of them have the impact they should. Even the legendary Obelisk of Light no longer gives off that powerful "ZWEEENG" sound. And the rocket visuals? They're so tiny, they look more like fireworks than deadly projectiles.

At the end of the day, I know Iâ€™m wasting time reviewing a 15-year-old game that will never get updated. But still, what a missed opportunity.

column9: Tiberian Twilight is a mockery of the RTS legacy. Lacking its own bases, with units limited by absurd "caps," and a story that tramples on decades of lore. Chaotic gameplay, boring design, and an unnecessary mandatory online system. EA buried the saga with this fiasco. Unredeemable garbage.

column9:
I thought I'd give the game a chance despite the negative reviews, since I love the Tiberium series. At the beginning, you're asked for an EA login (even for single-player). I tried logging in with the correct credentials, but every time I got a general system error.

There are dozens of people online describing the same problem. It's probably related to the servers being shut down.

column8:
umm nope, I wanted to try it out, because its "part of the story" just youtube the cinematics if you're that desperate.  The overall idea is interesting, but it is SO BADLY implemented it really isn't worth playing. The first couple of missions might not seem so bad but maybe 4-5 mission in you realise just how terrible the rock-paper-scissors-lizard-spock-ad nauseam the counter unit system (you basically have to memorise what unit counters what).

You basically get in to fights where no one is winning.  If that sounds fun to you, be my guest.

column8:
NOTE: This is NOT Command & Conquer. 

I read a whole mess of the reviews after I purchased this "game" via the "Ultimate Collection."
They're right. They're all right... Well, the negative ones anyway. 

Here's how my experience went:
1) Launcher wants you to sign in with your EA account... [Ok, fine.]
2) Error... [Fuck]
3) Error persists seeming at random. [What THE fuck?]
4) Suddenly it's all fine for the game to start up. Nothing changed.  [Riiiiiight...]
5) A different login asking for the same information... [Ooookaaay?]
6) Pretty cool looking loading screen... [but why is it all blue?]
7) Start skirmish. [Oh... Oh god no.]
8) Exit and delete.

I absolutely DO NOT recommend purchasing this thing. It's very much bottom of the barrel for EA.
As I said at the top, it is NOT C&C. It's some base-level cash in. I have B-grade mobile games with more RTS soul than this.

To those running EA, I hope L*igi gets out and takes great offence to your actions.

column8:
Yeah, no
I really wanted to give this one a go after all these years. My 1st experience was awful playing this since my friend got me a pirated version of this from the local market and it is on 4 discs. Had a lot of "fun" installing it and cracking it all for it to be a C&C without base building, xp grinding and a boring C&C campaign both story and mission structure due to the nature of walking "bases".
The soundtrack is even not that good compared to other C&C games somehow... how did they manage to mess that up?
Clearly this was meant to be a Online Only game for Asian players and it shows. Kind of reminds me of the saddly failed attempt at Company Of Heroes Online which was kind of awesome honestly.

It doesn't work most of the time, even on EA app and when it works it is just not fun. Reminds me of the Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak due to its gameplay style, but worse.

column8: EA why?? you screw up the login? EA today uses the EA app and I don't see why this game should be different and most of the bad reviews are about the login, I did get it to work eventually and if anyone is having the same problem there are guides on steam that can help you get the game to load. Personally I have always been a fan of the CNC series and this is the first time on CNC 4 the game can take some getting used too as it uses an entirely different system set into offence, defence, support and the main command centre is mobile making the whole game more challenging than previous titles, most people seem to dislike this way of playing a CNC game but after playing for awhile it can make for some really interesting game play it just takes some time getting used to. The graphics are much better then previous titles and you get a real sense of elevation and differences in the maps terrain, the units range from small to massive and the names are different from previous titles. The sounds is not bad and i like them as it gives that CNC feel to the game. Overall people don't like the login which is understandable and they find it to challenging were as if you grind you can get through the levels and also they don't like the online service that does not have anyone available however I have found at certain times it is populated. I give the game 8/10 for graphics 8/10 for sounds and 8/10 for game play overall 8/10 as is a good game if you take the time to adjust to the new system but the login should be scrapped.

column9:
I bought the game on Steam. So what?
Launcher: Error (General System Error)
And if it's not the Launcher, and the game itself launches, it still won't let you into the menu due to some incompatibility.
I recorded myself...
I wish EA management would eat blood soup for dinner!
It's a disgrace what they did with the CNC series, and the fact that the game itself is unplayable; it's impossible to get into it.
But I admit that when I played a pirated version once and unlocked most of the technology in single-player, the next time the attackers could form a great formation with MSC and destroy everyone.
