column8:
to launch cnc4 in 2025 on win10. servers are closed, but u can play it in single player.
1. go to install folder, click Properties on cnc4.exe, in compability tab check Run as administrator, click apply, ok.
2. create new EA.com account in web browser. password must be exactly 8 symbols, 1 big letter at least and 1 number at least. only letters and numbers.
3. launch the game with cnc4.exe in files folder. when promped by windows to make chages, click yes - allow.
4. type email for ur new ea account and password
5. choose some ingame name that is not already taken, click PLay.
6. when cutscene starts, press Esc to skip it.
7. when u see another login screen, alt +tab to desktop, find Windows Firewall promt for cnc4 and click OK - Allow access to internet.
8. Again enter email and password for ur new ea account.

i saw 7 ppl online in chat. 1 responded. we launched coop campaign mission. nothing else works. no custom skirmish, no coop automatch, no pvp, no coop vs ai. only coop campaign with other players.  have not testes single player. maybe can lauch skirmish solo.

the campaign mission crashed the game in middle of mission. will try to lower graphics settings.

[Kane looks at you with a smirk]
Kane: You look good. Here, see for yourself.
[Kane places a mirror in front of you, and you see in the reflection that you look exactly like yourself. Kane]

â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•©â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•©â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

If If you're familiar with the Tiberium Wars series, it's probably no secret that these strategy games are captivating. The fourth installment is released on a new engine, and the core of the game has undergone a number of changes: there's no longer any need to earn money or build bases (the defensive crawler is an exception, but more on that later). The construction center or headquarters have been replaced by crawlers, which combine all the functions of a base. Crawlers can be defensive, offensive, or supportive. Essentially, the game boils down to quickly creating units and leveling them up. The number of units is limited, and that's the only challenge.

column8:
This game managed to kill even the messiah.

But I still give it a thumbs up for having nailed something perfectly: the end time atmosphere.

Perhaps not in the way intended. But in a meta sense, that, in a strange twist of abstraction, made it even better. So, yeah. We witnessed a real death here. It's over, folks. It's over.

column8:
[h1][i]â€œPeace through powe... ğŸ’¥â€[/i]
~Kane[/h1]

So, overwhelmingly negative status, huh? You don't see that often. Also, it's a well-known fact that this game is a series killer. That's right. One of the most influential and important series for the RTS genre, the one that shaped and defined it the way we know it today was destroyed by this little fella here. How did that happen? To understand that we should first go for a quick summary.

1992 â€“ [b]Dune II[/b] is released. Based on [b]David Lynch[/b]'s adaptation of [b]Frank Herbert[/b]'s novel, it introduced series' core gameplay. We were collecting [b]Spice[/b] with out harvester vehicles to earn credits and then spending those credits to build ourselves base and an army. 1995 â€“ the first [b]C&C[/b] is made. While being spiritual successor of [b]Dune II[/b], the game had much more serious tone, while also including FMV elements. 1996 â€“ [b]Red Alert[/b]. Pretty much the same thing with [b]C&C[/b], just with some improvements, naval battles [i]and[/i] an important backstory to [b]C&C[/b] villain â€“ [b]Kane[/b], who was revealed as evil mastermind behind the humanity's major history events. 1997 â€“ [b]Sole Survivor[/b]. Failed attempt for online-only deathmatch experience based on the original [b]C&C[/b] game.

1999 â€“ [b]Tiberian Sun[/b]. The first game after [b]EA[/b] acquisition. Originally planned as much more complicated project, it ended up feeling a bit rushed, but still, in many ways it was a sequel everybody waited for. 2000 â€“ [b]Red Alert 2[/b]. Made mostly by new members under [b]EA[/b], it rebooted the [b]RA[/b] series. Shared universe was no more. 2002 â€“ [b]Renegade[/b]. Failed attempt to make next-gen mixture between RTS and FPS genres. 2003 â€“ [b]Generals[/b]. The first game after the series' creators were shut down by [b]EA[/b]. Rather weird attempt to reboot series by dropping the old lore and altering core mechanics from [b]Dune II[/b]. 2007 â€“ [b]C&C3[/b]. A pretty smart U-turn for the series that brought it back to its roots and felt a lot like remake of the 1995 game. 2008 â€“ [b]Red Alert 3[/b]. A consoles-oriented game that felt more like [b]Generals 2[/b] and also introduced us to co-op. Thanks to which it felt more like online-oriented spin-off. Yet it was a very good game that lots of people loved. And [i]that[/i] was the beginning of the end.

How's the good game is a bad thing you may ask? You see, it made [b]EA[/b] believe that quick online sessions is what people wanted. You may expect them to learn from [b]Sole Survivor[/b]'s failure, but it was an ancient history, while at the moment [b]RA3[/b] was selling really well, so... Yeah. [b]C&C4[/b] was planned as a co-op-oriented project. Which... Isn't a bad thing per se. I mean, [b]RA3[/b] was good, right? Unfortunately, the fact that people swallowed [b]RA3[/b] being more [b]Generals[/b] than the original [b]C&C[/b], gave [b]EA[/b] another idea. An idea that... *SIGH* But OK, let's finally take a proper look at what we've got. And what we've got is... Anything but [b]C&C[/b].

I know, I know, it comes from a person who keeps saying that [b]Generals[/b] was not really [b]C&C[/b], but this here? It took every single [b]C&C[/b] element and flushed 'em down the toilet. Resource gathering? Believe it or not, it's no more. Remember the days we were arguing about [b]Generals[/b] having resource management similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] instead of our usual [b]Dune II[/b] thing? Well, resources are no more. No resources â€“ no problem by [b]EA[/b] logic. Technically, [b]Tiberium[/b] ([b]C&C[/b]'s counterpart of [b]Spice[/b]) is still here, but it's just some crystals you'll be able to pick up now and then to upgrade units. Like I said, resource gathering? Not a thing. And so is a base building. Again, remember that old argument about how in [b]Generals[/b] we were able to build anywhere (similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] too), while â€œrealâ€ [b]C&C[/b] was all about the construction yard and things we were building around it? In this game we can't build at all. Well, technically, there [i]is[/i] one building. And the whole game revolves around it.

Everybody who played [b]C&C[/b] is familiar with the [b]MCV[/b]. So-called mobile construction vehicle was pretty much a portable construction yard. The original idea was to let us choose place for our new base to get the advantage we wanted. Now? Now it's more like our portable all-in-one base. Not only we can move it at any time ([b]StarCraft[/b] anyone?), it also acts like all other buildings from previous games. We build units, we purchase upgrades, we use powers... You've got the idea. Our whole base is just that â€“ one fat [b]MCV[/b]. Where do we get money to produce units, you may ask? Well, that's a very good question, because in this game? You don't need money. You're free to build as many units as you want. There's a very strict population limit now, though, much more strict than in those [b]BLIZZARD[/b] titles. But that's just a thing. Forget about those big armies. Our goal in this game is, while only having a few units, to figure out perfect combination to outsmart our enemy.

But OK, you may say that simplified take on [b]Company of Heroes[/b], while not being a [b]C&C[/b] at all, may still be a good game. True. And that's where our second problem comes in. See, [b]C&C4[/b] is not a well-made product. Not even thought-through. The first thing you'll notice after the initial shock is... how hard this game is. Which... isn't even true. The problem is â€“ single player campaign here is tied to your online profile. Remember the challenges from [b]RA3[/b] expansion? The ones, where you started with close to no technologies (units)? That's the stuff. You start single player campaign with nothing. Yet doing some skirmish grinding first will make it much easier. And a lot of grinding? You guessed it, there are no limits. Grind for the highest commander level (may take quite some time, especially since [b]GDI[/b] and [b]Nod[/b] are leveled separately) and get big advantage for your single player experience. What. The f*ck? Pretty sure single player experience implies dealing with properly calculated conditions. Here? It's a lot like playing story in some MMO. You stuck? Go grind somewhere else and come back later. Like I said, WTF?

Thankfully, most likely, you won't even get a chance to suffer through all that. Why? *SIGH* Did you play [b]Anthem[/b], guys? [b]C&C4[/b] was exactly that long before it. Starting [b]C&C4[/b] goes like this â€“ launch the game, enter login and password for your [b]EA[/b] account, get an error, change password to fit eight symbols (don't ask me why) and voilÃ ! The game works. Is it, though? Right after launch you'll be asked to enter login and password [i]again[/i]. Only this time even the short password won't help. Why? Because you need to have [b]EA[/b] app running on background. Again, don't ask me why (it doesn't look like the game interacts with it). Even after all that, there's still a chance for a game to tell you to go f*ck yourself. Hello, [b]Anthem[/b]. How you doin'?

So here we are. Not only this game dropped everything that we fell in love back in 1992, it also feels rushed (naturally, it's buggy and imbalanced too) and, well, it's half-broken. And it's all pretty sad, you know? The atmosphere here is quite solid. Moreover, the story is quite creative. It has FMV cutscenes, it's told from the first-person perspective and we, the commander, are the main character. The one who plays the most important role. We [i]finally[/i] got [b]Kane[/b] explained, there [i]is[/i] a proper ending for the [b]Tiberium[/b] saga... Sure, it's too short (game only has seven missions per faction), but still, with some proper gameplay, it'll be quite enjoyable. Unfortunately, [b]C&C4[/b] is a mixture of the unfortunate coincidences and bad decisions. When you look back, you see that such a mistake was inevitable. But it [i]is[/i] [b]EA[/b]'s fault that shot ended up being deadly. Dixi.

Like I said, resource gathering? Not a thing. And so is a base building. Again, remember that old argument about how in [b]Generals[/b] we were able to build anywhere (similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] too), while â€œrealâ€ [b]C&C[/b] was all about the construction yard and things we were building around it? In this game we can't build at all. Well, technically, there [i]is[/i] one building. And the whole game revolves around it.

Everybody who played [b]C&C[/b] is familiar with the [b]MCV[/b]. So-called mobile construction vehicle was pretty much a portable construction yard. The original idea was to let us choose place for our new base to get the advantage we wanted. Now? Now it's more like our portable all-in-one base. Not only we can move it at any time ([b]StarCraft[/b] anyone?), it also acts like all other buildings from previous games. We build units, we purchase upgrades, we use powers... You've got the idea. Our whole base is just that â€“ one fat [b]MCV[/b]. Where do we get money to produce units, you may ask? Well, that's a very good question, because in this game? You don't need money. You're free to build as many units as you want. There's a very strict population limit now, though, much more strict than in those [b]BLIZZARD[/b] titles. But that's just a thing. Forget about those big armies. Our goal in this game is, while only having a few units, to figure out perfect combination to outsmart our enemy.

But OK, you may say that simplified take on [b]Company of Heroes[/b], while not being a [b]C&C[/b] at all, may still be a good game. True. And that's where our second problem comes in. See, [b]C&C4[/b] is not a well-made product. Not even thought-through. The first thing you'll notice after the initial shock is... how hard this game is. Which... isn't even true. The problem is â€“ single player campaign here is tied to your online profile. Remember the challenges from [b]RA3[/b] expansion? The ones, where you started with close to no technologies (units)? That's the stuff. You start single player campaign with nothing. Yet doing some skirmish grinding first will make it much easier. And a lot of grinding? You guessed it, there are no limits. Grind for the highest commander level (may take quite some time, especially since [b]GDI[/b] and [b]Nod[/b] are leveled separately) and get big advantage for your single player experience. What. The f*ck? Pretty sure single player experience implies dealing with properly calculated conditions. Here? It's a lot like playing story in some MMO. You stuck? Go grind somewhere else and come back later. Like I said, WTF?

Thankfully, most likely, you won't even get a chance to suffer through all that. Why? *SIGH* Did you play [b]Anthem[/b], guys? [b]C&C4[/b] was exactly that long before it. Starting [b]C&C4[/b] goes like this â€“ launch the game, enter login and password for your [b]EA[/b] account, get an error, change password to fit eight symbols (don't ask me why) and voilÃ ! The game works. Is it, though? Right after launch you'll be asked to enter login and password [i]again[/i]. Only this time even the short password won't help. Why? Because you need to have [b]EA[/b] app running on background. Again, don't ask me why (it doesn't look like the game interacts with it). Even after all that, there's still a chance for a game to tell you to go f*ck yourself. Hello, [b]Anthem[/b]. How you doin'?

So here we are. Not only this game dropped everything that we fell in love back in 1992, it also feels rushed (naturally, it's buggy and imbalanced too) and, well, it's half-broken. And it's all pretty sad, you know? The atmosphere here is quite solid. Moreover, the story is quite creative. It has FMV cutscenes, it's told from the first-person perspective and we, the commander, are the main character. The one who plays the most important role. We [i]finally[/i] got [b]Kane[/b] explained, there [i]is[/i] a proper ending for the [b]Tiberium[/b] saga... Sure, it's too short (game only has seven missions per faction), but still, with some proper gameplay, it'll be quite enjoyable. Unfortunately, [b]C&C4[/b] is a mixture of the unfortunate coincidences and bad decisions. When you look back, you see that such a mistake was inevitable. But it [i]is[/i] [b]EA[/b]'s fault that shot ended up being deadly. Dixi.

column8:
It's not just a bad C&C game, it's a bad RTS. It's fascinating how it exists and nobody at any point didn't halt further development. It doesn't feature base building, something C&C is iconic for, but instead features a "Command Unit" which, by itself, is actually a cool idea but in execution for this game is dreadful. The game series is infamous for spam, it's often known as "Spam & Conquer" for whoever spams the most MBTs first wins. This game not only amplifies that, it limits you from doing much of anything else. 


The unit design is strange too. It feels like a mod more than a sensible professional game studio, but it also feels like a mobile game more than a computer game made by a game studio. The campaign constantly ruins lore and immersion. To this day, what lives rent free in my head is the mission where you need to save x amount of busses the GDI is trying to slaughter. You could literally sit there, turtle, and watch thousands of busses be destroyed for an infant amount spawn and drive, you just need to save X amount for a mission success.  I don't know how anyone can play the game without losing any little immersion they have by such low thought out "video-gamey" moments. 

Speaking of lore, spoilers! Not that you should play this game,,,, 
[spoiler] You also assassinate Kane at the end of the GDI campaign with a sniper. Nothing crazy to elaborate,  just they decided he is super special and requires a super special bullet to kill him. No, no biblical references to Cane. No, no references to cloning. No, no references to anything that made C&C special and Kane special, no interesting reveal, just "he's just super special because he's around the Tiberium so much". It's just better to leave mysteries alone, they didn't need to answer this mystery, and they answered it so lazily and boring.
[/spoiler]

Overall, game is terrible. Don't play it. It killed the series. It killed it so badly that all we get are slop mobile games now.

Ğ£ Ğ¿Ñ–Ğ´ÑÑƒĞ¼ĞºÑƒ Ñ ÑĞºĞ°Ğ¶Ñƒ Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞµ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğµ - Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ñ” ÑĞ¼ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¾Ğº Ğ·Ğ° Ñ†ĞµĞ¹ Ñ„Ñ–Ğ½Ğ°Ğ». Ğ¡Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ñ 4 Ğ· 10.

EN

The last part of the legendary game series, and this fact makes me and most of the fans of Command & Conquer universe even more upset and sour from the experience of playing it. I will not be surprised that EA deliberately buried the hope for next part in the future in order to continue milking more profitable franchises.

Let's start with the plot. C&C was not famous for its stories and characters, but still they attracted our attention and we were interested in following further actions. The fourth one does not give any clear development of the Tiberium universe. The characters are gray and are inseparable from each other, even Kane cannot direct this whole mess that is plot into the right direction. There are no details and well-known plot points of the story from the end of the previous game - Kane's Wrath. Data also did not return. And I won't say anything about the Scrin - they are simply not there (only mentioned), although a huge hint of their return was demonstrated at the end of their campaign.

The gameplay has changed fundamentally and the very fact has angered many players, but in my personal opinion the problem is not in this, but in the implementation. The dynamics of the game and the game design of the missions are lame, along with the maps and gamemodes of regular skirmishes (and there is only one  - point control). The might of all units and buildings is not felt, even the combat troops of the last, third level do not show fear on the battlefield. The apogee of disappointment were the iconic robot "Avatar" and the tank "Mammoth". Some seem completely useless to me and I do not understand why they were created (like NOD's aftershock). The presence of command points significantly limits the player and deliberately makes the game less desirable. The tasks that are given to us during the walkthrough are of little interest, and the additional ones generally have practically no meaning of their existence. The only optional ones that were worthy of completion are rescue of prisoners in the mission. where we try to catch Gideon ("Heresy's Award"), and the most interesting one is where we kill the sniper ("Bleed Out").

The graphics are nice and do not disappoint, and the unit designs are creative, sometimes. The soundtrack is the only part of the game that can and must be praised. The composers did care about the end result.

In the end, I will say only one thing - I am consumed by sorrow because of this end. I give it 4 out of 10.
It's not the greatest game the older ones are better but it's playable

column8:
Recommended to those who are not familiar with any other games of Command & Conquer franchise.

IMHO the game could have much better reception if it was not released as part of C&C Tiberium franchise. 
The gameplay concept is completely changed from classical resource gathering and base building to managing the mobile factories of 3 types (air, vehicles or infantry units production + their support). 
A worthy parts of the game are soundrack and list of units. All other things are worse comparing to previous games of the serie.
Too bad the achievements are not integrated to Steam.
Due to bad reception it is no surprise if multiplayer mode is wasted, sucks, etc.

column9:
I'm really disappointed with Command & Conquerâ„¢ 4 Tiberian Twilight.

This whole login mess is a disaster. The game doesn't even start when you install it from Steam. So I uninstalled it and reinstalled it via the EA app. But if you think it's starting now, you're mistaken. The EA app has to be open, and from there you have to start the game once and wait for the error message from the EA app. Close the error message and start the game from the desktop. Now the login works, for whatever reason... Once you're finally in the game, you think, "Cool, I can play!" Haha, but no, it would be too good to be true. You have to configure everything first, graphics, etc. Once that's done, you can finally start. But if you think it's like C&C 3, you'll be very disappointed. The whole gameplay system with these so-called scrollers is just so stupid. You have offense, defense, and support. If you want to switch between these, you always have to destroy the pre-built Croller, since it combines all the buildings into one. You no longer have power plants or vehicle factories, nothing at all. You're limited in terms of units, etc. Goodbye C&C charm!

I don't know what EA was thinking. But I can't recommend this game.

column8: This game is a very fun and original for its time C&C series spin-off wrongly calculated and advertised many years ago as 4th main title. You doesn't build Your base, You doesn't harvest resources, instead You'll got three types of the MCV to choose from, each with different unit types available to produce and for the rest of the time trying to combine and micro Your few units (cause of the pop cap never seen in any C&C before - excluding Sole Survivor) with or without friends to take over certain buildings around the map. These places generate points You'll need to collect to win the game. Destroying enemy forces will give You the points too. One game could take even few hours. Sounds boring but its not, especially when You must level up both GDI and NOD to get better units and upgrades. It weirdly reminds me of Halo Wars, but slower paced. Honestly speaking this title is really worth Your time while waiting for real fourth main C&C game. Or maybe idk 8th if EA still can't count properly.

column8:
How to bypass the EA bug to play C&C 4 Tiberian Twillight (Fixed) and successfully launched the game.

1) Right click the game in your library and select browse local files.

2) Find the application (.exe) file CNC4, right click and select properties. Under Compatibility, make sure that Run this program as administrator is checked, and apply.

3) Make sure that your EA.com password is 8 characters  also that make sure it does not have 
ANY SPECIAL CHARACTERS IN IT [!@#$%^&*].

Noted: This game will not work if there are more than 8 characters in your passwords.

4) Bingo, The game should work and you can see for yourself why so many people who have gotten it to work still hate it.

Eigentlich schon ein wÃ¼rdiger Nachfolger! 
Also wenns denn dann doch mal lÃ¤uft wies soll...
Habe die komplette Reihe fÃ¼r 6 Euro bekommen und bin gespannt ob mich bei allen Spielen die gleichen Probleme mit dem Passwort erwarten... einfach nur nervig!
Die Missionen sind bisher (8 Stunden) sehr abswechslungsreich und mir offenbaren sich immer neue Taktiken.
Grafisch sehr gut gelungen und die Maps machen Lust zu erkunden statt direkt den Feind platt zu machen und weiter gehts - Das lÃ¤sst der dauernde Zeitdruck aber irgendwie nicht so wirklich zu. 
Wer normalerweise riesige Armeen in die Schlacht schickt hat noch einen Grund zum umdenken denn die kriegt man einfach nicht zusammen.
An die guten alten Zeiten mit "Generals" wird es definitiv nicht anknÃ¼pfen kÃ¶nnen aber die Story zocken is Pflicht.
Das Spiel kÃ¶nnte noch sehr lange nach der Weihnachtszeit Freude bereiten... wenns denn startet XD
column9:
Actually, a worthy successor!

So, if it ever works as it should...

I got the complete series for 6 euros and I'm curious to see if I'll encounter the same password problems in all the games... simply annoying!

The missions so far (8 hours) are very varied, and I'm constantly discovering new tactics.

Graphically very well done, and the maps make you want to explore instead of just wiping out the enemy and moving on â€“ but the constant time pressure doesn't really allow for that.

Anyone who normally sends huge armies into battle has another reason to rethink their strategy, because you simply can't assemble them.

It definitely won't be able to recapture the good old days of "Generals," but playing the story mode is a must.

The game could provide enjoyment long after the Christmas season... if it ever launches XD

The plot of this episode is completely terrible. In the earlier C&C episodes, Ken had a certain charisma, but in this episode, aside from the same appearance and name, it's like asking, "Are you Ken's brother? Why are your personalities so different?" I have to log in to my EA account twice every time I enter the game. Sometimes it says "incorrect password" (even though it's correct), and I have to log in multiple times before I can connect and enter the game. But I only play the single-player campaign, and constantly having to log in is really annoying. The gameplay is also poor. Like Red Alert 3, it inherits the bugs of "Generals," and it even has a commander promotion systemâ€”not the "Generals" system, but more like an online/mobile game. Your account has rank progression, and it's divided into GDI and NOD, one for each. You can only progress faster by unlocking more in-game achievements. Although you don't need to collect resources to recruit troops, there's a limit of 50-60 units. Each type of troop occupies a different number of units, which means you might only have ten troops in a battle before you can't recruit any more. Playing real-time strategy like this is really... The resources you collect in each battle are used to unlock new commander abilities... If you want to jump straight into the campaign on the hardest difficulty, with hordes of enemy troops, NOD enemies constantly capturing your machines and mission objectives, it'll all tell you to upgrade your commander's level first...

column8:
It sucks. Technical issues with the always online requirements aside, it isn't fun to play. No base building, no resource gathering, pathetically limited unit cap, units are overall uninteresting, the game play is uninteresting, the story makes no sense, the cut scenes all look like a youtuber made them, and all this pretends to be a mainline command and conquer game. It was so bad that EA pretty much killed the franchise after this disaster. I wouldn't even consider anything in this canon. This game is at best a spin off that had some story super glued onto it at the last minute, as it was originally developed as a mobile game. EA sucks as a company and ruined my favorite franchise in history and this game just bleeds that out of every crevice. 

F*ck EA for making this garbage and I hope against hope no one buys this.

I decided to give this game a chance despite my reservations, but it turned out to be a huge disappointment. It doesnâ€™t play like the rest of the series at all. Instead of the strategic depth I expected, thereâ€™s just one mech, no base-building, and no resource gathering. The units felt awkward and unpolishedâ€”far from what I hoped for in the fourth main installment. They had so much material to build on from the rest of the series but failed to adapt anything meaningful. Overall, itâ€™s just a terrible game.

column8:
TLDR: Disgusting 'recreation' of the best RTS series of all time; marred by stupid double-logins

Pros:
- None

Cons;
- Requires you to change your EA login password to 8 characters in length with 1 uppercase character.  
- Requires you to login twice just to reach the main menu
- Completely destroys everything that made the original games fun; primarily, base-building.  

I regret installing this trash

column9: At first, I was puzzled as to why such a classic game would have so many negative reviews. After playing it once... sigh, it's a Frankenstein's monster, neither StarCraft nor Warcraft, and it's tainted my impression of Command & Conquer.

column8: The game that killed the Command and Conquer series. I so badly want to like this game because it has many of the classic units you remember from past C&C games. The issue is that this game tried to reinvent the franchise by getting rid of everything that made the series great. Base building is replaced with crawlers that act as like a mobile unit that can create more units. The amount of units that you can create is minuscule, the campaign is short and boring, multiplayer no longer exists and there is no skirmish mode. There is no reason to buy this game as all you have access to is campaign, and that's after jumping through hoops to get the game to boot. This game is included in the C&C collection on steam, and that's the only reason anyone should get this game. Even after you get it, I still don't recommend trying it unless you must know why we don't get Command and Conquer games anymore.

column8: When I launch this game, I am greeted to a login screen asking me for my EA account information. I do not have an EA account. I bought this game on Steam, not Origin or anywhere else. Do not buy this game unless you have an EA account. You must be online to play this game, even in single player.

column9:
The biggest problem is whether it even runs. Aside from that, other aspects are also unsatisfactory.

As the official mainline installment of the CNC series, it deviates from the established rules by drastically altering the gameplay. The building and economic systems were removed, and a population limit was added (roughly 3 T1 infantry, 6 T1 units, 12 T3 large units, totaling 50 population), destroying the series' original grand battle scenes. The storyline is even more outrageous. The perfectly good tech tree was split into three parts (offensive, defensive, and support), making it virtually impossible for a single player to achieve combined arms or air-ground coordination. And as the final installment, the final battle feels completely uninspired.

Even disregarding the CNC series, it's a mess. As an RTS game, units are unlocked based on commander level, and GDI and NOD levels are calculated separately. Initially, only T1 low-level units are available, resulting in low combat power and an inability to utilize elemental advantages. It was initially thought that using T1 units against T2 and T3 units in multiplayer would be incredibly powerful, but even campaign units require leveling up to unlock, making it very difficult without sufficient levels. (However, it's not exceptionally difficult, as even the final mission locks the technology cap at T1.)

The units' designs are quite good, providing inspiration for various mods, which is one of its few contributions.

column8: Even in single player I need to create an account and log on to some lame EA games BS, where the servers doesn't work. After 3-4 hours of googeling and solving different problems, I got to the point where it said I needed to change to a shorter password, and the redit or whatever said I needed to make a 6 digit password to make it work, however EA games require you to have a 8 digit password. The game itself might be the worst in the series, so many of the fundamentals are thrown out the window, and the "new" take on the mechanics I loved in the series are at best sub par. My main problem is that the MCV respawns, so you can not really win like you would in EVERY OTHER C&C game ever. The whole Tiberium thing is just trash, as you will not mine ore like in the old games, and there is no power and almost no building. Just mindless grinding to unlock generic units that seems loosly based on old artwork, but nothing really cool, and all the best cool stuff like missing. Yes, and the ingame clock doesn't really seems to work in like the time we use on this planet, like 10 minutes remaining is somehow way longer than 15 minutes on a real clock. I just play solo skrimish tho', so your experience may vary, if you somehow are able to even get to the menu of this sad end to such an amazing series. I think RA2 is the best, but I still enjoy RA3 alot for context.

column8:
Saying C&C 4 is subpar is not news to longtime C&C fans, but after over a decade of pretending this game did not exist, I finally tried it. Why did I do it? A mix of nostalgia, completionism and a dose of curiosity.
I can now honestly say this game deserves every part of its awful reputation.
Even getting the game running is tricky and I will link a guide in this review if by any chance you want to try it for yourself.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3198390063
Once you actually get it working you will be forced to log in not once but twice every time you launch the game, which will always be connected to the internet. I guess EA was worried that some people would pirate this masterpiece.

 When you actually start playing you will see that the gameplay does not resemble a C&C game whatsoever. No real base building or resource gathering. What do you think this is a C&C game or something? Well, it really does not feel like one at all. When I found out that this was originally an online only game made for the Asian market, which had a story attached to it to sell more copies during production. It all made more sense.
This brings me to the next point.

But Vogel, besides the gameplay C&C always had a fun story, Full motion video cutscenes, are those any good? The answer to that question my friends is a solid negative. The story feels like some lazy fanfiction that you would find on the internet. The cutscenes obviously have much lower production values compared to Tiberian Sun and C&C 3. Here is a good visual example of what I mean when I speak of lower production values.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=522954423

As I was watching these cutscenes I was wondering if Joseph Kucan (Kane) was thinking about the good old days when this franchise would feature Hollywood actors like Michael Ironside, J.K. Simmons, James Earl Jones, Billy Dee Williams and Ray Wise. I can't say I have heard of any of the actors who were cast for C&C 4 and frankly besides Joe Kucan,  most of them were not very memorable in this game. 
I like Joseph Kucan as an actor and I was always surprised that he did not have more roles in Hollywood movies, he would have been great as a villain in a James Bond movie during the Pierce Brosnan era, but I digress. It is just a shame that C&C 4 was the sendoff that a character as iconic in PC gaming as Kane and the C&C franchise got.

Some people would bring up the music as an example of something  good about this game but honestly, I thought it was trying too hard to sound "epic" and after a few hours of play I just wanted to turn it off. Especially the Nod soundtrack. Give me Frank Klepackiâ€™s soundtrack for C&C 95 over this games soundtrack any day. Tracks like â€œAct on Instinctâ€, Remember the track that kicked off the whole C&C series? :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n4AUY-v1nsE


Seriously unless you are a completionist like me and feel the need to play every C&C game, just avoid C&C 4 like a blue Tiberian field during an ion storm.

Aside from the catchy music, this game is utterly worthless! The game mechanics are baffling; is this still Command & Conquer? The gameplay is completely off, and what's with the population limit? The charm of strategy games lies in the deployment and command of large armies.

Furthermore, the single-player campaign feels rushed and disjointed, like a rushed job with an irresponsible ending. Is that all? This game doesn't deserve to be part of the Command & Conquer series at all, a truly disappointing experience for countless veteran players.

column8:
Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight is such a misunderstood gem, I think it honestly gets way too much flak from the community. Sure, itâ€™s a departure from the classic C&C formula, but isnâ€™t that what makes it unique? They ditched base-building and resource-gatheringâ€”yeah, it was boldâ€”but the new Crawler system adds a fresh dynamic that keeps the gameplay moving. Instead of turtling in a base, you're constantly on the move, which makes things feel more tactical and tense. This constant forward momentum really changes the strategy in interesting ways, especially with the three distinct unit types: Offense, Defense, and Support. It really makes every battle feel different depending on which role you take on.

The story? Classic C&C drama. Kaneâ€™s back, GDI and Nod are still at each otherâ€™s throats, and thereâ€™s this whole apocalyptic vibe with Tiberium threatening to destroy Earth. I mean, itâ€™s the end of the Tiberium saga! Sure, the cutscenes have less of that campy charm we loved from earlier games, but they still hit the mark for me. The narrative is darker, but fittingly so for a series finale.

As for the visuals, they might not pop as much as Red Alert 3, but come on, itâ€™s still solid for a 2010 game. The unit designs are cool, especially the upgraded Nod Avatar walkers. People complain about the graphics, but hey, thatâ€™s hardly the point of a strategy game, right? Itâ€™s about the gameplay and thatâ€™s where C&C 4 shines in its own way.

Okay, I know the game has its quirksâ€”logging in every time is annoying (especially when there are technical issues), and sure, the campaign can be a grind if you're not into the whole "leveling up to unlock better units" thing. But if you're patient, itâ€™s totally worth it. The multiplayer and co-op are where this game thrives, offering some seriously fun moments once you get the hang of things.

All in all, Tiberian Twilight isnâ€™t perfect, but itâ€™s definitely not the trainwreck people make it out to be. If youâ€™re a die-hard C&C fan, give it a shot with an open mind. Itâ€™s different, but thatâ€™s not necessarily a bad thing! Itâ€™s a refreshing twist on the formula and a great way to end a legendary saga.

column8:
Considering i got this with EA play, its not that bad..  tiny cost for a game to play.
  
That being said..  compared to all other C&C games, this is trash, online only is a major pain, im having to login again and again with errors, i do eventually get in to play. the whole login to launch, then login again to play.. like seriously lol who thought that was a good idea, never seen that on a game before, major flaw.  

the game itself is such a downgrade from previous C&C games, i always loved to build my base and get the army out, play strategic..  cant really do that in this game.  most missions are done in less than 10mins, the division of  types.. defensive has troops and towers with a power supply, offence has vehicles, support has air units and ability points.
you cant really mix and match them

as a lover of all C&C games, i had to play it and i will finish the campaign at least.
If another ever comes out or is in design phase.. i hope they go back to the real C&C style and dont repeat this tragic mistake of a game.
column9:
Considering i got this with EA play, its not that bad..  tiny cost for a game to play.
  
That being said..  compared to all other C&C games, this is trash, online only is a major pain, im having to login again and again with errors, i do eventually get in to play. the whole login to launch, then login again to play.. like seriously lol who thought that was a good idea, never seen that on a game before, major flaw.  

the game itself is such a downgrade from previous C&C games, i always loved to build my base and get the army out, play strategic..  cant really do that in this game.  most missions are done in less than 10mins, the division of  types.. defensive has troops and towers with a power supply, offence has vehicles, support has air units and ability points.
you cant really mix and match them

as a lover of all C&C games, i had to play it and i will finish the campaign at least.
If another ever comes out or is in design phase.. i hope they go back to the real C&C style and dont repeat this tragic mistake of a game.

Just don't buy or bother.

column9:
Level up to witness the epic ending of Tiberium Saga.
Brilliant, truly brilliant!
Level upâ€”without leveling up, you can't play anything decent.
The epic ending of Tiberium Sagaâ€”it completely buried a legendary RTS series with one installment.

------------------------------------ Let's leave the plot aside for now. [spoiler] Worked for GDI, and his wife died immediately after he became a full member. [/spoiler] Just talking about the skirmish mode, removing economic management and combat, directly using tower defense and point capture, and then forcing players to micro-manage and adjust their unit composition through strong unit countersâ€”this design concept is actually quite interesting.

However, the failed grind-driven mechanism of directly linking unit and upgrade unlocks to level completely ruins the experience. At a low level, you can only build low-level buildings with low-level units, and there's not much to upgrade, making your game experience severely crippledâ€”a complete turn-off.

The units you can use in the campaign are also tied to this level system, and the developers cleverly added experience acquisition restrictionsâ€¦ further discouraging players.

Therefore, for players looking for a casual RTS game to play, this title isn't worth buying. However, if you're aiming to complete the CNC series, are just curious, want to buy it as a bundle, or are adding it to your library, then it might be worth consideringâ€”after all, the game can still be launched and played normally (though not every time).

La saga es buenÃ­sima pero este ultimo lanzamiento es una tremenda cagada, los red alert 3 son muchÃ­simo mejor que este pedazo de MARRÃ“N, hasta me atrevo a decir que los comand & conquer generals es mucho mejor que este juego, venÃ­an re bien con la saga y la re cagaron con este ultimo lanzamiento. No se por que tuvieron la idea de innovar una nueva mecÃ¡nica y para colmo grÃ¡ficos menos que los red alert 3, no se siente satisfactorio en nada. Agradezcan que lo juguÃ© mas de 1 hora por que la verdad no lo pensaba jugar, le habÃ­a dado una oportunidad por respeto a la saga pero ni eso! no puedo! me mata! me saca aÃ±os de vida este juego. 

Dentro de todo y perdÃ³n por mi vocabulario anterior pero se lo merecen por que le erraron bastante, almenos que hagan otro comand & conquer red alert 4 y bien hecho o que el 5 por favor logre tapar lo que el 4 no pudo brindar. Aun confiÃ³ que sacaran otro red alert que tanto esperamos!
column9:
The series is fantastic, but this latest release is a complete disaster. Red Alert 3 is so much better than this piece of garbage. I'd even go so far as to say that Command & Conquer: Generals is far superior. They were doing so well with the series, and they completely ruined it with this latest release. I don't know why they decided to innovate a new mechanic, and to top it off, the graphics are worse than Red Alert 3. It's not satisfying in any way. Be grateful I played it for more than an hour because I honestly wasn't planning on. I gave it a chance out of respect for the series, but not even that! I can't! It kills me! This game takes years off my life.

All things considered, and excuse my previous language, but they deserve it because they really messed up. At least they should make another Command & Conquer: Red Alert 4, and do it right, or at least let Red Alert 5 manage to make up for what Red Alert 4 failed to deliver. I still have faith that they'll release another Red Alert game that we've all been waiting for!

column8:
I bought C&C4 when it first came out. I hated it back then and I thought MAYBE if I installed it now I would appreciate it a bit more. So I wrote this review...
This game is an abomination, a black hole of fun where joy goes to die. Imagine all the worst parts of every Command and Conquer game, mix them together, and then set it on fire. That smoldering, glitch-ridden trash fire would be miles better than this "game."

First off, how did the cut scenes go down in quality fro C&C3? I know the cut scenes were never anything better than a subpar B rated movie, but these are poorly designed even by Westwood standards. The first cut scene was a pair of blocky fighter over a poorly rendered city. Good start. Kane walks down a halway with nothing in his hands of in his coat, then pulls a basketball sized Teseract out of his pocket. From where?

The gameplay? Calling it "gameplay" is a stretch. Itâ€™s more like a soul-crushing exercise in futility. Driving your base around the battle field pumping out rock paper scissor style units as fast as they can be destroyed by the enemy base doing the same thing. This whole sequence is designed solely to annoy players. Thereâ€™s no challenge hereâ€”just frustration. The difficulty comes from trying to keep playing without hurling your keyboard across the room. 

This game is not just badâ€”itâ€™s a crime against humanity. They spent 15 years standing up against their competitors StarCraft, Age of Empires, and Supreme Commander just to throw it out the window to make Command and Conquer League of Legends version? For the very last game in the C&C series it was not the game ANYONE wanted. Were their not play testers? Whoever greenlit this disaster needs to reconsider their life choices. If you like Command and Conquer games I can recommend all of them up to this title. If you value your sanity, avoid this game like the plague.

column8:
This "game" stands as a cautionary tale against always-online games. Some day, those servers may not work anymore and the game will become unplayable. Imagine buying a book and a few years later the publisher gets bought out and suddenly the book's pages go blank. Buying always-online games is the equivalent to renting the game for as long as the developers decide to let you enjoy the product you paid for. Either pirate cracked copies or only support games that are truly offline compatible.

I played this game when it came out and it was honestly terrible for having such a prestigious name. Maybe the world is lucky that you can't even play it anymore.

Units look cartoonish and ultra stylized, more like something out of warcraft than C&C. And you have to grind profile EXP to get points to unlock more advance units. What game does that? Oh wait, this one!

Campaign story is extremely short and pointless, added nothing to the overall Tiberium saga story except for the ending scene.

Not recommended.

column8:
In order to get this game working on Windows you need to do the steps below.
After these steps, I logged into the game on Windows and played it for a bit.
Got curious if I do the same for Steam Deck, if it would work ? It did. I didn't do any of the launch options for Windows and it just worked. I have no explanation. If you are a steam deck user, just wanted to throw this idea out there so you can maybe have a fighting chance.

Here is the SteamOS launch option version change the executable folder to yours: gamemoderun mangohud "/mnt/n_drive/SteamLibrary/steamapps/common/Command and Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight/Data/CNC4.game" -config "../CNC4_English.SkuDef" %command% 

These are copy pasted through the Steam Forums credit goes to MaxSixTux.
Some people say that they were able to get it working without this but sadly for me, all of the steps below had to be done. I like the C&C series and with the price this one has, normally I would recommend it but because its so broken and it might become completely unplayable really easily, I can't recommend it any shape or form.


--------------------
1) Went inside the C&C4 installation folder (where CNC4.exe is), and inside the compatibility tab, enabled the Administration mode for the executable.
2) Logged on inside ea.com with their account (not through Google account token or whatelse etc.) but with an account registered inside their servers. Changed the password in order to have just 8 characters and no special characters (like &%@ etc.)
3) Surfed on the net and found this website: https://gist.github.com/JeodC/cb7d632d1f20646defd0b2d180d43beb

Went in the "Tiberian Twilight" section and read what they wrote there. They stated that you have to go on Steam and put an start-up line:

cmd /c ""PATH-TO-GAMEFOLDER\Data\CNC4.game" -config "..\CNC4_English.SkuDef" %COMMAND%

if you check, there two " after /c. Leave them there, is not a typo. Change only the part "PATH-TO-GAMEFOLDER" with the path directory of C&C4 (if it contains spaces it doesnt matter). For example mine is: cmd /c ""E:\SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Command and Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight\Data\CNC4.game" -config "..\CNC4_English.SkuDef" %COMMAND%

Put the line inside the start-up command line inside Steam and double-check Steam got it right.

4) Launch the game. If everything is right, you should see a CMD prompt opening and the foreground window shrinking to 800x600. That's normal. The game will launch. THERE, you have to place the UserID (not the EA ID, the User ID that usually is an email address) and then the 8 character password. It should launch then login (like what happened to me). There's not much people connected, so it should work pretty smoothly.

5) Register a "commander" name and then continue with the main menu.
--------------------

column9: I've never seen a game in my entire life that requires logging in twice to play.

column8:
Hated everything about it. Such a mood killer cause I was literally hype when The Scrins had such a big role in the Tiberium Saga and they had a really big introduction back in Tiberium Wars.

I was expecting a lot more when I saw the menu, saw the screenshots of this game from the page and thought that "hell yeah! the walkers are back!" But no! The Walkers are literally your base that's super useless, they added a level up thing, and worst of all........ A POPULATION LIMIT! BRO THIS AIN'T BATTLE REALMS FOR F**K SAKE!

If EA, and that is a BIG IF, ever decided to revive the franchise, I just wish that they would focus on a lot more in the story cause the whole cutscenes literally made me to roleplay the game like I was in it, hoping to become that one Commander to change everything. Games today shouldn't even be about graphics, gameplay or pro scenes, sometimes we all just want to enjoy it and Command and Conquer delivered that for me.

column9:
1. I've got a bug; I can't build any buildings.

2. You need an active internet connection... to play it OFFLINE.

3. Online functionality is no longer possible; the servers have been shut down. The game doesn't support LAN, so VPNs like Radmin/Hamachi won't work either.

4. "Irony on"â€”awesome Nod cutscenes! I've always wanted to see Mr. Proper Kane with a white background.

The GOOD thing about the game: Finally, Chrono Legionnaires can do something useful.

column8: In typical EA fashion, they have taken a groundbreaking series with memorable mechanics and then turned out this monstrosity that they have the audacity to call a game. Play any other C&C game in the series, do not start with this one because it will leave a bad taste in your mouth. Even better, just skip this title entirely as it shouldn't even be considered cannon.

column9:
This game is practically deserted, why doesn't EA just shut down the servers and make it purely single-player? Even now, you still need to log in to your EA account twice to get in.

The battle mode was drastically changed to the point of being called "Turtle Arena." Of course, everyone knows this game was a spin-off turned official, I don't know what got into EA executives. I think EA squeezed a lot out of the CC series, both browser and mobile games, why did they have to turn this thing into an official title? This resulted in the single-player mode being rushed and having a bizarre upgrade mechanism. There's nothing new to do after the endgame, classic EA game lifecycle.

Unfortunately, during the wave of simplified RTS or RTS-to-MOBA games at the time, this game was one of the less haphazard and more playable ones. The three base types separated infantry/buildings, armor/scavenging, and air/command skills; population limits simplified operations; unit construction only required time for easy transitions; the mechanics of victory points and research points (Taijin) made 5v5 quite fun when it first came out, but without any follow-up, it naturally flopped. It's worth mentioning that the units in this game are the most nostalgic in the series; they've thrown in everything imaginableâ€”the hover missiles from Mass Effect 2, the Colossus, and the burrowing machines from Nod. After all, spin-offs don't need to worry about lore. If it were developed as a standalone long-term project, it might have even crammed the entire Critical Ops series into it, but EA's long-term strategy... haha.

If the plot is bad, they can leave it blank. The drastic changes to the lore can't be excused by rushing; it was intentional. Kane, from the Tyrant, rode the pitiful Siggin who couldn't return home, waited thousands of years, and finally succeeded in returning. The opening effect of the Siggin Tower somehow became the destruction of all Tiberium on Earth to restore the ecosystem? While the Siggin lore is quite clichÃ©, what does this make the Siggin? A cosmic environmental ambassador? Thus, Kane's ascension becomes a win-win situation. And the most important of the ten thousand questions arising from this is: how did this ghost story of three Tiberium Wars and the use of the Joker for participation even pass censorship and actually get made into a film? Is this their epic ending? Epic like Mass Effect 3, huh? Suddenly, I'm starting to worry about Dragon Age 4.

Let the memories remain in CC3.

column8:
[h1] A Bold New Direction [/h1]
[h2] Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (5/5) [/h2]



As a long-time fan of the Command & Conquer series, I approached Tiberian Twilight with a bit of trepidation, given the mixed reviews it received upon release. However, I was pleasantly surprised by what the game offers and found it to be a unique and engaging experience that deserves a positive nod.

Innovative Gameplay:
One of the most striking aspects of Tiberian Twilight is its shift away from the traditional base-building mechanics that defined earlier titles in the series. Instead, the game opts for a more dynamic, mobile approach to gameplay through the use of â€˜Battlefield Commandersâ€™ and a focus on unit-based strategies. This fresh take encourages players to adapt to the rapidly changing battlefield and think on their feet, which keeps the experience exhilarating and fast-paced.

Compelling Storyline:
The narrative in Tiberian Twilight ties up many loose threads from the Tiberium saga, providing closure to long-standing story arcs involving familiar characters. The voice acting and cutscenes are engaging and well-produced, immersing you in the conflict between GDI and Nod. Itâ€™s thrilling to see how the game integrates its lore into the gameplay, making decisions matter in the context of the overarching narrative.

Rich Multiplayer Experience:
The multiplayer component is another standout feature. With comprehensive co-op missions and competitive modes, the game brings a sense of community and competition that can be incredibly rewarding. Forming alliances and strategizing with friends adds layers to the gameplay, making it an ideal choice for those who enjoy team-based tactics.

Visuals and Sound:
On a technical note, Tiberian Twilight boasts impressive visuals for its time. The environments are detailed, and the unit designs are striking, reflecting the seriesâ€™ signature aesthetic. Coupled with a robust soundtrack and sound effects, the game creates an immersive atmosphere that draws players into the conflict.

While Tiberian Twilight may depart from the classic C&C formula, it introduces innovative mechanics and a rich narrative that have left a lasting impression on me. If youâ€™re open to new gameplay styles and appreciate a compelling story within the C&C universe, this title is worth diving into. It may not be perfect, but it certainly stands out as a worthy installment in the legendary franchise.



[b] -Level Up For the Epic Conclusion of the Tiberium Saga. [/b]

column8:
Managed to get ingame after reducing password character count to slightly below 16 and only after copying my password, quickly pasting it in for insistent login. The EA Launcher's server refuses to acknowledge the new password limits (imo should have been easy to solve but I guess someone doesn't want to pay their programmers). The moment you can input an ingame username, your game will then be recognized by the EA server and launch without aforementioned headache.

The artwork is great all-over, but the story quickly degenerates to a sudden and unsatisfying open closure. 

Gameplay is similar to DOW 3; base building is limited in favor of mobile deployment. Your hero unit is your transformer HQ (one of three niches). You have a unit cap with no worries about resources or gathering. Units have relatively similar response patterns when it comes to pathing to previous games, all while divided into rigid tiers. They can be upgraded and provide different responses, but are severely limited by a rock/paper/scissors system.

I would not recommend for a full playthrough. The entire Tiberium-based technology isn't used as an axis for developing either the artwork or the mech-technology seen in the artwork above. It's just mech and tank units for days. Fun for a while, but the initial limitations and hiccups make for a poor desire to return to play again.

Menus are as primitive as they could be for 2010. If not for the EA launcher, you could have easily hosted LAN parties with third party software. Very unfortunate choice for them to make.

RIP C&C.

column9: This installment might have been acceptable as a multiplayer sub-module of CC3. However, its appearance as the final chapter of the main series is a grave mistake. The Tiberium story was originally very long and extensive, but it ended extremely hastily with this game. This, coupled with the already weakened state of the RTS genre, essentially sealed the fate of the entire Tiberium series with such a low-quality title. Therefore, the failure of this game has far-reaching and detrimental effects. DC Comics can reboot, and now, nearly 20 years later, hopefully Tiberium 4 can also be rebooted, removing the single-player story from this game before releasing a sequel.

Das fulminante Ende einer der beliebtesten Echtzeit-Strategie-Reihen mit atemberaubender Grafik und dem befriedigenden Ende der Geschichte um GDI, der Bruderschaft von Nod und deren AnfÃ¼hrer Kain... ist C&C4 leider nicht geworden.

Stattdessen bekommt man ein Spiel das stÃ¤ndig abstÃ¼rzt oder mit steigender Anzahl von Objekten auf dem Spielfeld (nicht im Bild!) immer langsamer wird, bis es vÃ¶llig unspielbar wird - auf einem System mit Ryzen 5800 X3D, Radeon RX 6900XT und 16GB RAM wohlgemerkt. Schon lange vorher fangen alle Texturen an zu flackern oder komplett zu verschwinden. Dann ist ein Neustart des letzten Savegames angesagt,

Das sich auch das Spielprinzip geÃ¤ndert hat, sollte sich schon herumgesprochen haben. Es gibt keinen Basisbau mehr und auch kein sammeln von Ressourcen. Das hÃ¤tte dennoch SpaÃŸ machen kÃ¶nnen, wenn alles andere gepasst hÃ¤tte.

Inhaltlich bietet C&C4 eine hauchdÃ¼nne Story mit Ã¼berwiegend einer einzigen Cut-Scene-Kulisse fÃ¼r GDI und NOD. Von den coolen Zwischensequenzen der VorgÃ¤ngerspiele ist nichts mehr Ã¼brig. Man hat nicht mehr das GefÃ¼hl in einen globalen Konflikt um das Ãœberleben der Menschheit involviert zu sein. Selbst die einzelnen Maps wirken wie ein beengter Sandkasten in dem man mit einigen wenigen Einheiten herumspielt.

Auch der Sound ist kaputt. Bei mir waren keine KampfgerÃ¤usche zu hÃ¶ren. Keine SchÃ¼sse, keine Explosionen, nur Musik. Die Nod-Kampagne hat ein wenig mehr Charakter durch die atmosphÃ¤rischere Musik, aber das kann auch nichts mehr retten.

Aktuell kann man das Spiel nicht mehr kaufen, sollte sich das aber wieder Ã¤ndern: Es ist absolut rausgeschmissenes Geld!
column9:
The grand finale of one of the most popular real-time strategy series, with its breathtaking graphics and satisfying conclusion to the story of GDI, the Brotherhood of Nod, and their leader Cain... is sadly not what Command & Conquer 4 (C&C4) promises.

Instead, you get a game that constantly crashes or slows down as the number of objects on the battlefield (not shown in the screenshot!) increases, until it becomes completely unplayableâ€”and this is on a system with a Ryzen 5800 X3D, Radeon RX 6900XT, and 16GB of RAM, mind you. Long before that point, all the textures start flickering or disappearing completely. Then, restarting the last save game is the only option.

It should be common knowledge by now that the gameplay has also changed. There's no more base building or resource gathering. That could have been fun, though, if everything else had been right.

In terms of content, C&C4 offers a wafer-thin story consisting mostly of a single cutscene setting for GDI and Nod. The cool cutscenes of the previous games are completely gone. You no longer feel involved in a global conflict for the survival of humanity. Even the individual maps feel like cramped sandboxes where you just mess around with a few units.

The sound is also broken. I couldn't hear any combat sounds. No gunfire, no explosions, just music. The Nod campaign has a little more character thanks to its more atmospheric music, but that can't salvage the game.

Currently, the game is no longer available for purchase, but if that changes: it's an absolute waste of money!

column8:
Its good and BAD  , ill explain my reasons why. ( I refunded the entire bundle because i was so upset at the time. Refunds are always time conditional ). 

Because you cant play your own game offline. What if your internet goes out or you cant afford to keep paying ISP and want to save some money? You wont even have access to your own game. And its insane because its old !

It has SOLO MODES....

You cant even see options for Resolution monitor settings until you have a EA account !

1st try to use your Current active EA
account. 

Because you have to use the same Email and Password anyway. So 
Don't make a new account or password if you have a EA client account already. 

Once in, you can bring all the graphics up to acceptable levels.
There is good graphic details to the game models once you up the resolution to max. 
Then the graphics appear to be quality.

In the lobby you will find only a handful of player names:
And no one will respond to you. Probably died at their computer :(

Your best bet is organize a game on DISCORD find some C&C servers there. Discord  desktop app web app or cell phone your preference. And first google some Tiberian Twilight discord servers you can find people and organizing matches with perhaps. 

I suggest Don't buy this game. Not even for the D L C Unless you always have internet access.  
If for the near future always have Internet, then by all means get it if you want.

PS TheShepherdsChapelChannel Youtube.

The Shepherds Chapel Channel youtube official with Arnold Murray and Dennis Murray .

I've only played the tutorial and haven't seen any buildings other than the base vehicle yet...

Always online requirement and a double login check ruin the game before you even start it. If I hadn't gotten the game in a bundle for so little money, I would have immediately demanded a refund. I would even go so far as to assume that EA Games is deliberately fraud its players in order to squeeze even more money out of them.

And another thing, what genius came up with the brilliant idea of â€‹â€‹introducing a character cap on the password for the second login and thus forcing its players to create a second account? I certainly won't change my secure password for my account just to play this disgrace for the Command and Conquer franchise.

I wish I could say something about the gameplay, but it never even got that far. However, judging by the other reviews and comments in the forums, the gameplay itself was or is probably not the real thing either.

column8:
The game is a huge disappointment for me. An ugly ending to an iconic game series. Maybe I just had high expectations, but after C&C 3, this game can be a big disappointment for true fans.

In terms of gameplay, it broke with the excellent mechanics of the previous 3 parts. It reminds me more of a mobile game. Can't be built, infinite resources, units are unknowable. For the biggest fans, it's a very crappy gameplay at first, which is very difficult to get used to, but that doesn't make it any better.

Campaign history after C&C 3 is very poor. The actors in the walkthrough videos are very weak. Costumes have also changed, they have become more modern, but they are less suitable for this post-apocalyptic future.

I only played through the campaign. On easy difficulty to get over it as quickly as possible. One of the positives of the game is that the campaign is short, even this is a lot from this game â˜¹ The entire storytelling was weak, as was the ending.

The fans didn't deserve this...
column9:
The game is a huge disappointment for me. An ugly ending to an iconic game series. Maybe I just had high expectations, but after C&C 3, this game can be a big disappointment for true fans.

In terms of gameplay, it broke with the excellent mechanics of the previous 3 parts. It reminds me more of a mobile game. Can't be built, infinite resources, units are unknowable. For the biggest fans, it's a very crappy gameplay at first, which is very difficult to get used to, but that doesn't make it any better.

Campaign history after C&C 3 is very poor. The actors in the walkthrough videos are very weak. Costumes have also changed, they have become more modern, but they are less suitable for this post-apocalyptic future.

I only played through the campaign. On easy difficulty to get over it as quickly as possible. One of the positives of the game is that the campaign is short, even this is a lot from this game â˜¹ The entire storytelling was weak, as was the ending.

The fans didn't deserve this...

column9: It's absolutely terrible. Duplicate accounts log in, and even with the correct password, it keeps saying the password is wrong. Disconnecting mid-game resets all experience gained, making the whole game a waste. The population cap is pitifully low, and high-level units easily take up 10 population slots. While you can use the Support Base skill later to free engineers to occupy high-level ground unit wreckage and limit the population cap, it's practically uselessâ€”not even as good as one High Archon unit. The story is a mess. If you really want to play, I'd recommend CNC3 or CNC3: Kenny. You ask why I've played CNC4 for almost 50 hours? I can only tell you I'm a master at finding garbage.

I curse your horse, EA! What RTS game requires a constant internet connection? Even if it's online, the servers are worse than my grandma's simmered pig's trotters. And then there's the double login! Playing single-player campaigns is a nightmare, constantly disconnecting and losing progress.

You're on Steam now, all you care about is making money, completely ignoring the gaming experience modern games should have, right? No optimizations or improvements whatsoever? You don't treat players like human beings, but like cash cows and money-making tools, right?

And you're forcing bundled sales! If it weren't for Red Alert 2, I'd rather pay a dog than buy this garbage.

Oh, you damn EA, you rotten piece of trash! You're just like Activision Blizzard, those two are like the Crouching Dragon and the Young Phoenix, all they have are top-tier IPs and they don't do anything useful. You're arguably the two worst game companies in the world. Tencent and NetEase are a million times better than you! Ubisoft's canned games are a billion times more fun than this pure industrial garbage!

Buying this piece of crap from you will only pollute my inventory and my computer!

column8:
This was loathed on release and where some games actually redeem themselves with time and effort or just don't feel as controversial in retrospective, this one still sucks, to this day.

For starters, to start *enjoying* this, you need to login with your Origin or whatever EA has to this day, twice, first in launcher, then ingame. Next up, you'll be met with music and cinematics whose tone doesn't match previous CnC games at all but does match the EA's executives at the time ideas of what people would like, the faction conflict of GDI and Nod is being diluted by personal drama of main character who gets to loose a wife that previously showed up for ten seconds but she's a woman saying a nice thing in your face so I guess gamers will forever remember her, and then troopers you serve with get pretty emotional too except the actors aren't the best at it so it comes off goofy and pathosy, and the forst first person perspective with neural network UIs is just over the top with it's flashyness. The art direction in particular seems very influenced by at that time EA's most successful Mass Effect series, you can see it in UI in particular. Music is also way more orchestral and pompastic than anything ever delivered by Frank Klepacki.

Now, the gameplay, it gets a lot of hate. I must say, but as a team-based, online RTS with focus on dynamic shift of frontlines and no preset bases it's kinda sound, conceptually, plus three distinct types of "crawlers" the mobile bases in a single unit, with one being able to push trough with best armored unit, another getting to deploy defenses and infantry that can garrison structures, and yet third getting mostly aerial units and special abilities. It feels kinda like a sci-fi take on World in Conflict, more gamey, but with defined player roles and sides constantly harassing and pressuring each-other. Problem is, the online scene never lasted with how badly this game was received, there's this absolutely insulting grinfingg mechanic where you need to complete missions, skirmishes or online battles to unlock new units, not as some alternative loadouts but as part of core progress, demanding many more games to be played than just going trough a campaign, and all unified for both online and single play, and finally, this gameplay just doesn't translate to as very enjoyable experience in singleplayer, you get to have a small, very modest array of like 8 to 16 combat units at a time, there's some situational additions like husks of wrecked heavy units like in CnC4 to capture if you can afford engineers for it, but ultimately you're just pumping samey units and treating it all like some micro-intensive small squad breaktrough thing even though your units don't have any micro-intensive abilities or benefit from taking cover or something, plus unless necessity dictates you need to defend a single point or need to cover impassable terran with aerial units, you'll be playing all missions with Offensive crawler, so you won't use the free occupyable structures the game has, nor will you be using special ability most of time - and since you'll often deal with more numerous enemy forces that replenish as fast as you, it usually all boils down to building the exact units that counter enemy's forces, collecting veterancy upgrades dropped by enemies, and keep pumping reinforcements while hoping you can hold up. Even repairs don't feel worth it when performed by your easy to destroy engineers, takes too long, so you're better off ordering new units that microing back for repairs, and let me tell you clicking one or two unit buttons endless is a downgrade for CC, going way back to tank spam days.

And going back to presentation, I must say levels look pretty nice, the supermassive industrial construction sites and futuristic green cities make for nice arenas, but the structures and units you get? They range from way more toyetic takes on something you've seen in CnC3 or even earlier games, to genuinely embarrassing, goofy designs. The developers had to even replace the pre-release Nod engineer because it looked like a goofy cartoon worm with a jetpack - and yet, many other designs in this one could have used similar reworks back in the day. And the story? Yeah, Command and Conquer cinematics always felt cheap and hard to take seriously but this one really feels like a new low with team just filming "citizen interviews" with dev team members on streets of LA, blatantly modern day LA without a single postprocessed-in thing all while ingame cities look radically different from modern urban environments. Oh and the very last cinematic is just a white void.

People say this one killed the CnC series and harmed the RTS as a genre for years. I agree. I don't think it's worth your time, if you grabbed the CnC collection you should have a whole load of great games, don't hesitate to pass on this one even if you're a true penny pincher.

column8:
I only bought this as part of a pack for the Command & Conquer series.

C&C has some of the most iconic RTS titles of all time. This, sadly, is not one of them.

C&C 4 took everything great about the series and just sort of tossed it aside and went in a completely different direction. Instead of building a traditional base, you have this strange mobile command vehicle, where you recruit all your units and do everything. It's sort of like an all-in-one base. And BOY is it not fun at all. A big part of RTS games is building a base and managing your resources, but this game is like "nah, we don't need that."

Furthermore, there's also no resource gathering. You just gradually earn points that allow you to recruit more units. The unit limit, by the way, is incredibly low. This game seems to want you to micromanage just a few units, which I don't personally find nearly as fun. This also means, that there's no "worker" or "harvester" unit, and there's no way to attack your opponent's economy, other than gradually taking control of the map to earn your points faster.

If this had been a standalone game, people might have been mildly interested. But calling this abomination a "Command & Conquer" game was just a giant slap in the face to fans. You want to play Street Fighter with no punching? How about Super Mario Brothers with no jumping? That's what this game feels like to people who love the series. 

There's honestly no point in picking up this game, not even to laugh at how bad it is. The whole thing is just so dull that it fails to leave any impression on you other than wanting to play a better game.

Go play an actual RTS and don't waste your time on this schlock.

This also means, that there's no "worker" or "harvester" unit, and there's no way to attack your opponent's economy, other than gradually taking control of the map to earn your points faster.

If this had been a standalone game, people might have been mildly interested. But calling this abomination a "Command & Conquer" game was just a giant slap in the face to fans. You want to play Street Fighter with no punching? How about Super Mario Brothers with no jumping? That's what this game feels like to people who love the series. 

There's honestly no point in picking up this game, not even to laugh at how bad it is. The whole thing is just so dull that it fails to leave any impression on you other than wanting to play a better game.

Go play an actual RTS and don't waste your time on this schlock.

column8:
Never played it.  Never will.
Trying to get this game to run makes running C&C 3 look and feel like a cakewalk!

You can't play this game without an EA Account and to make matters worse, it throws out the same damn "General System Error" regardless of what you do to fix it (whether you log in and play by the rules or try to sneak past the "Bouncer").

From what I have seen of others playing this and uploading videos to YouTube...

Here's my limited impression of Tiberian Twilight: (In Short) Forgettable and not worth remastering, way too easy to retcon the whole damn thing...
(2 Cents) Shame, to see waste of the A-Grade performances from the story content that was ACTUALLY good and worth caring about.  If you never played this one, you can easily let the Tiberian Saga ride off into the sunset with C&C Tiberium Wars and Kane's Wrath.  C&C 4 and the mobile games are evidence the Command & Conquer franchise means absolutely nothing to Electronic Arts beyond another golden goose the C-Suite can take turns "Riding" (like the village bicycle that it is) until it inevitably croaks.

If you're buying the C&C Ultimate Collection - Don't let this game become a blemish on an epic purchase...  Save the HDD/SDD space and click "Hide".
Otherwise, if you're thinking about about buying this lemon as a standalone purchase (assuming you can)...  DON'T!

If EA EVER DO green light a redux of the Tiberian Saga, Twilight is so unforgettably bad few are going to miss it if it's retconned for something better.

column9: For those who haven't bought it, note that buying this game is essentially useless; you can't play it anyway. Let me explain why. This game requires two logins after starting. The first login uses your EA account, and you'll need to log in multiple times to succeed. Okay, after completing the first login step, you'll enter the game. However, the game will force you to log in again. Here's the problem: you absolutely cannot log in again. Why? Because the servers are closed. Therefore, you can't log in. If you can't log in, you can't start the game. Note that this is a single-player game; you need to log in twice to start, and the second login won't even let you in! Hahaha. Happy? Surprised? So why did you spend your money?

column8: Nonostante le recensioni pesantemente negative su questo gioco, ho deciso di acquistarlo comunque e mi sono reso conto che non Ã¨ pessimo come (quasi) tutti scrivono. SÃ¬, ammetto che anche io avrei preferito che questo capitolo avesse avuto il classico gameplay RTS come i precedenti Tiberium Wars e Kane's Wrath, ma complessivamente mi piace. Il gioco Ã¨ molto incentrato sulla cooperazione e si basa su un concetto di 'azione/controllo' in cui si sceglie il proprio ruolo sul campo di battaglia (attacco, difesa o supporto). Un concetto che probabilmente, nel 2010, era ancora nuovo e poco concepito. Il Tiberium Ã¨ sempre presente, anche se qui non Ã¨ la risorsa usata per costruire le unitÃ , ma serve per acquistare i relativi potenziamenti. Personalmente, lo consiglio.
column9: Despite the overwhelmingly negative reviews for this game, I decided to buy it anyway and realized it's not as bad as (almost) everyone says. Yes, I admit that I too would have preferred this installment to have had the classic RTS gameplay like the previous titles, Tiberium Wars and Kane's Wrath, but overall I like it. The game is heavily focused on cooperation and is based on an action/control concept where you choose your role on the battlefield (offense, defense, or support). A concept that was probably still new and poorly conceived in 2010. Tiberium is always present, even though here it isn't the resource used to build units, but is used to purchase their upgrades. Personally, I recommend it.
