column9:
Since "Dawn" in 1995, the Command & Conquer series has entered its final "twilight."

It's a pity there's no "recommended" or "not recommended" option; the game isn't particularly bad, but it was unfortunately managed to remain in a state of near-death.

Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight can be considered a bold and innovative revolution for the series. It broke through traditional RTS gameplay and shattered the previous CNC game mode. However, change inevitably comes with pain and skepticism, especially bearing the heavy yet glorious name of "Command & Conquer."

ã€The Pros and Cons of the "Battle of the Turtle"ã€‘ The huge changes lie here.

The satisfaction of expanding base buildings like in previous installments is gone; the overwhelming thrill of massing troops in equal time is gone; and the excitement of building super units and weapons is goneâ€¦ Instead, there are three different mobile MCVs with varying functions; a shared limit on unit population for both sides; and upgrade resources that spawn at fixed times on the mapâ€¦ Based on these changes, the gameplay has also undergone a significant transformation. This game places greater emphasis on the functions and mobility of different MCVs. Players must also decide how to allocate unit production and combat combinations at different times within the constraints of population resources. Furthermore, they must utilize their existing forces to seize upgrade resources or achieve mission objectives.

Therefore, this game focuses more on unit and function combinations and resource allocation, significantly enhancing its online gaming aspect and promoting player cooperation and competition. Especially in team battles, different players choosing different MCVs will have different roles and combinations, resulting in a qualitative leap in gameplay.

However, this change also brings several disadvantages. Firstly, old-school CNC players may not appreciate it. The content is too simplified, and the gameplay differences may not be immediately adaptable or comfortable. Moreover, the map design has become more rigid, almost entirely consisting of competitive maps, greatly reducing the randomness of initial positioning and making it overly esports-oriented. One of the biggest criticisms is the poor population limit. While it somewhat curbs the over-concentration of troops, it also reduces the diversity of unit combinations and lowers the margin for error during tactical experimentation.

In short, for players who genuinely can't find friends or can't quickly adapt to the new mode, these changes are a failure.

ã€Old Bowl, New Riceã€‘ The number "4" can be seen as a legitimate continuation of the main series, but the development team didn't use a new engine. Instead, they used the old CNC3 engine to create CNC4. Therefore, both the interface and in-game controls feel stagnant, even making players feel like it's a large-scale official mod made from old components. It even carried a hint of being rushed and cost-cutting.

ã€A Bland but Necessary Storyã€‘ As the final chapter, the story content is adequate, its biggest flaw being its brevity and rushed pace. However, given the quality of CNC3 and Kane's Wrath, this final chapter's achievement is quite remarkable. The acting seemed only solid on Kane and his wife; the other actors' performances were somewhat awkward, and casting a Black woman as the GDI Commander felt a bit politically charged and ultimately quite jarring. While the set design was simple, the actors' on-screen presence was quite good, somewhat compensating for this.

The story remains the conflict between GDI and NOD, but with global environmental degradation, people are forced to make choices between different ideologies. The protagonist, the "Commander," is a key figure in this struggle. He rescued his GDI superior and joined the uprising to thwart the enemy's ambitions; he also helped NOD eliminate the traitorous double Kane, enabling his ascension. Finally, the believers went to a new world, and Earth ended its cycle of war.

If this game truly marks the end of a 15-year journey, it's Kane's meaningful words to the player when the ascension portal opens:

"Thank you."

To avoid completely condemning the game, I can only say: Fun, but not very replayable.

column8: Do not purchase.  I can't say this is a scam, as that implies intent, but at the very least this is incompetence.  This isn't an issue affecting just a thin slice of the user base.  I've followed the posted suggestions on getting into the game and none of them worked.  I have an EA account.  I shortened my password to the minimum length and requirements.   They tell me to look for a CD key, but there is no "View CD Key" option for me.  Just criminally incompetent.  If you purchase this, do not expect to be able to run it.  Hopefully, if purchased in a bundle, you're getting enough value from the other items in the bundle

column8:
DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME, If you are a C&C fan, this will literally ruin the franchise for you. and if you must, just play CnC3, the last REAL CnC game.

I don't know what this is, but I do know that it is NOT a Command & Conquer game, but rather some random competitive RTS wannabe with a Command & Conquer skin on it. This game is an abomination to the name. EA clearly had plans for some competitive RTS, and not only was it absolutely CRAP, but they tarnished the name of a beloved franchise by trying to capitalised on an established name. EA should be absolutely ashamed of what they did here.

For context, I bought this game on initial release back in 2010. And quite frankly, after I played it, I would have happily have paid EA not to make it. They should have made one of the other two CnC games they started but then canned.

column9: The game is actually pretty good. The reason for so many negative reviews is due to issues with the launcher. Adding Steam requires logging in three times to get in, and there's also the account registration problem â€“ specifically, you need an Origin account. If you don't have one, you have to register. Just create a text document on your desktop, enter your password, and then copy and paste it using CTRL+C~V. It's not that complicated. I don't know what they were thinking, requiring so many login attempts. But the game itself is still fun.

column8:
Leider ist es Unspielbar, man muss sich 2 mal mit seinem EA Konto anmelden. Beim 1. Anmelden kommt sehr oft
Genereller System Fehler, dieses kann einige zeit und etlich Passworteingaben dauern. Hat man das 1. Login gemeistert,
kommt das 2. Login an welchem man aber zu 100% scheitert, da Falscher Benutzername, Subkontoname oder Passwort.
Also er die Collection kauft sollte Wissen dieser Teil kann nicht gespielt werden!
column9:
Unfortunately, it's unplayable; you have to log in twice with your EA account. The first login very often results in a "General System Error," which can take some time and require numerous password attempts. Even after successfully completing the first login, the second login attempt fails 100% of the time due to an incorrect username, sub-account name, or password.

So, anyone buying the collection should be aware that this part is unplayable!

column8:

So even if you wanted to play it, what a shocker, you can't. Because to noone's surprise, EA is still trash.

column8:
The reviews are deserved.
At the start you'll be level 1, you will have access to 5 units per team. It takes hundreds of matches to get max level to unlock all units. Your enemies already have full access to all units, including AI and opposing players. 
They tried to turn a beloved RTS into a MOBA and absolutely ruined a franchise and probably started the downfall of the RTS genre.
Never in my 10+ years of being on Steam have had such a negative opinion of a product.
This is an absolute sh!t show.
I hope everyone who green lit this mess no longer works in the industry.

column9:
Update: I found a tip online about deleting/renaming a file in the Windows folder â€“ it worked, and the game reaches the main menu. But it can still disconnect from the server at any time. Even in single-player. And that's very bad for an always-online game.

Basically, it's still crap on all counts.

***
I bought the game on release, but after playing for five minutes, I realized it was crap. Many years later, I finally decided to find out how exactly C&C "ended," but it's been practically impossible for years because the game runs on EA servers, and they've supposedly been down for years. Someone on the forums claims to have gotten into the game (not through the first login before the game, but through a second one â€“ in-game after the intro cutscene â€“ lol, yes, you have to log in twice), but that sounds like a story like, "In my version of GTA, you can go into every house, but I won't give it to you â€“ my dad won't let you."

This problem is a long-standing one; it was in Origin, and now it's back on Steam. There's some online hype about an "offline server," but it didn't work for me on Origin, and I don't even want to try it here. I just have one question.

How does Valve even allow outright scammers to sell a game that's impossible to launch?

column9: It's 2024, and EA already requires you to log in with your account to play the game, but they also want a serial number! It's like stepping back into 2002 AD. You have to enter your EA account before entering the game, and then again after entering. Does that mean they don't recognize me after a few seconds? This is the first time I've seen a computer get Parkinson's. But the most bizarre thing is that they've made a single-player game constantly online, and now EA has shut down the servers. So, I paid for a title? Once again, I've become a victim of copyright infringement. No wonder they're the worst company in America!

column9:
The game is the definitive version of what remains of the series, offering more of the same with impossible possibilities, yet still incredible possibilities as every update deserves! The story follows Kane towards a more personal perspective with the choice of sides, and tries to show how the negative side can also be dignified, depending on which side one sees as bad, which means, regardless of that, being good!

But playing it still follows the series sequence from both sides as always, and leaves GDI a little simpler as technology has progressed since the 90s and NOD with its revolutionary factor more included in the syndicalist condition of the future!

I'm biased in saying my liking for the series remains consistent with all the criteria since the first version and everything that was lost with Dune, and what else was perhaps lost with Electronic Arts and Westwood, which even ceased to be so in this sense!

The graphics are very flexible and respectful in their art style, yet it's stagnant in some sequences and super difficult to configure!

The launcher is a pain, it keeps crashing and it seems like Electronic Arts is the one making the decisions! And the buttons don't work!

column8: PlÃ¶tzlich geht der ProduktschlÃ¼ssel nicht mehr, sowas ist einfach nur unprofessuinell. Irgendwann geht es dann Ã¼ber Steam, aber der Login Server scheint auf einem C-64 zu laufen. Manchmal geht es, manchmal nicht. Heute geht es wieder nicht. Aber dann muss man sich ein zweites mal einloggen und das klappt dann sicher nicht. Warum kann man denn nicht einfach den Anmeldeserver laufen lassen fÃ¼r ein wenig Spielspass? Wenn EA dafÃ¼r keine KapazitÃ¤ten hat, dann stellen wir gerne fÃ¼r dieses Spiel den AnmeldeServer zur VerfÃ¼gung in unserem kleinen DataCenter. Das kann ja nicht so schwer sein. column9: Suddenly the product key stops working; that's just unprofessional. Eventually it works via Steam, but the login server seems to be running on a C-64. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. Today it's not working again. But then you have to log in a second time, and that's bound to fail. Why can't they just leave the login server running for a bit of fun? If EA doesn't have the resources for that, we'd be happy to provide the login server for this game in our small data center. It can't be that difficult. EA is welcome to contact us at borghesi-datalink.ch.

column8:
I wish I could get a refund.  

This game is not worth any amount of time other than to copy some of the unit models for porting back to Kane's Wrath or C&C:3.  It is only fortunate that Westwood studios' name will not be tarnished by this typical EA dumpster fire of a product.

Reasons it sucks:
>Balancing is off - the game feels like an MMORPG where you spend days to kill one unit.
>Mechanics are wrong - the game was built upon the resource collection mechanic and they decided to go away from the format that the customers required
>Graphics are thoroughly MID
>The FMV lacks the creative and dramatic spark of the prior products
>EA is a cancer on the gaming community - a malignant tumor that must be purified with flame.  They can't even Copypasta correctly

TLDR: EA is cancer

column9:
In short, this isn't C&C (Command & Conquer), it's a slap in the face to the entire fandom of the series.

For those who simply want to learn Kane's story and save their burning chair, rather than have to deal with the developers' filth, it's best to just watch the videos on YouTube.
Again, this isn't Command & Conquer, but a completely different game, stretching the series' legendary name and plot. It's strongly not recommended for purchase, unless you're looking for a freebie to add to your collection.

Now about the game:
Pros: just the name and Kane.

Cons: literally EVERYTHING:
1. There are no bases, instead there are crippled crawlers (a kind of walking workshop) of three types â€“ attack, defense, and support. Ultimately, you'll only use one (most likely the first â€“ attack). I used the Defense Crawler once, and that was when the story required me to build a bunker (I struggled with how to summon this crawler for a long time, but it turns out I had to destroy the previous one!!! There's no [Del] button in the interface! Or maybe I couldn't find it). The rest of the time, I'm attacking (ground vehicles) and, for variety, supporting (aircraft).

2. Resource collection - none, unless you count the boxes dropped by enemies (for unit upgrades) and Tiberium cores for technology development.
3. Unit construction - an absolute limit on quantity, not in units, but in fixed points (each unit has its own point value).
4. Unit design is something perverse, practically unlike previous series, with the exception of a few types (such as the Mammoth Tank, Mastodon, etc.). For example, the Scorpion tank actually looks like an insect with an obelisk on its tail. During the game, you'll only use a couple of different types and a repair tank.
5. Gameplay - forget why we came to S&S in the first place. The charm of building bases, collecting precious Tiberium, tracking those clumsy harvesters that require constant care, air raids, amassing forces, defending a base, attacking the enemy with a strike force, launching a nuclear missile, or launching satellite strikes is gone. None of that is there. You won't experience that feeling of a newly built obelisk rising in the heat of defending your base, accompanied by that enchanting zzzzzzzzzzz-pew sound. There will only be small, localized skirmishes across the map with a limited number of units.
6. Graphics - the engine is fine, but the design is terrible. The art, from the menus and maps to the units, is completely uninspired by S&S. The feeling of playing a different game will haunt you throughout the entire story.
7. The cutscenes are a C, in my opinion. The storyline between the Commander and his wife is tedious, and the storyline is woven inconsequentially and awkwardly.

8. The music is abysmal, not because it's bad, but because classical music and compositions with folk (Folk Carl!!!) motifs feel out of place in this game.

9. It constantly asks you to enter your EA password upon launch, and once isn't enough â€“ twice! Registration is also a quest, requiring you to go through the EA launcher and enter your Steam key first (there's a guide on how to do this, you can find it here).

If EA really wanted to end the series, they really succeeded, unlike the game itself.

column8:
Heres a list of features that EA did not include in the sequel to command and conquer 3
1. the ability to boot the game without logging into a now defunct online service
2. an ingame economy, no seriously there is no economy all you have is a supply cap and you just max and throw what you have at the enemy rinse and repeat, its so incredibly boring
3. The alien faction, remember that cool alien faction, welp they have all just vanished, and entire faction was removed from the game, the other two remaining factions have be re sculpted to become more symmetrical which if anything feels regressive of RTS's in general,

Just dont play this game, not that you could anymore if you wanted too they have shut down the servers.

column9:
[h1] C&C Remaster Review![/h1]

[i] The beautiful and awesome region block prevents me from reviewing the remaster.
[b]I highly recommend the remaster! [/b] [/i]

I started playing C&C with Red Alert on the first PS4 a hundred thousand years ago, and I've been in love with this RTS for ages. I've played C&C through and through.

Generals was a bit iffy at first, but after a couple of missions, I blew through the entire campaign in one breath, and then I really appreciated the expansion pack. The only exception was the ugly miscarriage with the number 4; I abandoned it after 10 hours of play and forgot about it. Tiberian Dawn, which I somehow missed, was a real gift from the developers. I played the GDI campaign on hard mode and had incredible fun. I'll be thrilled to play through the rest of the campaign with Nod, and then I'll definitely revel in Red Alert.

The remaster turned out quite well; it's still the same standard, but with a refreshed visual style that's definitely pleasing to the eye and a new soundtrack that's just as good as the classic game's. While I generally don't buy games over 500-600 rubles, the extra 1.5 rubles spent here are absolutely worth it!

column8:
Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight ist eine enttÃ¤uschende Fortsetzung einer einst groÃŸartigen Spielereihe. Als jemand, der als Kind Command & Conquer auf der PS1 geliebt hat und nun die Teile auf Steam nachholt, habe ich mich sehr auf dieses Spiel gefreut. Leider wurde meine Erwartungen nicht erfÃ¼llt.

Ein deutliches Problem in Command & Conquer 4 ist das offensichtliche EA-Prinzip, Spieleentwickler zu kaufen und dann Spiele in kurzen AbstÃ¤nden herauszubringen, bis die einst erfolgreiche Spielereihe letztendlich kaputt ist. Dies hat auch hier seine Spuren hinterlassen. Das Spiel fÃ¼hlt sich nicht mehr wie ein authentisches Command & Conquer an, sondern eher wie ein liebloses Produkt, das nur darauf aus ist, Geld zu generieren.

Die technische Umsetzung von Command & Conquer 4 lÃ¤sst zu wÃ¼nschen Ã¼brig. Die Grafik ist zwar solide fÃ¼r die Zeit, aber es gibt technische Probleme und Ungenauigkeiten, die das Spielerlebnis beeintrÃ¤chtigen und den SpaÃŸ nehmen. Man quÃ¤lt sich beinahe durch das Spiel.

Alles in allem kann ich Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight nur als enttÃ¤uschend bezeichnen. Es ist ein Beispiel dafÃ¼r, wie eine einst erfolgreiche Spielereihe durch das Einmischen von EA ruiniert werden kann. 

Keine Kaufempfehlung
column9:
Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight is a disappointing sequel to a once-great game series. As someone who loved Command & Conquer on the PS1 as a kid and is now catching up on the games on Steam, I was really looking forward to this one. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met.

A significant problem with Command & Conquer 4 is the obvious EA strategy of buying game developers and then releasing games in quick succession until the once-successful franchise is ultimately ruined. This has left its mark here as well. The game no longer feels like an authentic Command & Conquer title, but rather like a half-baked product solely focused on making money.

The technical execution of Command & Conquer 4 leaves much to be desired. While the graphics are decent for their time, there are technical issues and inaccuracies that detract from the gameplay and spoil the fun. Playing the game is almost a chore.

All in all, I can only describe Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight as disappointing. It's an example of how a once-successful game series can be ruined by EA's interference.

Not recommended.

column8:
Well, you can't buy this on Steam anyway so there is not much to say about it. One thing I want to say is that the story of the Tiberium saga is left incomplete. Kane's Wrath is the last  game of this saga. Almost everyone in the community agrees that this game never happened and the ending of Kane's Wrath is the canon ending. From what I understand EA's love for the E-sports market which caused some drastic changes in the game design as a whole and the terrible direction the story goes were the main reasons that this game had failed so miserably. A true franchise killer and a terrible "conclusion" to one of the most beloved franchises of RTS genre. They finally removed this unplayable mess of a game from the Steam Store. Don't pay money for it, don't pirate it, don't even play it.

*Don't mind the played time. I pirated it many years ago. Besides It didn't even let me play it because it could not connect to the server.

column8:
The Good:
- Still runs on moderns systems without issue
- FMV production quality is in line with other C&C games
- Designing the game around a mobile base system makes for some interesting gameplay
- Plenty of different units to play with

The Bad:
- Both the GDI and NOD campaigns are short and feel rushed; additional missions could have been used to flesh out each campaign. 
- The story itself is atrocious 
- The preorder bonus mission impossible to access outside of co-op
- Progression is a big grind; it's not possible to unlock all units in one playthrough.

The Ugly:
- 30fps cap
- EA account shenanigans 

Command and Conquer ends with a whimper, not a bang.

column8:
This game is different from the others C&C but it even plays well with the innovations created ... the bases instead of being one that serves for attacks, defenses and supports are 3 ... while you use one defense for example, you can't call another attack or maintenance ... there are times when we need the 3 to get the necessary weapons ...

Another problem is the need to use your password every time you enter the game... it becomes uncomfortable that the game doesn't memorize our password right from the start or doesn't even ask for a password because after all we entered through Stream and it should be enough as it is for C&C 3 or for red alert for example...

Conclusion ... it is possible to play without problems but the path to enter each time we want to continue our game is uncomfortable, in addition to not always being possible to save when we have to leave the game for our day to day ... so when we return we have to repeat it all over again ... in short .. it is inferior to the other C&C but playable so ... if you like this type of game ... I advise you to buy it

column9:
I want to express my opinion on this game. First off, I haven't played any games from this universe except this one, but I did follow the backstory of the characters, how they came to be, how they ended, and I also watched all the spinoffs from the main game, as well as the graphics and the gameplay itself.
I'll say this: I really like this part of the game, if only because the graphics are very cool for its age, and I also like the infantry and building models. The only thing that's disappointing is the limit on infantry and buildings (I don't know if there was a limit on infantry and buildings in the previous games, although I quickly figured out whether there was one, or not, but you could have created a lot of both). Another disappointment is that the story is too short, and frankly, the price tag is too high for this game because I want more story than graphics. This was my purely subjective opinion about the game, but now my advice to those who still want to buy it. I understand that it's not much and is unlikely to be needed, considering the game is almost dead, but still,
if you played the previous parts of this game, you probably won't like this one due to its short length and the small limit on infantry and building production. Still, if you decide to buy it, only at a discount, because it's really expensive.

column8:
long time fan of C&C... this... is not C&C... WTF... game play is good meaning everything works the way it should for the most part other then units getting stuck around legs and ramps...but to the real problems base building gone the face you have to destroy your CC just to make other units and you only have a limited amount of CC stupid and the animations... why is everything so big and bulky looking looks way too cartoonish to me and the fact that in order to destroy a unit you need to you its counter witch do not get me wrong in C&C 3 yes infantry would take forever to kill a take compared to rocked INF and a tank but in this game it just seems terrible so many times i had to destroy units and re build units to compensate and i even field a mission because i destroyed my own last CC by accident... in short game play was gross and so happy i waited this long to be disappointed in this game now i see why C&C died... story was lame too.
that is all.

column8: I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

column8: I beat both camps in 7.5hrs total, story is throw away and the actors are trying but you can't save a story this bad. Game play is not C&C, it's a mobile base that builds units based on control points you own and fight over. You stop caring about what units you have and just worry about your queue being full so that you are replacing what your loosing and death ball around the map until you win. Rinse repeat every map until you beat the game. You can really feel that this title was not supported and developed with the same standard as the previous ones.

column8:
To play this game (Campaign & Multiplayer):

1) Go to the Steam Library.
2) Find and click on C&C 4.
3) Click on game settings button and go to Manage -> CD Keys.
4) Open Origin, go to the Game Library.
5) Click on 'ADD A GAME'.
6) Click on 'Redeem Product Code...'
7) Enter your Steam CD Key here.
8) Check if it's added to your Origin Game Library.
9) If Origin find the game and wants to update even if it's from Steam, let it update.
10) Run C&C 4 on Steam.
11) Log in with your Origin Account.

Additional: You can add your other C&C games that have CD Key the same way to Origin.
column9:
To play this game (Campaign & Multiplayer):

1) Go to the Steam Library.
2) Find and click on C&C 4.
3) Click on game settings button and go to Manage -> CD Keys.
4) Open Origin, go to the Game Library.
5) Click on 'ADD A GAME'.
6) Click on 'Redeem Product Code...'
7) Enter your Steam CD Key here.
8) Check if it's added to your Origin Game Library.
9) If Origin find the game and wants to update even if it's from Steam, let it update.
10) Run C&C 4 on Steam.
11) Log in with your Origin Account.

Additional: You can add your other C&C games that have CD Key the same way to Origin.

column8:
[h1] Remember what was so enjoyable for the rest of the franchise games? 
Forget it, this plays entirely different.  [/h1]

The story is really short

The gameplay is subpar.

The new actors and actresses aren't always the greatest, but most are all right.

This game was made and EA stated something along the lines "Gamers don't know what they want, we have to tell them what they want"....    They were wrong and this game was wrong...  However, as a finale to the current C&C series. It's not terrible. There's definitely worse games. While this is a neutered rts, where you have to be mobile all the time. The concept lived on and was perfected.  
Look at Homeworld Deserts of Kharak for a better recipe to this type of playstyle. 

Still it's playable, get it on sale. 

OH did I mention you have to have an internet connection?!  CAUSE THAT's SUCH A GOOD IDEA... >.>

column8:
Ni plus, ni moins qu'une honte...

Je pensais vraiment que les critiques Ã©taient trop forte car il y avait une volontÃ© de faire trop dans les puriste derriÃ¨re.... et ben non vraiment.

Le seul point positif, c'est qu'il reste fidÃ¨le au lore du jeu sur les unitÃ©s (encore heureux !)

Le gameplay est juste... mauvais.... il est trÃ¨s mal Ã©quilibrer. Vue qu'il n'y a plus de rÃ©colte, par moment, la mission se rÃ©sume soit Ã  tout dÃ©foncer avec la petite compo de base que vous avez fait avec vos points car la rÃ©paration peut Ãªtre trÃ¨s forte avec juste 2 ou 3 rÃ©parateurs.... ou bien cela se rÃ©sume Ã  du spam d'unitÃ©s qui vont Ã  la boucherie car l'IA vous envoie Ã©normÃ©ment de troupe dessus.

Le jeu est trÃ¨s court comparer aux nombres de mission que l'on a habitude avec les autres C&C. au totalement 3 missions du GDI comme dÃ©but pour le tuto commun au deux factions et puis 7 missions pour chaque faction....

Bref une honte, ni plus ni moins. je ne l'ai terminer que pour voir la fin de la saga... et lÃ  encore, il est dÃ©cevant. La fin est vraiment torchÃ©... Mon dieu mais quel conclusion pourrie pour une saga aussi dantesque que celle ci.
column9:
Nothing more, nothing less than a disgrace...

I really thought the criticism was overblown because there was an attempt to be overly purist... but no, really.

The only positive point is that it remains faithful to the game's lore regarding the units (thankfully!).

The gameplay is just... bad... it's very poorly balanced. Since there's no more resource gathering, at times the mission boils down to either destroying everything with the small basic army composition you've built with your points because repairs can be very powerful with just two or three repairers... or it boils down to spamming units that are sent to the slaughter because the AI â€‹â€‹sends tons of troops at you.

The game is very short compared to the number of missions we're used to with other C&C games. A total of 3 GDI missions as a starting point for the common tutorial for both factions, and then 7 missions for each faction...

In short, a disgrace, plain and simple. I only finished it to see the end of the saga... and even then, it's disappointing. The ending is really rushed... My god, what a lousy conclusion to such an epic saga.

column8:
It's not command and conquer.

- no base building
- no resource gathering
- units unlock slowly till a point you don't even care what units you build as long as you run for control points
(capture the flag style)
- story is crap and over dramatized

- they took what is staple of the command conquer gameplay experience and turn it on it's head. Biggest fail to close the tiberium series.

column9:
[b]An excellent game[/b], demonstrating how not to do things.

Perhaps if this wonderful "fourth" part were not the "fourth" for the legendary C&C series, but the first for some new universe, MAYBE (but I'm not sure), it would be at least a little clearer why everything is so bad (the first pancake is always a flop, and all that).

The game is completely unsuitable for multiplayer, bot battles, or any kind of competition between players. It's more geared toward "Complete the story and forget you even played it," even though the story itself is disjointed and incomprehensible. Everything happens so fast: one moment we're here, the next we're gone, one moment everything's bad, the next it's ok, Kane is good, the next he's bad...

Not to mention the complete lack of explanation of what happened, why the Brotherhood got mad at Kane, why Kane suddenly decided to hand the Tacitus over to GDI, and how he even ended up collaborating with them. There's a huge plot hole from the end of Part 3 to the beginning of Part 4.
[hr][/hr]
Speaking of the GAMEPLAY itself. My favorite part of the series is C&C 3: KW, and I think everyone who played it and decided to try this game felt a terrible emptiness inside, namely:

* There are absolutely no screenshots, only GDI and Nod (compared to 9 factions (3 main + 2 subfactions for each) in KW);

* There's no base buildingâ€”just one crawler (like the MSC), and that's not really even a building. There are three types, which is a bit depressing. If you want to play with air power, there's a crawler for that, but you can't build decent ground forces. And basically, this division of roles into Tank, Support, and Damage Dealer kills any desire to consider this game a strategy game. Welcome to the RTS version of Team Fortress, gentlemen (or Overwatch, I'm writing this review in 2022, after all);

* The economy, which in multiplayer has always been the main goal, and the winner is essentially whoever builds their own better and ruins the enemy's? Noâ€”here's a Tiberium crystal that needs to be hauled to spawn to upgrade your crawler, make your troops stronger, and upgrade the ones you already have.

* Combat dynamics? Attempts to sneak up and do something? Yeah, no one's stopping me, but why? Capturing points depends on the troops inside the zone, not on whoever has a live turret at spawn.
And the point-capture mechanics themselves. Am I playing Battlefield or an RTS? My goal should be to destroy enemy forces, not capture and hold some obscure points, and I don't even really understand why. I wouldn't be against it at all if it were part of the gameplay, like "Hold these points and you'll have an advantage," i.e., if it were a component (like the Tiberium Spikes in the third game or the EMP Control Center) to achieve some larger goal, not the end of the battle itself.

* Different playstyles? Macro and Micro? No, never heard of them. You can be an infinitely skilled macro player, but what's the point if you have a unit limit? Spamming isn't an optionâ€”yes, it adds some "tactics" to the gameâ€”you can't just spam units and smash everything, which is definitely a plus. However, if we're talking about a slightly higher level of play than a complete noob, even spamming, without micromanagement and tactics, you won't win. So, we've "solved" a problem that didn't actually exist, but merely limited the player's freedom of action. To counter an enemy's unit, they have to literally send their troops to the dogs, allowing you to create new ones.
The counter-troop mechanics themselves are also extremely awkward and unclear. Everything used to be simple: there were infantry, vehicles, aircraft, and buildings. Here you have units for each of these types that are effective against them, and it was fairly obvious who was against whom (bullets - infantry, missiles - vehicles and aircraft, grenades/fire - buildings), and the lack of any restrictions allowed you to quickly respond to any enemy decision.

Now: light, medium, heavy armor, and you look at a unit and have no idea which is effective against it. I find it rather funny when a tank with two huge machine guns literally tickles enemy infantry because their armor isn't the type that bullets are effective against. Yes, you can get used to it and become picky, but it complicates and confuses what is best left as simple and intuitive as possible, so that in battle you can focus on more important tactical matters.

* Again, the lack of variety in the units themselves is terribly lacking. While in the old game, the 9 factions had a fairly decent selection of each unit type (although, of course, some might say they were underpowered compared to other strategy games, but I personally believe that "more" doesn't mean "better," especially for an RTSâ€”there were just enough). In this game, not only are we essentially getting redesigned models of the same units in terms of mechanics, but there's also little variety. And here, the lack of a third side in the conflict in the form of aliens is truly noticeable; battles become too repetitive, ESPECIALLY considering that you can't now fight, for example, Nod vs. Nod; every match is Nod vs. GDI, which completely destroys any hope of variety.

* The worst part is the leveling. While the older games lacked leveling and the unit locking mechanic was only present in the Campaign, designed solely to convey the storyline correctly and prevent you from crushing the first missions with Tier 3 troops, in this game, even for multiplayer and battles, you need to level up to unlock units. Simply put, if you want to play against other players, you first have to spend a lot of hours chasing bots to gain a rank. Incidentally, there's a separate rank for Nod and GDI, meaning you get a total of (likely a lot) x2 bot chasing. Moreover, once you reach a rank, these units become available to you in the campaign, which turns what were initially quite challenging missions into a breeze once you've reached the maximum level. I still don't understand why this mechanic was even introduced, as these ranks don't reflect your experience in this game at all. They only make your "start" more painful and time-consuming. While this extends the gameplay, it's clearly not enjoyable.

* Also, after launching this marvel again and literally jumping into a battle with bots, I realized how terrible the interface is. It's huge, taking up almost the entire screen (at a resolution of 1920x1080, mind you), with tons of buttons scattered all over the place, even though these buttons could have been made smaller, or even placed in hotkeys so they wouldn't take up my screen...

In short, I'd like to believe the developers will never remaster this "masterpiece," and if they do, they'll likely make it into a completely different game, truly worthy of being the fourth installment in this iconic series.

column8:
This game departs from the traditional C&C RTS you've grown to expect from the previous games.

1. Mobile bases. Literally just one structure per mode (Defense, Offense, and Support) instead of building your war factory, infantry building, power plants, etc. Just one vehicle that can switch between modes to build different things. Ugh. This was the worst part of the entire game imo, at least let me build a base.
2. No more harvesting minerals. You accumulate "resources" overtime.
3. Outfits in the cinematics are more basic than past games. E.g. soldiers wear basic army armor compared to Tiberian Sun where the NOD Light infantry in the cinematics wore armor that looked like how they should as their pixel self.

This game is not a great addition to the Command & Conquer franchise - and it should get retcon'd / made non-canon.

column8:
A bloody disgraceful successor to the Tiberium Wars series. This game makes me want to be successful just so I can contact Joe Kucan in the future about a possible reboot of this so the series can have the final game it deserves. Thanks to this piece of shit for a game, the Tiberian saga went out with a whimper instead of a bang. 

If you're truly a fan of the saga and want to find out how it all ends, I recommend you read the plotline on wikipedia instead of wasting your time and money trying to play this game. Seriously, after the beautifully crafted units of CNC3, the units and gameplay of this "video game" make me want to break my laptop. Prime example of EA trying to fix something that was the farthest thing from broken.

column8:
Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight' ~ 2/10

"Twilight? More like Twi-shite!"

---

I remember playing this game when it first came out. I first started playing games from the C&C franchise with Tiberium Wars, and from that day, bought every single one the day it came out. I decided to rebuy Twilight on Steam because I'd since lost the DVD and thought "maybes its not as bad as I remember". Wow, that was incorrect.

The game-play is shoddy, and a complete departure from previous C&C games (change isn't a bad thing, but EA made some pretty horrendous changes to the format). The soundtrack is completely unmemorable, and completely lacking in any memorable tracks! Its just got no spirit.

Now, let's talk about a stable of the C&C franchise; the hammy F.M.V. cut-scenes. Well they are certainly hammy, but you can really tell that literally nobody is enjoying the scripts they've been handed - in fact, I'm shocked Joe Kucan didn't walk off set demanding a better set of lines... which leads me onto a bigger issue. The story!

The story has got to be the most boring, lazy waste of space in the history of the franchise, and that's really saying something, since Generals and Zero Hour were just a generic war thriller. What I will say, is that at least those two games had functional stories; 'Twilight' plops you into GDI command and introduces you to your character's wife who does nothing except cry and get sentimental. Its like the writers clearly want you to care about her, but they give you no reason. You feel absolutely no sympathy for her - I thought it was just my issue cause she's not my type, because I'm as gay as a bloody West End musical! But most people seem to hate her character.

Do I recommend this game? No, not even to the hardcore fans of the franchise. I mean if you're really, genuinely curious then feel free to watch a YouTube play-through because its not worth wasting your hard earned cash.

column8:
12 minutes. Seems unfair, right? Well, couldn't even get past the login - game wouldn't accept any information I put in that was valid and the online only crap was poorly done and unnecessary. Still, from what I have seen... I will try to somewhat criticize the aspects that I dislike.
No base building whatsoever. Major departure that could've been executed better. Specialization of crawlers is a decent concept on its own, but seems a bit dry and EA didn't really hit any marks with the audience they were trying to please, and missed the niche that their fanbase is used to.

Back to mobile bases for a second... it's genuinely a decent idea that has been executed in other games with success. EA didn't do that. No resource gathering, but a limited number of buildable units? Yeah, that's a pass.

I've seen the cutscenes. Just no. The new characters are unlikable. The cutscenes themselves look very drab and meh.

In short, just... no. This was not a fitting end to the Tiberian saga. The Tiberian saga deserved a far better ending. Only positive is that you can't get this shitpile on Steam anymore.

column8:
[b]Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight[/b] is an RTS that ditches base building in favor of more dynamic action. Instead of a regular base you get choice between the three walking tanks - crawlers, that can produce units, build defenses or call up support abilities, like bombing the area or laying down mines. While the concept might sound fun on paper and there are a lot of games built around similar ideas, the game pulls it off completely wrong. Now that your base is walking around the map, thereâ€™s no need to collect resources, so you can build whenever you want, but your maximum number of units is limited. This makes the campaign so much harder, because your enemies usually have multiple crawlers and so the bigger unit limit. At times I felt like I was deadlocked into a stalemate, because the enemy produced units at the same time as I destroyed them. However, the stupidness of the AI helps very much in such cases. If you focus your fire on the enemy base, AI will not notice it most of the time and will keep destroying your units, but you can keep replacing them almost at the same rate as they can.

I wonâ€™t go into story details here, first of all because it requires at least some knowledge of previous games. Second of all, itâ€™s so bland and generic in this game, that you will probably forget it as soon as you close the game. The graphics look ok, doesnâ€™t feel like theyâ€™ve changed much since previous game and it still has a 30 FPS lock, that no one in the modding community bothered to remove, so youâ€™ll be stuck with that if you decide to play it. The FMV cutscenes have changed for the worse, it feels like they cut the budget in half. The original costumes are gone, now soldiers wear the same outfits as in our world, other characters wear plain clothes. A quick reminder that the game takes place in the year 2077 and the cities in the video reports they show you throughout the game look the same as in 2010. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ A new take on the C&C formula

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Unbalanced campaign
- Story feels shallow and boring
- FMV cutscenes are very low budget
- Very short (around 8-9 hours)
- You have to enter your Origin login and password every time you launch the game

I didnâ€™t think it could be that bad. Now I know, and I think you should not waste any time on it. Thankfully, it was removed from the store, hopefully to be replaced with the true sequel to [b]Tiberium Wars[/b] and [b]Kaneâ€™s Wrath[/b].

What is this game?

It's not Command & Conquer for sure, maybe by actors it is, but by gameplay... oh hell no... C&C3 was the final game in the series this was just, IDK what this was....

At the request of the publisher, Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight is no longer available for sale on Steam. 

I think that should read - At the request of the just about EVERYONE, Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight is no longer available for sale.

column8: Be warned i've only played this game for an hour. Before you even start the game you need to login into EA. Play time!...ummm NO. You need to login AGAIN this time ingame. Base building (as well as resources) was almost entirely removed (you can only build turrets) so if you are a fan of gathering resources/base building just ignore this game completely. Instead you can only use mech-like crawler mobile base to build units. Units looks cartoony AF  and they are way too big. Maybe one day i will force myself to play through the whole game but for now it's a big NO.

column8:
I literaly can't even play it thanks EA, the CD key is completly broken I don't remember C&C 3 asking me for anything 
The story revealed something in the most garbage way ever, I only know this cuz I watched the campaign on youtube to even know what I would get into, 
Firstly the tiberium is gone, it's just gone, no longer plot relevant I guess even tho from 1-3 it was literaly the thing that made this game interesting and it's the entire plot point of all 3 of these but no just remove it. 
Than we got something we never asked for, where is the base building asset gone to, WASN'T THAT LIKE WHAT WE LIKED ABOUT IT EH? BUILDING A BASE? EXPANDING? No give us this armored walkers that work as an entire base, no tech to research, no tech, no make us level up to unlock new units, instead of building a high tech building to unlock the top tier shit, get to level 30 or something and the combined arms aspect? nah we don't need that shit, heres offense, defense, support because you have been used to using your firehawks to bomb the living hell out of NOD while charging in with your zone troopers an mammoth tanks, no heres only one for you, your either infantry and defenses, aircraft only or heavy vehicles cuz fuck you
Next up we have this being an online game, AI? goodbye, online only, no fun trying to work your ass of trying to be brutal AI for that dam platinum cuz that shit wasn't fun nooo we all just hated it you know?
Also now you just have unlimited money because we can longer mine tiberium which was very important having to expand your area to get other tib fields so you can get more money so you can get more units, just give us a unit cap because yes
No more trying to get that giant tiberium field, no more aquring that blue tiberium, no more getting those silos, no more getting those towers.
Defense is literaly the most useless MCV ever, next being support and offense being the only one you should ever pick
Also we added the scrin into the storyline even tho they never appear in the game despite it being clear that the first apearence was just an Expeditionary force, we couldev gave them a second comming with literaly more firepower than ever but nah man just add some random scrin guy or whatever his name was I don't remember the story it's boring
Also good way to kill the whole mystery of Kane being literally immortal by telling us, hey this dude ain't human his an alien. Way to kill the mood

column9:
This isn't a C&C game.
It's a mobile clicker. Call it whatever you want, but don't disgrace the iconic C&C strategy series.
The gameplay has been casualized and simplified to the point that you can't build bases or mine Tiberium.
Moving plastic icons around is like a tug-of-war. Capturing points is reminiscent of the old Empire at War, but even there it felt more appropriate.
Sh*t up and take my money!

column9:
After 11 years, this game has finally been removed from the Steam store.

Leaving aside its quality, what was the game's state before it was taken down? Servers were frequently down, and when I posted questions on the EA forums, the community managers were either completely clueless or just offered a few useless "solutions."

This removal means that players' unit unlock progress and battle records will be lost. More importantly, since the single-player campaign also requires a constant internet connection to save, even though the story campaign is utterly terrible, experiencing this storyline in the CN Tiberium series will no longer be possible through legitimate channels. The series is currently being presented as a purely multiplayer game, and its unreliability is self-evident.

Now the Steam store page has even removed the multiplayer tag, so it seems EA has voluntarily given up on selling it. If this is EA's attitude, I suggest TTF's removal be done quickly as well.

12.02 Update: TTF really removed? Then it's fine.

column9:
I'm a die-hard C&C fan. Yes, I played the very first one back in 1995. It was a revolutionary game in its time. The FMV, the iconic music, the intuitive controls... the cutscenes were magnificent.

I knew this latest Command & Conquer wasn't exactly brilliant. But I had to play it, just for the story and to see the famous Kane one last time...

It's been a long time since I played it, but it's so vivid in my memory that I have to comment!

This is probably one of... if not the WORST example of a "good idea" gone wrong in video game history!

Instead of a base, you have a mobile builder.

The game is characterized by a pronounced rock-paper-scissors aspect. Which can have its good points, but is totally ridiculous at times. Or anti-tank vehicles with virtually no armor can withstand direct hits from shells without any problem.

In short, a mobile builder as your sole base, and you win in multiplayer with capture points, because you don't have any resources to manage.

Was this supposed to make the game more fast-paced and revolutionize the RTS genre?

No? I bet it was EA who wanted to invest the bare minimum. No base, no balancing to worry about. And a game accessible to a wider audience (non-RTS players).

Seriously, no base to build and MANAGE? This is the worst idea they could have had.
The result is that you wander around the map blindly, trying to capture control points and avoid exposing your only HQ if possible.
Plus, if the enemy has built a counter to yours, the very pronounced rock-paper-scissors effect means you simply can't win. You select all your units and delete them, lol. To build a new army. Yes, because it has no resources, just population points. You can get rid of your units without remorse.

Air units are OP. And the flying HQ is just as overpowered. It lets you avoid enemies indefinitely. Which allows you to play the little parasite the whole game! Yay! What fun!... (yes, the balancing in this game is awful)

Even if you play the campaign, you have to grind XP to unlock units. Forcing you to replay single-player maps. As if the game wasn't bad and uninteresting enough already...

Multiplayer was dead within the first week.

Finally, let's talk about the story. Uninteresting, even stupid. Sad ending...
Minor spoiler:
Kane uses the alien portal from the third game to leave for good. The end, and that's the end of the saga. Everything you accomplish during the story is pointless. You were Kane's bodyguard and you activate the portal.
Argh! Where are the aliens?

Graphically, it's... Uh... The same as 3? Only less detailed???

In short, a big "F" for this franchise, shamefully humiliated and butchered in C&C 4.
I think it's the worst game in my Steam library... That's all...
And it's 20 euros! Really? At that price, you can get much, much, much better alternatives.

However, I wholeheartedly recommend C&C Remastered. Just as good as the original, with cutscenes optimized for current resolutions. The gameplay is old-school but still excellent, especially for a nostalgic gamer who played it back in the day like me ğŸ˜„
Don't get 4, one of the biggest disappointments in history. Its Steam rating is well deserved.

column9:
The worst strategy game I've ever encountered;
The mechanics are incredibly stupid; it's not even a strategy, it's some kind of gypsy circus! You just wander around with your base (which is the only building in the game, aside from two cannons and bunkers if you choose the defense module).
There are no decent resources, no familiar buildings. At least nothing is familiar! This isn't C&C. Maybe someone as old as me remembers Strategy Z on the PS1. It's the same, but the maps are much smaller.
The campaign, when played, gives you a complete shambles after the 3rd or 4th mission. It's almost impossible to complete without skill upgrades, and skill upgrades are achieved either by playing the campaign or through long battles in Skirmish mode.
Skirmish mode is a complete bummer. You can't choose a sideâ€”it's like GDI, and you can't even stand a chance. Apparently, the ability to play as Nod needs to be unlocked somehow, but damn, this skirmish mode is a lousy one! It's always been like this: choose a map, starting conditions, opponents/allies, and off you go.
This isn't a case of a great idea with poor execution. This is a case of a truly flawed idea executed as closely as possible to the original.
I don't recommend purchasing it, even if they give it away for free, don't take it.
I rate it 1 out of 10 and wish an Arab would visit the home of everyone involved in the development.

column8:
Poniendo en una balanza lo bueno y lo malo, lamentablemente cobra mas peso lo MALO. 

-Como C&C es malo, como juego de estrategia tambiÃ©n. Y digo "estrategia" por decir algo, porque es casi nula. Cada pantalla se basa en un "toma y daca" entre tÃº y la cpu "defecando" unidades infinitas sin parar hasta que una aplasta a la otra.

-La historia es la peor de la saga, ya no solo por el sinsentido del argumento si no por lo pÃ©simamente malos que son todos los actores de los vÃ­deos, ni el propio Kane se salva, es su peor papel de lejos. 2 campaÃ±as, una larga y la de NOD cortisima que parece un "pegote" puesto de relleno y ambas con el mismo final.....

-Tiene ideas que podrÃ­an haber sido medio buenas pero si se hubiese planteado de otra forma, lo Ãºnico salvable es el uso del motor grÃ¡fico de Red Alert 3, que este Ãºltimo sin ser perfecto ni mucho menos es bastante mejor juego y mÃ¡s disfrutable.

+Resumiendo: Solo puede interesar a alguien que quiera terminar la saga y saber como se cierra la historia, dejandole el sabor agridulce de lo que podÃ­a haber sido y lo que nos han dado. Una lÃ¡stima ver como esta gran franquicia acabÃ³ asÃ­ de mal.
column9:
Weighing the good against the bad, unfortunately, the BAD outweighs the bad.

-As a C&C game, it's bad, and as a strategy game, it's bad too. And I say "strategy" loosely, because it's practically nonexistent. Each level is based on a back-and-forth between you and the CPU, endlessly churning out units until one crushes the other.

-The story is the worst in the series, not only because of the nonsensical plot but also because of how terribly bad all the actors are in the cutscenes. Even Kane himself is terrible; it's by far his worst role. Two campaigns: one long and the very short NOD campaign, which feels like an afterthought, and both have the same ending...

-It has ideas that could have been halfway decent, but if they had been implemented differently, the only redeeming feature is the use of the Red Alert 3 graphics engine. While Red Alert 3 isn't perfect by any means, it's a much better and more enjoyable game.

In short: This will only appeal to someone who wants to finish the saga and know how the story concludes, leaving them with a bittersweet feeling of what could have been and what we got instead. It's a shame to see this great franchise end so badly.

column8: The disappointing end to a great series. Command and Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight was a completely botched game that ultimately leaves you with a bad taste for the whole series. The campaign is short, the servers are down/dead, and the gameplay was repetitive from the earlier entries in the series. Unfortunately this game isn't really playable so that means a negative review but I hope Command and Conquer makes a return one day.

column8: I have to say this came as a nice surprise since virtually everyone is trash talking this game... But I actually loved it. I really enjoyed the balance between strategic planning and live action, I think it comes pretty smooth and natural. Besides, the graphics and sounds are really enjoyable. Much better than the previous Tiberium release, or the really disappointing Red Alert 3. One negative note though, it is quite hard to understand what type of units you are creating - or should create - before seeing them behaving on the battlefield. Their name and visual are hardly helping (especially for Nods units), and their summary is poorly written.

column9:
I downloaded Command & Conquer TW and KW a long time ago... It's rare to fall so deeply in love with a game... A deep story, excellent dynamics, graphics for something its age, oh, the charisma and performance of Joseph David Kukan (Kane). Thanks to his performance, I fell in love with the Brotherhood of Nod and believe in the bright future of Tiberium!... And then I decided to buy "Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight." To say it's complete crap is an understatement. How could they kill something players have loved for so many years with one release? The familiar mechanics and gameplay that made you spend hours playing are gone... These cartoonish, mobile-game-like graphics... it's nauseating. 
If you don't want to be disappointed in this series and don't want to make yourself vomit... don't even try it.
You can, of course, but people warned you... Those people who wrote reviews had tears in their eyes.

Contras:
-Te pide iniciar sesiÃ³n 2 veces en EA, caso contrario no podrÃ¡s jugar
-El serial puede no funcionarte y hasta podrÃ­as tener que instalar Origin para correrlo
-Ya no se arman bases, cosecha tiberio ni existen las bombas nucleares ni caÃ±Ã³n de iones
-Ahora cada unidad tiene un tipo de arma y blindaje: si no dispones del arma adecuada para destruir a cierto blindaje, casi que no podrÃ¡s destruirla (por ej. destruir Mammoths con lÃ¡sers)
-Las unidades son gratis, se construyen rÃ¡pido y son limitadas: ahora existe un sistema de puntos parecida a la comida en Warcraft III. Esto provoca que entres en un loop contra el rival donde cada unidad destruida instantÃ¡neamente es reemplazada
-Todo se hace desde un Crawler, una base mÃ³vil que cae del cielo (literal)
-La campaÃ±a tiene 7 misiones por facciÃ³n y se terminan en 5 horas
-Los Scrin nunca volvieron a pisar la Tierra, a pesar de haber prometido una invasiÃ³n total
-El hilo argumental no sigue para nada C&C3 ni KW, todo el ejÃ©rcito cyborg de LegiÃ³n prÃ¡cticamente no existe
-Su apartado grÃ¡fico es inferior a su precuela, con un tono ligeramente caricaturesco
-El diseÃ±o de los vehÃ­culos es demasiado genÃ©rico, casi que no existen unidades mÃ­ticas de toda la saga mÃ¡s que el Mammoth tank, la nave Venom y la moto de ataque
-Al no haber base, la condiciÃ³n de victoria se reduce a capturar nodos de tiberio, algo asÃ­ como construir maravillas en Age of Empires pero mÃ¡s aburrido todavÃ­a

Pros:
column9:
Cons:
- You'll need to log in to EA twice; otherwise, you won't be able to play.
- The serial number might not work, and you might even have to install Origin to run it.
- You can no longer build bases, harvest Tiberium, or use nuclear bombs or ion cannons.
- Now, each unit has a specific weapon type and armor: if you don't have the right weapon to destroy a certain armor, you'll almost certainly be unable to destroy it (e.g., destroying Mammoths with lasers).
- Units are free, quick to build, and limited: there's now a point system similar to the food system in Warcraft III. This causes you to enter a loop against the opponent where every destroyed unit is instantly replaced.
- Everything is done from a Crawler, a mobile base that literally falls from the sky.
- The campaign has 7 missions per faction and can be completed in 5 hours.
- The Scrin never returned to Earth, despite having promised a total invasion.
- The storyline doesn't follow C&C3 or KW at all; the entire cyborg army of Legion is practically nonexistent.
- Its graphics are inferior to its predecessor, with a slightly cartoonish style.
- The vehicle designs are too generic; there are almost no iconic units from the entire saga other than the Mammoth tank, the Venom ship, and the attack bike.
- With no base, the victory condition is reduced to capturing Tiberium nodes, something like building wonders in Age of Empires, but even more boring.

Pros:

column8: Certainly not the best CnC game. U could say a "unique" system. However the grinding for exp to unlock the full army potential is just annoying. Campaign itself doesn't represent much. On the topside u could say there a few "old time units" coming back from games like tiberian dawn and CnC 3. But that's about it, also the unit limit is annoying, you could say it adds to the tactical element so the player needs to overthink what units to use. But not really fitting for those that know the franchise. It's a bit of a mixed feeling for me. I got it simply out of nostalgia after playing the other games in the series. Would say try it if you haven't played any other games in the franchise, otherwise you may get dissapointed.

column8:
As a long time C&C fan who played all the others back to the original when it came out, I knew this was bad, but saw it on sale and wanted to "complete the collection".  This game feels like it was designed by executives in a conference room who never saw any C&C game.  They completely killed the playstyle and themes that made the franchise what it was. There is no base building in the sense of past C&C games, everything is done by your headquarters. And you have 3 types of HQ you switch between all that do completely different things.  To switch is not a button on the building to toggle. Oh no, they chose a much more logical option. You destroy it and call in a new HQ! Thought Tiberium was cool? There is no resource collection/management, you just stay under a low cap for units and defensive structures.  You'll see a bit of Tiberium on the map sometimes, take a screenshot for the memories. 

Oh yeah, and you need to have an EA account to play it. Even on sale, your cash is better spent by lighting it on fire. At least then you won't waste hours of your life you can never get back.

PS/ The game is great, but being forced to buy it again is unacceptable, especially since I bought it on Steam.

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700]â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€[/url]
EA doubled down on DRM for this game. The first problem I encountered was logging in. When you buy this off Steam, you need to make sure you have an Origin account and register your new cd key on Origin. There are two logins in this game. When you start the game, you start the launcher first and it requires you to enter your Origin credentials. Now thereâ€™s another login screen in-game, you will enter the same credentials. HOWEVER, compared to the launcherâ€™s login, if your password is MORE THAN 16 CHARACTERS the game will not log you in. The [b]in-game password field cannot go past 16 characters.[/b] I had to shorten my password, making my account less secure. Now, this game has another problem and itâ€™s a major one.

It appears that the multiplayer features of the game are locked; the servers supporting the multiplayer must have shut down. Attempts to host a lobby will give you an error. [b]Thereâ€™s no way to know if auto-matching works, but itâ€™s safe to say that all three multiplayer features--lobby hosting, co-op campaign, and auto-matching--do no longer work.[/b]

The only features you have access in this game is the campaign and skirmish against computer AIs. And who knows when this gameâ€™s remaining servers, for logging users in, will shut down.

So, if youâ€™re interested in only playing Command and Conquer 4â€™s story campaign, I recommend you buy it when it is heavily discounted. I got this for $5.


[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700][b]PUBLISHER REVIEW[/b][/url] ğŸ‘
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700]â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€[/url]
Electronic Arts double downed on DRM for this game, making it always online. Prior to this gameâ€™s release, the publisher killed some interesting projects for the franchise. They shutdown Tiberium, a squad-based shooter that takes place after Tiberium Wars that looks like Halo and is a spiritual successor to C&C Renegade. They shut down a sequel to Generals that had a story that sounded similar to Homefront games. Command & Conquer 4â€™s Tiberium Twilight started its life as an MMO which explains why there is a class and leveling system. The game was forced to be salvaged into a triple AAA rts game, retaining many gameplay mechanics that fans definitely would dislike. Furthermore, they forced the franchise's future games to be browser and mobile games. They killed Generals 2, which is trying to return to its RTS roots.

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700][b]DEVELOPER REVIEW[/b][/url] ğŸ‘
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700]â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€[/url]
They tried their best salvaging this game when it started as an MMO and faced heavy pressure from Electronic Artsâ€™s higher ups. There are some bugs, but the production quality is still good. These guys did their best and I wouldnâ€™t fault them.

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700][b]ACCESSIBILITY & OTHER REVIEW[/b][/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700]â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€[/url]
So I usually supersample the older games I play. Playing on 4k resolution in C&C4 in 1080p monitor is fine. The game looks a little better and sharper, but the cursor does not scale up. It's incredibly tiny, so it's hard to select buttons or icons.

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700][b]GAME REVIEW[/b][/url] ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700][b]AS A RTS GAME[/b][/url] ğŸ‘
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700][b]AS A COMMAND & CONQUER GAME[/b][/url] ğŸ‘
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TITLEplayer/recommended/47700]â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€[/url]
So this is a review of the current state of the game, meaning it will keep in mind that the multiplayer features are unavailable. Out of all the command and conquer games, this one has the worst story and campaigns. It is also very short. The GDI campaign is the worst one, and doesn't really explain the little details that's going on in the story. That's left to the NOD campaign, but is a bit better. Few of the Normal missions are hard to complete because your arsenal will be incomplete, your profile is under-leveled, and you can't play coop with another. You will have to play the campaign twice if you want to complete your arsenal. By then, it would be fun to play the campaign on the hardest difficulty with your full arsenal, but would it be worth the replay though?

This game reminds me of End of Nations and feels like a real slim down version of Red Alert 3. Even some of the unit designs feel as silly as the Red Alert 3's. Take, for example, the scorpion tank between C&C 3 Tiberium Wars and C&C4. In the previous game, it's sleek and looks like it's designed to be fast. In C&C4, it just looks more like a robotic scorpion. Or GDI's wolf tank looks like a little brother of the apocalypse tank.

The crawler system is interesting. You are given three types: offense, defense, and support. It makes the game almost feels like a moba and a beginnings of a MMORTS. Some units would have one or two abilities. Unit commands are carried over from Red Alert 3 and C&C3 Tiberium Wars and this game emphasizes a bit more on micromanagement. Although, I found the max population to be low and wished it was a tad higher. To upgrade, you have to level up your profile and right now, the fastest way is probably through the campaign. In the game, you will need to use your engineers to collect Tiberium crystals to be able to do upgrades (once you unlocked them through leveling). Furthermore, there are buildings that serve as control points which can be captured by your surrounding units. These grant further defense or extend deployment/building area. It feels similar to Dawn of War 2 or Company of Heroes, but worse. The defense crawler will be the closest thing to base building. Support crawler is focused a lot of building aerial units and using support abilities. I think the game shines a bit when you're playing 5 vs 5 with the AI, so you can have different crawlers supporting each other with their different unit compositions. Too bad multiplayer doesn't work anymore.

So as a C&C game, it's the worse but it's better than the recent mobile/browser C&C games. As a RTS game, it's okay.

Where to start.... Well, I manged to get 2 missions in before giving up, and those were just the tutorial missions. It felt nothing like a C&C game. At all. And while it may say 12 or so hours played, that's because I fell asleep on the keyboard from trying to get it to work. I also had to contact EA on playing the game since my code didn't work. It took longer for me to get access to the game than I've actually played.

In conclusion, I paid $4 and still feel ripped off, although the laughter I get from this game is priceless.

Edit: My brain cells were so fried after playing this garbage that I made grammatical errors. Corrected.

+ Balance, fast match endings, enhanced unit control.
- Huge bugs, the level of which would burn the asses of those who don't like farming, an old â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ engine, a low-budget company, and the game as a whole.
Conclusion: If you're willing to tolerate bugs and an old engine where units feel frozen, but still pride yourself on balance, this game is for you.
I'd give it a positive rating, but even though I was given this game as a gift, I have no idea whether it's worth the pain I've suffered because of the aforementioned downsides.

column8:
If you're looking to play this game as a sequel to the Command and Conquer Tiberium series, you shouldn't buy this game. It holds almost no connections to the original trilogy gameplay-wise and the overall plot isn't all that well supported. Now if you were looking to play this game without knowing what Command and Conquer is, then you might find some enjoyment in this game. It offers a sort of new concept of a moving base, and is very different from the base building RTS games that everyone is fond of. While the Unit Cap is quite annoying, it's understandable because for many people, commanding a limited amount of units while doing the same with the mobile base is easier than say, 200 units. 

There's a lot wrong with this game, one being that it was supposed to take the mantle of the Tiberium series, but failed catastrophically, and another being that there's many gameplay mechanics that are very dumb, like the unnecessary grind-y element of the game. Who would want to willingly grind out about 10 hours just to get the mastodon, or kodiak? They could have just restricted those unit access in the campaign, not in the Skirmishes. Or take the aformentioned unit cap; I said it was understandable, but that doesn't mean it was a very dumb thing to do. Most of the RTS players are perfectly fine with commanding a very large amount of units, that's the whole appeal of it.

With the story, I genuinely don't think it was alright. I will try not to spoil anything (though I doubt anyone would care even if I did,) but the way the campaign did the cutscenes, just no. I don't hate the actors that had to go through that, it's everything else about it; bland lines, decent-but-not-good enough emotion, the effects were alright, and definitely felt like it was made back in 2010. The story line did match up with the gameplay, but almost none of it made sense when you think about the other games in the franchise. There were plot holes like "how did GDI magically find a way to fight back against the Tiberium spread?" or "For what reason did Kane show the Tacitus to GDI?" that were never explained, even after pretty much a decade of radio silence. You should really not count this game as being canon to the story, sticking to C&C 3: Tiberium Wars is much better than this.

TL;DR, game not command and conquer, but decent RTS.

column9:
Don't buy it! Absolutely don't buy it! It's completely unplayable! Buying it is a complete waste of money!

Fuck EA, selling games you can't even play!

I got a pirated copy and tried out the GDI campaign. The story is mediocre; both sides' stories are similar. The final portal looks like it was just drawn on the wallâ€”so cheap. For grinding experience, you can play 5v5 PvE with four brutal units on your side and two or three on the enemy side. Just try your best; you have more players anyway. The experience is a bit low; it takes three games to level up. Playing the story mode levels you up quickly, but it's a bit difficult. If you can't beat it, try PvE to level up.

The early game is extremely painful, but the experience improves as you level up. The units are quite nice to look at, so it's not bad for killing time. Finally, a couple of points: don't buy it on Steam. Resources are everywhere online. If you can't play it, download all the necessary runtime libraries and try again with your antivirus software off, otherwise the CNC4.dll file might be deleted.

column8:
I hate that it's so hard to get working, but it still works. Eleven years after the fact, if you register your game on EA's website, login twice and then run in admin mode on Windows, you too can play CnC4. That's all it takes.

For the game itself, it's ok. If it wasn't a legacy game, I'd say it's a solid 6.5/10. If you liked this game on release, something was wrong with you. But if you like the nostalgia, and the $4 price tag, it's a good game.
column9:

Die Aufbaustrategie, das Sammeln von Tiberium und sÃ¤mtliche Themen die das spiel ausgemacht haben sind verschwunden.
Bauen von Basen ist nicht mehr mÃ¶glich und die Ressourcen quasi nicht begrenzt.

Als Fan der Reihe bin ich hochgradig enttÃ¤uscht, auch wenn hier neue Herausforderungen gestellt werden.

column9:
It has nothing in common with the previous installments.

The base-building strategy, the gathering of Tiberium, and all the elements that defined the game are gone.

Building bases is no longer possible, and resources are virtually unlimited.

Only the size of your squad is regulated.

As a fan of the series, I'm extremely disappointed, even though it does offer new challenges.

It's a real shame; I hope they eventually return to the old system.

column8: Killed the franchise

This game is STILL plagued with issues regarding redeeming the CD key ...after you PURCHASE  the game! When trying to play the game thru steam you will get an error after trying to use your legit CD key and won't be able to play the game after entering the CD key. What isn't mentioned is you can still redeem the CD key on the Origin website if you get this error. I purchased this game years ago and never got to use that other CD key. Back then I had gotten no help from EA on the offical forums. I even had the original box and receipt for the game back then but didn't even get a response on official forums from EA games (was a different email etc for me). This is the last EA game I will purchase, no reason to buy games from a company that doesn't even bother to make minimal effort to insure you can play the game you paid for. They could have easily remedied the issue by including a link to the Origin website when launching the game advising to redeem the CD key there if you get an error message when trying to use your CD key after launching the game.

column9:
+ Balance, fast match endings, enhanced unit control.
- Huge bugs, a level that would burn the asses of those who don't like farming, an old, crappy engine, a low-budget company, and the game as a whole.
Conclusion: If you're willing to tolerate bugs and an old engine that makes units feel frozen, but still pride yourself on balance, this game is for you.
I'd give it a positive rating, but even though I was given this game as a gift, I have no idea whether it's worth the pain I've suffered because of the aforementioned downsides.
