column8:
This is not Command & Conquer.
You don't build bases, you don't farm Tiberium and spoiler, at the end;  Kain Lives. 
There's no Intel to give the story depth, the cut-scenes are parents-basement budget level and like ET, the Scrin have gone home. 

However; in place of base-building/resource farming mechanic, units are recruited through a mobile command centre that levels up as the game progresses. There's no limit to how many units you can field but you are limited to how many can be deployed at one time. 
The upside is; you are thrown into combat immediately and the intensity of the battle doesn't letup as you endlessly order more troops into the flesh grinder of combat. 

The objective based RTS is familiar and GDI/NOD maintain their traditional eagle/scorpion airborne/guerrilla antagonistic combat styles. You will lose a few games so its not a walk in the park.

I would give it 2/5. It's easy to play but loyalists will be woefully disappointed and there are better RTS' on the market. Play only if you want to see the series through.

column8:
[i]I thought I can't launch the game, after doing some steps I managed to launch the game with no issue[/i]

Good game, enjoyable and very good quality in 4K even the game was released 10 years ago, might be the worst game on Steam due to the game support on CD Keys, errors, and such (and EA).

Login twice wasn't an issue to me, the story is just kinda back to zero again if you did played CNC3, however I'am not. Game features of using one unit (crawler) to create units is very enjoyable (able to go mobile, escape, and such). There is co-op on the game, which gave more availability to do campaign a lot easier, or even skirmish together.

AI is just a bit drag to deal with on skirmish. On solo, Easy is actually Medium, FYI the AI on skirmish is actually 1-3 level higher than you (unfair was it?), I'm not even gonna try higher than Medium cuz I lack of hotkeys and multitasking (need lots of practice).

Had to disagree to the limited command points on both campaign and skirmish, I would prefer without it just like RA3.

column8:
If this was a free to play game and had no connection to Command & Conquer, I may say give it ago... but it's not...

C&C4TT follows one of the best RTS series I've played. I would highly recommend playing any of the other C&C games in the series but this one. The reason this game got a overwhelmingly negative reviews is because (and I know this will be hard to believe) EA banged this out as a quick cash grab that ended up killing the franchise. You want the full story check youtube, many have covered this slap in the face.

If this game had no connection to C&C and free to play it would be okay at best. Unfortunately compared to it's predecessors its a turd...

column9:
Thanks for the Korean support!

# 3 Fun Things
1. Completely Different Game System: A new system that's quite different from existing strategy simulators.
2. Casual Gameplay: It's great because it even shows unit compatibility.
3. Decent Graphics: Even in 2020, the graphics are quite acceptable.

# 3 Boring Things
1. No Resources: Because there are no resources, the strategic aspect is largely lost, and units are not worth spending much on.
2. Uninspired Units: The unique units of existing C&Cs are gone, and they all look similar.
3. Limited Unit Creation: Despite being a strategy simulator, the system requires leveling up to unlock units.

# Overall Review
Many of the systems seem to be the foundation of the mobile game C&C Rivals. To put it bluntly, it's a game ahead of its time. I recommend playing it without thinking of it as a typical strategy simulation or C&C.

column8:
Bought this when it came out 10 years ago. It didn't take long for me to question all of the things they changed but I finished the game out of a sense of seeing the ending. If you're a big C&C fan I'd say it's worth 5 bucks just to experience how easy it was for them to both end and ruin an entire franchise at the same time.

I really just can't comprehend how this game made it out of testing. If they had ANYONE testing it who had played the previous games they would have been laughed at for wanting to make this. You know how base building, creating massive armies and everything else worked so well in the previous games? Yeah throw all of that out the window here. Your base is basically one building that does everything and you can only have a hand full of units at a time. This game is the perfect example of "Don't fix what isn't broken". Imagine if Blizzard released the next WoW expansion as a turn based browser game and this is how you end up with C&C 4.

column9:
Even though the game is extinct, I want to bring it back to life! It all depends on you! Yes, the game wasn't particularly good for fans of this franchise. But the gameplay of this game since 2010 is perfect. The game has proven itself to be a great success, and playing it with friends will be a pleasant and unforgettable experience.
Why am I getting at all this? I have a Discord channel where I invite all of you, my friends! Let's bring this game back to those days.

When we played side by side and fought for Tiberium points.

When we screamed with victories and new units.

When we tried to be the first to unlock upgrade points and upgrade our crawler.

Add me as a friend, and I'll add you to our Discord channel!

column9: The game is terrible! There's no base building, the units are all the same type, and you can't tell them apart when they're all crammed together. The graphics have dropped a notch compared to the previous game. The plot is pathetic, taking up half a page in 3-4 sentences. You're given a choice between two factions, and the one you choose determines the ending. They've removed the screenshots from C&C 4; you won't even see a hint of them in the game. The battles are boring and uninteresting! You have three MSCs to choose from, and they're all unbalanced! The game outside of the campaign is disgusting and looks like this: two beetles sit down and stare at each other to see who can outspammed whom. The economic component has been completely removed from the game; instead of resources, you have command points, which limit your unit selection. 10 units is all you haveâ€”you have no command points, so go and fight with those 10 units! You're sitting there, grinding away at that one squad of 10 units... Tiberium, which, by the way, you still have to get to the landing zone, is used to upgrade your units. In the later stages of the game, when you've maxed out everything, you no longer need Tiberium, and all you have is your damn beetle and your squad with 10 units. The game is the same on both hard and easy difficulties, and the question is, "What's the point?" It's like you have a choice, but that choice doesn't affect you. By the way, the campaign takes 3-5 hours, and there are two of them. To unlock all the content, you have to gain a ton of experience with one faction, grinding away at the same units for 15-20 hours. So, playing with two factions gives you a maximum of 40 hours of nothing to do. There's no real competitive edge to the game because of the cut economy; all you can do is spam units. THIS WHOLE GAME BOTTOM LINES UP TO ONE LOGICAL CONCLUSION - "UNIT WANKING," of which there are, by the way, as many as 10. Solitaire would be more interesting... Don't waste your time on it.

column9:
Not to mention the activation code that required reactivation from EA, the numerous dice rolls and failed registration attempts, this game simply can't compare to NOD3. As a game artist, I have some standards for mecha design, but setting aside other aspects, the art style alone is utterly terrible. The only redeeming quality might be the improved cinematics, perhaps because they invested all their money in live-action performances. Returning to the mecha and unit design, a few perfectly good machines are crammed with a bunch of glowing bars, making the units look like a bunch of cheap plastic toys. The realism of NOD3 is completely gone, leaving me extremely disappointed. NOD's units are also absurd, crammed with gothic elements or something, incredibly low-quality, especially some of the aerial unitsâ€”are they not toys? They're downright ugly. And the UI is equally tacky, especially the victory and defeat iconsâ€”what kind of cheap, low-budget effects are those?! Where did the cool 3D rotating logo go?

The gameplay is also incredibly strange. It's become a unit-farming game where you easily get stuck with limited population. Starting with several different bases is ridiculously difficult. Having come from the third installment, I'm completely bewildered. Basic management and gameplay have been completely rewritten, making it incredibly awkward and frustrating to play.

I don't want to say more, it's absolutely terrible! I'll stick to the third installment...

column8:
Of all the command and conquer games available, this will be the black sheep that the rest of the series will never admit to being part of. 

This is the worst game of them all:
[list]
[*] Cannot build an army to overwhelm the enemy
[*] Unit choice is extremely limited
[*] No longer constructing Bases, its all movable unit creation
[*] Limited resources

They should have left it at C&C 3 or Red Alert 3. Spend your money on something else, even if its a 95% off sale DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

column9:
I liked the game solely for the story. However, there are many downsides:
1. Constructionâ€”what I loved in this seriesâ€”is gone. I became disillusioned with EA right then, 10 years ago.
2. The graphics in Part 3 are vastly better than in Part 4. It's as if the creators were replaced, shot, pissed on, and raped. In that order. And in their place, they installed people who developed mobile games.
3. The balance system is unnecessary nonsense. Previously, you built a base and could balance the game according to your tactics, but now you just choose one of three tank systems and fight the entire game. Fortunately, you can change them during the game, but the restructuring is depressing.
4. They left the ending open, but I simply can't imagine what kind of drug addiction could be woven into the plot. For me, the game ended with Part 3.
5. Every time I want to log in to the game, I have to enter my username and password for the EA servers. This is just not right for me. The game forgets me every damn time.

This game is not as bad as people say it is. I have been playing command and conquer since it first came out in the early 90's. This game is not traditional to the series and is more comparable to Company of Hero's. You have levels and exp. You have commander classes and unit veterancy.  Making this game feel like a more recent  release than it is. You can have fun in this game just remember it's a little different than the others. With that said the story is not very good and leaves you on a cliffhanger but that's how they always have been.

column9:
Phew, it's hard to talk about SNS4, but we'll start with two things.
1) How to play?
Yes, the community has a big problem with just launching the game. Here's the instruction.
Buy the game, copy the activation key the first time you launch it, or copy it manually. Log in to your Origin account (or create a new one if you don't have one). Add the game to your account. Insert the key. Link SNS4 to your Origin account. Close Origin. Launch SNS4 through Steam. Enter your username and password in the launcher. Create a new SNS4 player profile. Log in to the game. Enter your username and password again. You can play without any hassle and with LIVE online.
2) Why? Because RTS is so fucked up in 2020 that SNS4 is a good RTS. Yeah, the game is a fucking mess, but there are no questions. - It's fun to play.
- There's a co-op campaign.
- It's live for 2020 online.
- The campaign is as interesting as the good old days, with live actors, plot twists, and so on.
- The game has abandoned the standard SNS mechanicsâ€”that is, a base with resources and such. Which has really blew fans' minds. WHERE'S THE FUCK IS TIBERIUM? Where are the harvesters? How can I even say shit here? Yes, I agree that completely changing the mechanics for the numbered unit is bad. BUT, the new mechanics are interesting to play, and the game offers a new experience different from the classic one: I build a power plant, I go to the barracks, I build a resource tank, and at the same time, I build a couple of soldiers. The typical RTS opening (standard actions for each game) is immediately removed; here you can go from strength to strength. The game has become more dynamic, preventing players from sitting on the defensive. Interesting mechanics with army profiles: Attack-Defense-Support. It's all unusual, but interesting. But this played a cruel joke on the game; most of the community got mad, didn't understand it, and buried the game and, along with it, the series. Cool.
- But besides the controversial issues, the game shot itself in the foot a couple of times. 1) Factions, there are only two. In the strategy game in 2010. Yes, after 2003, the developers realized that RTS with 2 factions was crap and started making it 3. Even in SS 2 and 3, there were forgotten units and screenshots. And what's here? NOD GDI is a neutral building with 3 types of forgotten units. THAT'S IT. Where's the 3rd faction? Couldn't they have made the same screenshots or made the forgotten ones a full-fledged playable faction? Or someone new? For example, people who got fed up with the squabble between GSB and NOD and created their own faction called "I'm so sick of this, I'm going to punch everyone who fights" (figuratively speaking). And here there are 2 factions. Yes, there are a lot of units, but 2 factions? Hello? In Star Wars, there was an Empire vs. Thief expansion pack, 3. 2) Unlocking units with experience. This is brilliant! I buy RTS and get unlocked units (abilities) like in an MMO. Aha, I'm shocked. EA, who the hell are you, a *female dog*, to even think of this? What *genital organ* am I supposed to unlock units in PvP/PvE and the campaign with? Do you have a dealer? Do you buy units from kiosks? What are you playing? Are you idiots? Yes, using less-than-honest methods, you can unlock all units for all two factions in about 4 hours. BUT WHY? I understand earning achievements or skins... BUT UNITS IN A PAID GAME?????
The verdict is: give the game a chance. If you haven't tried it before, it's high time you gave it a try due to the shortage of RTS games. It's like a creepy woman and a bottle of vodka. After the bottle of vodka, the creepy woman isn't so creepy. And we're in 2020 and RTS.
In 2020, SnS 4 isn't such a bad game.

column9:
I first bought it in 2016 when I reached level 20 on both GDI and Nod. If it weren't for revisiting those memories and this recent price drop, I wouldn't have bought it again. Here are my reasons:

1. Compared to Ragnarok Online (RA), Generals, and other Tiberium games, the game mode changes drastically. The population cap, in my opinion, killed the game. Furthermore, separating buildings, skills, and units, while intended to enhance teamwork and reduce difficulty, results in a very fast-paced battle. In 5v5 battles, you can't even find anyone.

2. The game mode is too repetitive and tiring. Upgrading and unlocking units, coupled with AI pressure before level 20, makes it incredibly grindy.

3. The story... is too rushed.

However, I must say, the game's rendering, models, and BGM are excellent (Nod's battle music is addictive).

Sigh... it's really disappointing that the CNC series ended so poorly. I hope RA2 and CNC2 will be remade in the future (I hope I can see a remake of Generals in my lifetime).

column8:
"Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight" is the worst C and C game I have ever played, because:
1) It has a mobile base that you have to keep moving.
2) You have to collect resources by driving a unit to the resource area and back again - but that function isn't automated (which is annoying).
3) The creation of units is limited.
4) You have to earn upgrade points to make your units stronger, but those points take too long to earn.
When I played, I found that the first lot of units are weak and junk.

You also have to defend points, manually collect resources, and keep these points under your control, and you have to choose defence (which gives you defensive structures and low level assault units) or a sky base (no defence, but flying units, low grade tanks and vehicles) or an "Assault" base (which has good tanks, but no sky units or defensive structures.

The only positive I can give is that the controls are not bad (although not great), and it is a nice looking game with good graphics.

column9:
I really wanted this to be a true installment in the series, not a last-minute imitation that they'd tweaked and tried to pass off as genuine. I tried to play it several times, and even almost finished it. I hoped to find some value in it, questioning all the criticism. And I failed. The only thing undeniably cool about this game is the main menu. I was glued to it every time I launched it. It exudes a promise of pathos and epicness, and when you see it for the first time, it's impossible not to fall for it. It seems like this is itâ€”an incredible and long-awaited adventure in a beloved universe. But unfortunately, it was a complete failure.

It's ironic that most of the criticism turned out to be a matter of taste. However, in each case, I still came to the conclusion that the game is crap. For example, everyone says the characters are bad and no one is memorable except Kane, and that the acting is bad and the plot is dumb. This is only partially true. I don't know what people were looking at, but the acting in the cutscenes is very good. They're trying hard, and it's clearly visible. But the performances themselves are bad.

Or, for example, fans of the series criticize the cartoonish graphics, although there's nothing wrong with them at all. I'd even say they're cool. And the effects are very beautifully done. But the unit designs are a disaster. Most of the game shows boxes on screen, either on wheels or flying, which are very difficult to distinguish from each other at first glance. That said, some individual units look really cool, like motorcycles, stealth tanks, and walkers. But all of this gets lost in the background of the overflowing boxes, especially in GDI.

And the gameplay itself has also been criticized, mainly for the inability to build a base. In my opinion, this game came out too early, and the developers, in turn, were ahead of their time. They practically predicted the trend in computer games for a decade to come. But neither the audience was ready, nor the developers themselves were ready to do it right. I think if it were released today, such a MOBA strategy game could have been a success with a few tweaks. I'd be more than willing to play such a game now if it were made with an eye toward competing with Dota, LoL, and other Overwatch games.

P.S. The final trailer is fucking awful. It's just fucking disgraceful. It's cheap and completely fucked up at the same time.

column8:
I played this with a friend ages ago for the campaign and brief multiplayer match; am an avid fan of C&C having grew up with it.

It's not the worst C&C game to date, or even when it came out sadly as EA are clueless idiots; any and all lite or mobile versions are blatantly worse if by a small degree.

They removed the core gameplay in favour of an untested premise that proved largely inferior and alienated the fans and vets (the only people who would play) and gave a pretty lacklustre rushed story.

Lots of the game feels out of balance and overhauled units and other things unnecessarily. C&C 3 did exist and had gotten very close to a great system, yet they threw out all of that to try something completely different?

I'd say this was the game that killed the franchise but in truth, EA's meddling and incompetence killed the franchise.
It's quite worth playing the older titles, though I wouldn't be surprised to find very little for online play left.

column8: As someone who grew up playing the many variations of this beautiful game franchise from the originals, red alert; generals; and the Tiberium sagas; even years after i purchased this horrid abomination of a game I still cannot bring myself to play it. This crap is not how the game series should have been sent off, this crap should never have seen its first downloads and unfortunate purchases. The developers I would hope didn't think this would be received well and did this under the age old my way or the highway petty bullshit that plagues the world of creativity when money is involved at any realistic level. If you've found yourself intrigued by this series, if you have any love for what you have come to enjoy out of this amazing strategy series DO NOT by this garbage please I wanted it to do well when it released I wanted to believe I was wrong for this thought process, but if over 2k people have had the same thoughts as i have that this game should be pulled erased and forgotten and our money and time reimbursed because of its sheer garbage nature then i can live with my favorite series ending in a damned dumpster fire so long as someone else can be spared my irritation. Edit: EA removed this dumpster fire and made it harder to get to hide the shame of this garbage game. F U C K. E A.

column9:
I bought this game despite the warnings of those who played it. I thought, "Hey, I'll try it for myself, see if it's really as bad as they say."
...I was warned.
You only have 50 command points, which, while they may seem like a lot, actually only allow you to have about 8 units. The gameplay is boring to say the least, and... there's an account leveling system to unlock everything you can build in a game, even though in the single-player campaign you can fight tier 3 mechs while still using tier 1 soldiers. Highly not recommended.

column8:
I loved C&C 3, both games.  But C&C4 went in the complete wrong direction.  The game mechanics are overly complex and just not fun and the online emphasis is a drawback, not an enhancement.  They got everything right in C&C3.  In fact, I would still be willing to pay money for an authorized C&C3 DLC with a full blown GDI or Scrin campaign, similar to what they did with Kane's Wrath.  Use the same game mechanics but clean up the engine and graphics.

For anyone who loves C&C3, stay far, far away from C&C4.

column8:
I'm not sure what almost ruined this more for me; the wave of negative reviews by angry 30 year old teenagers taking out their frustration on software after their partners / parents crapped on them for peeing on the toilet seat and not cleaning up afterwords or leaving dirty laundry on the floor? Or perhaps the C&C fanboy/girl base who expected Tiberium Wars 3.5 but got something different, so threw the toys out of the cot? I'd say the former, who appear to be in the majority, as the latter have the intelligence to channel their anger and hatred towards the big bad nasty evil multinational conglomerate cabal - EA for short. Fair game to them, their opinion is almost relevant, but still...

For perspective: after coming back to Tiberium Wars and Kane's Wrath time and time again (it's aged beautifully, hasn't it?), I finally decided to try this out as I wanted a bit more story, however I was fully aware of the negative reviews over the years. Finally I got my chance as I had just finished it's predecessor for like the 5th time when this one appeared on special for literally pennies, so I thought "why not?"

I found myself fighting the feeling that the lynch mob were right, at least during the first few missions. But once I had numbed myself to the fact that the story was indeed passable, the acting (or overacting, in some cases) was lacklustre (excluding Joe Kucan, of course) I went with it and in the end found myself playing the game for what it was. And it was actually okay.

The formula is completely different and forces you to be more resourceful. Resource harvesting is gone and bases are essentially mobile. The graphics, lighting etc, remind me of Tiberium Wars, thus feel familiar which is okay. Units are over the top, but some structures remind me of it's predecessor. 

In a nutshell - I'm kind of glad I played/finished this game and got to scratch it off my list. At no point did I feel the need to rush through and each night I couldn't wait to continue playing.

Did I get my money's worth? Definitely
Did EA ruin the franchise by trying to reinvent the wheel? 110% Yes
Would i have preferred "Tiberium Wars 3.5" instead of this? Absolutely
Was it a memorable experience? Not entirely
Was it as bad as people say? Definitely not

If you can pick it up for couple of Â£ one day and are curious, I'd recommend it. You wouldn't have lost much. Sadly, some of the keyboard warrior reviewers here have turned this game (among others) into a public toilet where they can dump their hatred and anger, wash their hands and move on to Dota 2, CS:GO and Fortnite (games with communities that aren't toxic at all ;P). 

Whatever. Just be sure to pick through the intelligent, logical reviews before deciding. My verdict? It's not THAT bad.

column9:
I managed to log in to EA, but then the key didn't work. I got a bit of an idea and went to Origin to find it and entered the key Steam had given me, and VOILÃ€! It downloaded! xD

Even so, the game is bad. It's basically just running around the map with your base, playing cat and cat with the enemy who's doing the same thing. You don't build bases, there's no resource gathering, units are created at your base on legs, and there's a very small limit on the number you can have. It's all pointless. Anyway.

column9:
After much deliberation, I still gave it a bad review.

To be honest, this is the worst game in the CNC series. EA's innovations haven't given CNC a new lease on life; instead, they've driven the final nail into its coffin.

Saying it's completely worthless is extremely unfair. The unit design and models are great; the attack, defense, and support systems are also decent; if you ignore the extremely poor storyline and the CNC sequel bias, it's at least a barely passable game. These are all the positives I can find.

As for the game's flaws, they include, but are not limited to, the extremely limited population, the terrible skirmishes, and the upgrade-to-unlock unit system that seemed to come up with on a whim. All of these contribute to a terrible gaming experience, coupled with the utterly awful storyline, making it the worst CNC game ever.

I strongly advise against buying it, even if you're just trying it out. You'll regret it.

column8: Es ist schade was sie aus der Command and Conquer reihe gemacht haben . Ein Epischer Abschluss der Saga mit so ein drecks Game. Crowler wer ist den bitte auf so eine blÃ¶de Idee gekommen damals ??? Und dann kommste aufgrund der Eingeschrenktheit in jeder Mission ab der seiten wahl in Strugeln. 48 einheiten limit ??? wer hat den scheiÃŸ erfunden ???     48iger einheiten limit heiÃŸt 6 einheiten gegen gegner der 2 crowlers hat und du bist alleine. WTF kauft diese Game bloss nicht selbst als Fan der reihe ist 4 der grÃ¶ÃŸte Bockmist den sie geschossen haben man macht mich das sauer. Hoffe es gibt ein Remaster von 4 WO MAN CROWLER IN DEN MÃœLL WIRFT. Und wieder auf Basenbau geht. wie es in 3 Teilen so war und auch GUT war.  Meine Warnung an euch wer UnnÃ¼tzes geballer ohne verstand will was den Look von C&C tiberium reihe haben will,kauft es,  wer auf basenbau hofft mit tiberium sammeln lasst die finger davon.  ps : rechtschreibfehler kÃ¶nnt ihr behalten wenn ihr welche findet danke.
column9: It's a shame what they've done to the Command & Conquer series. An epic conclusion to the saga with such a terrible game. Crowlersâ€”who on earth came up with such a stupid idea back then??? And then, because of the restrictions, you run into trouble in every mission from the moment you choose sides. A 48-unit limit??? Who invented that crap??? A 48-unit limit means 6 units against an opponent with 2 Crowlers, and you're on your own. WTF? Don't even buy this game. Even as a fan of the series, 4 is the biggest load of rubbish they've ever made. It makes me so angry. I hope there's a remaster of 4 where they ditch Crowlers and go back to base building, like in the first three games, which was actually GOOD. My warning to you: If you want mindless shooting without any sense, something that looks like the C&C Tiberium series, buy it. If you're hoping for base building and Tiberium gathering, stay away. P.S.: You can keep any spelling mistakes you find, thanks.

column8:
I actually like the concept of this game. They made a big mistake putting "4" in the title because you assume it will be like 1-3 but it's not. I did actually enjoy the game play though. 

Back when you could play online my biggest problem honestly was the you didn't get to pick which faction to play half the time because it had to have equal numbers of GDI and Nod players. Don't know why it matters. In every other C&C game you could skirmish with whatever teams you want. 

Not played for years but based on the other reviews you can't even play online now so for that reason I'm going to to choose not recommended.

column8: This game is such a massive piece of shit, they took literally everything that was the heart and soul of CNC and turned it into some shitty rock, paper, scissors game. there is so much game design that just doesnt make any sense, whether its the 3 distinct "mobile bases" for each faction, that can only build a third of your unit roster. or maybe the units cards that "level up" the more you use them, leading to an extremely unbalanced multiplayer, or the nonsensical storyline.... everything about this game just feels like a cash grab, it feels rushed, it feels like the development team had so many ideas and orders pulling them in different directions that the end product suffered so badly its absolutely unplayable.

column8:
A mediocre game that takes an approach completely at odds with all other games in the C&C franchise. If this wasn't branded with "Command & Conquer" you'd have no idea that it was meant to be part of the series at all, due to the fall in quality, the completely different gameplay style and the lack of an enjoyable experience.

Save your money for a real C&C game.

column8:
I got this with the C&C pack. I am very happy that I did not waste any extra money on this. I am a casual player or C&C from the first game also Red Alert from the first one. This is not a C&C RTS game, just garbage.

First you need to login to EA servers to play all the time which is absolute madness. After creating user or re-using your origin username, you cannot activate it from steam, it gives error. Workaround is to copy key to origin add it there then you can continue at steam. What a pile crap.

The mobile base seems to  be a change to make this game something else but it locks you on "command point" b-shit, it is not a fun game. Do not waste your precious time with this garbage.

The casual crawler mechanics killed the gameplay. Even the poor acting in cutscenes isn't a welcome detail in a well-designed game. It's more like icing on a cake of dashed hopes. Truly, this is a dark page in the history of the C&C series. I don't recommend it.

But before launching, I had to enter my Origin password three times, which sometimes doesn't save, and it's impossible to activate it through Steam. It was as if they were telling me: don't mess with it, it's bad! But I did. 0/10

column9:
Cons: 1. The plot is weak, especially the ending (yes, there are several, but essentially, they're the same). The characters are pathetic. Even Kane was ruined, in my opinion. Although Joe Kukan still plays great. I'll never forget Kane from the previous games. 2. The game isn't worth the money. I'm ready to pay 999 rubles for Red Alert 3, but for such a short, and one might even say, hastily made game, 1k is too much. 3. Dead multiplayer (either because of the servers or because of the dead online, I don't know). 4. Devaluation of units and buildings. Previously, you valued units and buildings because you spent a lot of money on them. This greatly impacted the dynamics of the game in a positive way. Now they removed this. You won't care about units at all. They lost them - they made new ones. This completely destroys the variety and dynamism. Why did they do this? It's unclear. (5). Translation. The translation is poor. For example: who the hell came up with the idea to rename GDI to GDI????? For those who don't know, GDI stands for Global Defense Initiative, which can be translated as Global Security Council. And what is GDI? I won't even guess. The voice acting is mediocre; it's clear they didn't try at all. They simply hired the most overused voice actors who simply read the text. Only Kane and the main character's wife are voiced properly. 6. Hacking protection. DRM, constant internet connection, and the need for an EA account. (7). Music. I don't know why, but I didn't like it at all. It feels like Star Wars, not C&C.
() - subjective or specific to a specific version of the game

Pros:
There aren't any, unfortunately.

column9:
Completely different from the third installment. I could accept the population cap and softened art style; StarCraft also has a population cap, and the experience is still great. Red Alert 3 has a cuter art style, but I still liked it. EA just turned it into Company of Heroes 4, completely destroying the fundamental structure of an RTS. If EASB is so powerful, why didn't they just acquire Minesweeper?

The terrible pathfinding and collision detection are still there. A single unit can walk through a group, and the rest of the units will immediately scatter in panic. This is a stark contrast to StarCraft 2, which came out in the same year.

The plot suddenly became mysterious, starting to veer towards mindlessly whitewashing Nod. Few of the mysteries left from the third installment have been solved.

PS: According to some experts, this fourth installment was rushed by EA, who packaged the spin-off Command & Conquer: Arena as a sequel, turning a perfectly good RTS into a chaotic free-for-all. EASB is done for.

column8:
This wasn't just a case of trying something aggressive and risky and having it fail in flames. This was abject disregard and disrespect for the consumer base. 

The best thing I can say about this game is that when it came out we thought EA had hit a low point. We were so naive. The rabbit hole turned into an inter-dimensional wormhole. 

If you're considering paying money for this atrocity in some 2020 COVID-19 sale, chances are it's not your money.

column8:
Command and Conquer 4 was a bad game when it first came out and it's still a bad game after all these years.

A little backstory behind the game, this was going to be a standalone game set in its own universe that's completely separate from the Command and Conquer universe. Early on during the project, the brilliant executives at EA thought they would make more money from the game if they slapped the Command and Conquer logo on it and based it within the Tiberian universe. So the devs were pretty much forced to turn a game that was never intended to be a Command and Conquer game into Command and Conquer 4. 

The result? An absolute mess. Plays nothing like any of the Command and Conquer games. There's really no economy or base building, it's just mindless unit spamming until you win. I completed the GDI and Nod campaigns and then immediately uninstalled -- never to play again. The story is terrible, by the way.

column8:
Playing Command & Conquer 4 makes me wonder why they didn't make Command & Conquer 4. 
This is not a Command & Conquer game.
This is a capture the flag game with tanks.
Is it possible that the people who made this had even played the previous games?
If it weren't for GDI and Nod themed cutscenes, it would be completely unrecognizable.

column8: Well The gameplay system is a bit disappointing. Like the old way, where theres no limit to how mnay army we can produce

Personally this has ruined the the franchise. Command and Conquer in name only. Personally its been some time since I played it. I lasted maybe the first 3 levels, quit game, without saving, then completely uninstalled it. Though unfortunately it still shows in my library and I regret it to this day for the money I threw away  for a game I waited so long for. And with the addition of an, apologies,   bullshit and totally unwanted/unnecessary mobile game, it seems to me CnC will turn into a pathetic money grab And as a fan for over 20 years, I'm not only disappointed but sickened by the pathetic attempt this game was to rekindle the franchise while totally ruining what could have been a fantastic addition. Alas, my fellow fans to the series. Perhaps in time, Kane shall rise again, and we get the Epic RPG we deserve with today's technology. Until then, 

ONE VISION, ONE PURPOSE. 
My brothers and sister.

it's a nice game with new RTS idea.
it has nice graphics , story and game play .
the only thing I'd say isn't good is that you start this game with a lower capabilities , I suggest you play it VS bots until you get ranks , and KEEP BACKUPS FOR IT'S FILES on another disk or on backup cloud/server to avoid losing the ranks you get.

have fun.

column8:
I've played this game twice, once alone and once with a squad of friends and enjoyed both
-Big open world with tons of weapons and different types of compounds and military bases that you can plan and approach as you see fit.
-Story is not that fresh but decent
-Sync shot is probably my favorite feature in this game.
-Overall enjoyable

column8:
This game is not ike the others. I grew up playing CNC, Starting with Generals and Zero Hour. eventually going back to play the 2D CNC Games. They all have the same basic way to play, Build a base, Defend and push. 

CNC 4 is more a Class Rush Strategy then a Real RTS. There is no base building. You drop the MCV build units from it and then send those units and the MCV to attack. thats it

Sure you can argue that you gotta finish the Kane Arch. No. watch someone else suffer through it or look up lore. cause playing it for the story is not worth it.

Go back, Play CNC 3 TB and KW. Heck even go play Generals or RA2 on ORIGIN. But do not BUY THIS GAME

column9: If you accidentally purchased this game, you'll encounter several problems. First, account registration: My solution is to use Internet Explorer to open the official website and register; otherwise, the website won't open. Second, the serial number must be used to activate the game on the official website where you registered. The website has an "Add Game" option to add and activate the game. Activating the game on Steam will result in an error; you must activate it through the official website.

column9:
No wonder it's receiving so many negative reviews.

It's lost the feel of C&C. The gameplay is different, fine, but please, don't make it look so cheap! The menu looks like an indie game. It's so annoying. The other actors are subpar. The videos look like they were made by an amateur YouTuber. The graphics are much worse than C&C3. Every combat unit has a colored circle; it's ugly. The controls aren't as smooth as C&C3.

Many people say they can't enter serial numbers. After Googling, I found out you have to go to the EA website's account page to enter them correctly:

https://myaccount.ea.com/cp-ui/redemption/index

Since it's so troublesome, why not put the input method on the store page?

column9:
This is undoubtedly the worst game in the C&C series. Even Joseph Kukan (aka Kane) couldn't save this gameplay disaster with his acting. However, in 2014, I bought a copy of this game from a store. I finished it entirely. Despite the game's low rating, I did enjoy it to some extent. You can talk a lot about how EA are jerks, doing everything possible to dump the game, which naturally turned into Halo Wars. But even this dump, which can hardly be called a PC RTS, remains a fond memory for me.

But EA wouldn't be EA if they didn't screw up even the Steam release. When pre-ordering the game, everyone who pre-ordered had access to the NOD mission "Night Moves," where, under Gideon's leadership, they had to hijack three transports and then destroy GDI crawlers. So, that's the year 2019, when I purchased the game. I bought the game with my own money, and this mission is NOT there. It's been 9 years since the game's release. SO WHY THE HELL WAS IT ON A PIRATED FILM FOR 150 RUBLES, AND IN THE LICENSED VERSION, 9 FUCKING YEARS LATER, YOU HAVEN'T GAVE EVERYONE ACCESS TO THIS MISSION???? WHAT THE HELL??? This was one of my favorite missions, plus it gave a maximum of 4k experience, which was an additional leveling. And now it's simply gone. Beauties.

column8:
As a long-time C&C fan, this game almost made me angry. It's not fun. The single player is terrible. I just...I can't even.

All of the other games were fun. We all have different opinions on Red Alert 3, Tiberian Sun, and all the others, but they were all fun. Why couldn't this one end a good, traditional franchise with something that the fans would like?

I'm sad this is the end of the road for Command & Conquer. The story was better in my head back when I was 16.

column9:
If you encounter any issues running the game, please see here:

1. EA account required

2. Activation via Origin is required (in-game activation will result in an error) (the "General Error")

https://myaccount.ea.com/cp-ui/redemption/index

Once completed, you can play normally. Arena of the Tortoise is essentially a buy-to-play MMO like R6S

(No need to download Origin)

Honestly, Arena of the Tortoise isn't as bad as you might think.

[b]1. Graphics: 7.5/10[/b] Many people are criticizing the graphics, saying it's worse than CC3 and uses the cartoon style of RA3. This is true; the RA series has always leaned towards "political jokes" and "dark humor," so many people can accept the cartoon style. However, the main CC series, from the first game onwards, has always aimed for a more rigorous worldview, making this style look a bit awkward. Of course, I don't think the graphics are all bad. The models in this generation are more futuristic, and they look cool, that's all that matters. [strike]However, the units require a lot of grinding, which is annoying.[/strike] Secondly, at least CC4 doesn't have too much light pollution (the shield brightness is acceptable; if I had to say, the Firehawk airstrike is quite bright, but RA3's yellow faction color makes it feel like you're going to go blind). The unit details are also okay, but only to a passable degree (the Titan turning into cat ears after eating a blue core is quite cute). Personally, I think overall it's just passable, not as bad as some people say.

[b]2. Gameplay: 5.5/10[/b] To say it's boring is a bit of a stretch, but you'll always find yourself playing it for no reason. As for saying it's fun, I honestly can't find anything enjoyable about it. How do you play it? It's very simple.

You can choose to be either aggressive or passive, and select your turtle type: ground turtles (attack & defense) and flying turtles (support). Ground turtles are further divided into four-legged turtles and tracked turtles. Your ultimate goal is to capture turtle nests on the map to score points. Of course, you can also be more aggressive and take down the enemy's turtles.

Sometimes, players will throw carrots onto the field. You can send your units to collect the carrots and bring them back to your turtle beach, which will give you upgrade points to make your turtles stronger.

Seriously, let's talk about the major changes in this generation:

1. GDI and Nod can no longer be mixed. If you choose the GDI faction, your entire team must consist of GDI units.

2. No more sneaky farming; dual-technology is no longer possible.

3. All production buildings are now concentrated on the MCV (Multi-Channel Vehicle); they are no longer built separately.

4. Some units have been changed, such as the Bulldog changing from anti-armor to anti-light units, and the Venom changing from anti-infantry to anti-medium aircraft.

5. The familiar population cap has been removed, and there's no economy. The only resource gathering method is stealing Tienite to upgrade (the game's guidance is poor; you only gain points after transporting Tienite back to your own colored grid-like terrain base).

These are the main points; it's said that this will likely continue until next year in the game. I can't really judge whether it's fun or not. First, the game's damage output is surprisingly low (this could be improved in skirmishes), especially laser damage against infantry, which is incredibly weak. Countermeasures are very rigid, almost like a game of rock-paper-scissors. Of course, if you're just playing for fun, you can still use basic attacks. Artillery damage is decent against light and medium armor, and even heavy armor is somewhat manageable (though you might get a little bit of a setback). If you don't care about anti-air, just go for Hunters and Avengers. This rigidity is the first major drawback.

Second, EA advertised that this installment has the most toys, provided you're willing to grind. Skirmishes are inefficient, and you'll definitely be at a disadvantage in campaigns due to incomplete technology. Soloing a campaign will somewhat ruin the story experience. Of course, you can gain experience in online mode, but while there are players, finding a match is a nightmare.

However, don't worry too much. As long as you follow the story, your available armaments are enough to complete the game. You don't need to deliberately grind to max level. Even so, it's still annoying to not be able to use certain units.

Third, I don't know if this is a flaw, but I initially thought that the absence of resource gathering and construction would make this installment easier, but it turns out it's actually harder. Firstly, because of this rigid system of checks and balances, team composition and unit coordination become extremely important. Secondly, you need to capture multiple objectives; multitasking is essential.

This also represents the game's high barrier to entry. Those with RTS or RTT experience will be fine, but newbies will be almost guaranteed to give up.

It might seem okay at first, but it gets boring after completion.

Oh, and by the way, I originally intended to read the credits out of basic respect for the developers, but not only were the visuals repetitive, but the credits were also looping.

Before getting to the third point, a quick aside: since this is CNC (Completely Incompetent) content, how could we forget to criticize EASB?

The game's original title was... Command & Conquer: Arena, a spin-off MMO, was developed by EA due to their dissatisfaction with the EALA development team's inefficiency. EA demanded a mainline Command & Conquer game to cash in, but with insufficient time (reportedly less than a year), development was impossible. Therefore, Arena was repackaged as Tiberian Twilight.

Many signs of rushed development are visible in CC4, and I'll discuss the later plot briefly.

But the biggest mistake was releasing an RTT (real-time strategy) game when you knew only die-hard fans would play it as a concluding title.

P.S. The game's balance is poor, and the rigid controls mean that even if you go all out and bring along a few incompetent AI, it's difficult to turn the tide. The points you gain from conquering nodes with all your might might not even equal the points your AI teammates lose by sending several Mammoths to their deaths and wreckage in the enemy's base.

3. Story: 5/10

The following plot contains spoilers.

Finally, we've reached the most important part, one of the souls of the Critical Ops series, and also the biggest flaw of the Arena of Valor. Please don't criticize the following analysis if you disagree.

First, the biggest retcon is that Eggplant (the AI) is nowhere to be seen. He promised to take revenge on humanity, but we haven't even seen a shadow of him.

King: Earth's stinking little brothers, I'm here! Eat my Golden Fleet!

Eggplant AI: Connecting to server Earth. Confirm?

King: Confirmed, hurry up!

Eggplant AI: Unable to connect to EA server. Please check if your network cable is unplugged.

King: F*** you! Silk Scarf Technology is the best in the world! Who do you think you are?

Eggplant AI: Connection timed out, returning to base.

King: ??? ? ?

Besides this, there are still other unexplained bugs, such as the fact that yellow and blue zones no longer exist worldwide, and even GDI headquarters was inexplicably contaminated by Tiberium (Zocom: touched). The only remaining controllable contaminated zone is Paris (I wonder who dares to criticize France today.jpg). However, I've also come up with some personal thoughts, and I hope everyone can actively correct or supplement them.

1. Is GDI the biggest villain? Does CC4 whitewash Nod?

Personally, I don't think so. GDI's subjective goal was to completely purify the planet, while Nod's goal was to assist Kane in achieving "ascension." Looking at the final outcome, it's actually a win-win situation, except that [b]GDI's victory is built on Nod's victory[/b]. Whitewashing isn't really accurate. CC doesn't have the clear-cut good and evil concepts found in traditional Western action movies. GDI doesn't necessarily represent justice, and Nod doesn't necessarily represent evil, but honestly, I feel the Nod ending in the Turtle Arena is the more authentic ending.

2. What are the relationships between the various factions in the game? There are roughly four factions in the game: [b]the GDI Council led by Leos, the GDI Radicals under James, the Nod Orthodox faction under Kane, and the Nod Separatists affiliated with Gideon[/b]. Brotherhood 13 and 24 are cooperative.

An interesting point is that the Brotherhood has always had traitors in every generation; it's practically a tradition. As for Gideon's betrayal and his obstruction of Kane's ascension plan, the official explanation seems vague (in retconned comics, Gideon was even orchestrated by Kane).

Another possibility is that Gideon was dissatisfied with Kane's changes to the ascension plan.

The Nod's initial belief was to use Tiberium to terraform the Earth for evolution (as seen in Command & Conquer 2, which may ultimately lead to the Tiberiumization of the world, culminating in Kane's ascension), but later Kane changed his concept of ascension to "leaving Earth." Gideon might have been an early supporter of the beliefs, perhaps feeling that while they had worked hard to build the cause, Gideon was thinking of running away, making him the true traitor who had betrayed all Nod followers. He would naturally have had reason to incite a large number of members to support his separatism and relentlessly sabotage the Ascension Plan.

Of course, it's also possible that EASB simply didn't bother writing the plot and retconned the source material.

On the GDI side, James's radical actions leaned more towards personal revenge, as her two children were killed by the Scrins during the Third Tiberian War, and she believed Kane was the instigator (which is true). Meanwhile, in his cooperation with GDI, Kane only informed the higher-ups that his ascension would completely eliminate Tiberium; the rest of the officials were kept in the dark. James believed Kane opened the portal to lure the Scrin people back to Earth, triggering a new war. The previous incident had already left James with a deep-seated fear, slowly driving her to madness. Driven by unwavering conviction, she was solely focused on erasing Kane from Earth.

3. Regarding the person who helped the protagonist escape in GDI's fifth mission:

There's no official explanation for this. The mysterious operator, Dukat, seems to have disappeared after that mission. So who is he? What is his purpose?

There's a casual remark: "An important person needs you to leave."

It's quite obvious; he's highly likely Kane's messenger. Why?

Dr. Pascal, the last TCN implant recipient besides the protagonist, is murdered. However, TCN activation is urgent, and Kane must ensure the protagonist's survivalâ€”the only one capable of operating the TCNâ€”to achieve his goals.

At the start of the game, the protagonist is told, "You need support, now," followed by an airdrop of a GDI infantry squad, not Nod's, indicating this person wields some power within GDI (Chicken: There's a mole, terminate the deal). Further information seems difficult to uncover. EASB is truly cunning; they've made a linear story incredibly confusing, requiring piecing together clues and deduction. Of course, it's possible this was intentional (CC4's development cycle was significantly shortened, perhaps EALA did this to reduce workload).

That's all for now. I'll add more later if I think of anything else.

In short, CC4, as the final installment, definitely lacks plot tension. The battles of the previous game, almost a matter of planetary survival, became small-scale conflicts in this one, and it retconned a lot. But since it's the official final game, we can't deny it. To be honest, it's watchable, although very disappointing.

By the way, the story in this game is surprisingly short.

P.S. Although the plot is weak, it was actually cut by EA. For example, the Nod route actually had its own beginning instead of inheriting the GDI branch, etc.

4. Music: 9/10 The music in this game is excellent, but unfortunately, the soundtrack was ruined by a bunch of bad teammates. However, I don't recommend listening to it on platforms like NetEase Cloud Music before playing. First, the music on those platforms is almost incomplete, and second, the CC4 music only really feels right when played with the game. However, when you first play Nod, you might feel a bit like you're watching GLA, since both are mainly female chanting with a strong religious feel. After playing more, you'll find it even more impactful than GLA.

In short, if I were to give an overall score, it would be: Graphics (10%), Gameplay (50%), Story (30%), Music (10%)

(It's not fair to say they treated it differently, considering RA3 is another example.) (This game isn't primarily story-driven, so its story score is relatively low, whereas in the main Clash Royale series, the story is the soul, hence its higher weight.) For longtime Clash Royale fans, this final score of 5.9 is fitting. However, for those unfamiliar with the series, the actual gameplay experience is much higher than that number, and it's quite enjoyable. It's not that fans are being picky, but rather that this game doesn't deserve a 4.

Additionally: It seems Clash Royale 4 really likes hiding General's Easter eggs, such as the "MiG Fighter" achievement for the Light Bomber and the "Crusader" achievement for the Paladin.

Don't be fooled by all the reviews saying the product key doesn't work. You simply need to register the key through the EA website instead of the game client. And you can easily get the key by right clicking the game in your library, going to MANAGE, and then CD KEYS. The following link is to redeem it.

https://myaccount.ea.com/cp-ui/redemption/index

Game works fine. Quality of the game is a different story entirely, or lack there of. Not recommended for die hard C&C players.

Ne reprend quasiment aucune des mÃ©caniques propres Ã  un C&C, possÃ¨de une limitation d'unitÃ©s trÃ¨s basse pour cacher les dÃ©fauts techniques du jeu, est graphiquement en dessous de C&C3, possÃ¨de une campagne trÃ¨s courte Ã  la difficultÃ© mal dosÃ©e, a mis en place une mÃ©canique pÃ©nalisant grandement les nouveaux joueurs, surtout en multi et y compris contre l'IA, a dÃ©truit le charisme de Kane, tente d'introduire des mÃ©caniques intelligentes mais mal exploitÃ©es, n'a qu'un seul acteur jouant correctement lors des cinÃ©matiques (spoiler : Kane, et encore, pas tout le temps), plante rÃ©guliÃ¨rement, possÃ¨de l'un des pathfinding les plus horribles des STR (mÃªme PA est au dessus), ne possÃ¨de quasiment pas d'IA sur ses unitÃ©s, dont la moitiÃ© ne servent pas et bordel, quelle fin de merde ! MÃªme Mass Effect 3 fait mieux.
Bref, ne l'achetez pas, ne pensez mÃªme pas Ã  acheter, Ã©vitez-le, si vous avez l'occasion d'y jouer, jouez Ã  autre chose, vous gagnerez du temps, sauf si vous voulez vous forger votre propre opinion et que vous avez un cÃ´tÃ© masochiste.
column9:
It barely incorporates any of the mechanics typical of a C&C game, has a very low unit limit to hide the game's technical flaws, is graphically inferior to C&C3, has a very short campaign with poorly balanced difficulty, has implemented a mechanic that severely penalizes new players, especially in multiplayer and even against AI, has destroyed Kane's charisma, attempts to introduce clever but poorly implemented mechanics, has only one actor who performs well in cutscenes (spoiler: Kane, and even then, not always), crashes regularly, has one of the worst pathfinding systems in any RTS (even PA is worse), has virtually no AI for its units, half of which are useless, and damn, what a terrible ending! Even Mass Effect 3 does better.

In short, don't buy it, don't even think about buying it, avoid it; if you have the opportunity to play it, play something else, you'll save time, unless you want to form your own opinion and you have a masochistic side.

column8:
Tiberian Twilight was terrible in 2010 and it's still terrible in 2020.

First off, you have to create an EA account to do anything. Then once you've made an account, you have to copy the CD key steam gives you, log into EA's website, enter the CD key, THEN log into the game launcher at which point you have to accept the EULA before the game starts. On top of that, you need a constant internet connection due to the game's awful DRM. What a mess.

The game itself somehow looks worse than its predecessors. The units have a strange simplistic blocky look to them and I can't say the UI is much better. Everything just feels off and oversimplified in comparison to the earlier games like Tiberium Wars and Kane's Wrath. What a mess.

Meanwhile the gameplay is somewhere between mediocre and infuriating. Unlike the previous Command and Conquer games, for some inexplicable reason, EA decided that it would be a good idea to forgo base building in a franchise known entirely for it's base building. Gone are the days of building multiple factories, upgrade buildings, and tiberium refineries. Instead you get a mobile crawler than can unpack into a factory and build a handful of units and maybe a turret or two. No longer do you need to worry about guarding your crystal-filled harvesters from the enemy. Instead you just play capture-the-crystal with a couple units and sit on a capture point with your crawler. What a mess.

God, I hate this game. I really do. I can't believe I bought it in 2010 - on a physical disc too. The only reason why I own it now is because it came in a bundle.

Oh yeah, and the game is locked to 30fps.

What a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing mess.

column9:
I bought the whole series on sale, just to satisfy my nostalgia. As a RTS fan, how bad could it get? I've never played a difficult RTS!

After playing: It's utter garbage.

First, you need to register an account, okay, that's basic these days.

After registering, I started playing, entered the serial numberâ€”it's an official game, after allâ€”STEAM copied it for me with one click. After confirming the copy... a general error...? ??

Maybe I messed something up and had to start overâ€”I had to re-enter my account and password! That means I have to enter my account and password every time I enter the game! The serial number just wouldn't work; after searching online, I found out I had to redeem it online.

That's not all. Playing single-player mode requires a constant internet connection. I frequently disconnect, and even after I've finished a level, I can't proceed to the next level or even get the current rewards. I can only continue at some auto-save point. So I have to re-enter my account and password, confirm my game name, and enter the game again. It's like playing single-player mode and getting a rollback...

The most fatal flaw is the game content. It's no longer about real-time strategyâ€”collecting resources, developing troops, and building units. Instead, you're given a command center and you just press the button to order the troops. Technology development is just research in the command center. There's no concept of money; besides the command center, you only have 50 units. And each unit doesn't even have a population of 1. You can't build many troops at once. Tactics? Since troops are free, I'll just build more; there's no concept of casualties. Trading 50 tanks for one enemy soldier isn't a loss, right? What kind of game is this? The controls are terrible too. Aside from the special effects, the atmosphere and gameplay are worse than 2. Is this a refund? The money didn't even go to WW (World War II).

column9:
The game didn't work for me at first, and the code wasn't accepted.

If you're having the same problem, do the following:

1. Download the EA Launcher Origin

2. Log in to your account or register

3. Go to Games - Add a Game

4. Paste the Steam code there (with dashes)

5. The Origin Launcher will then try to download the game, but since you already downloaded it via Steam, you don't need to do that again.

6. Start the game, log in with your credentials, and add a name.

7. The game will start.

This also works for Red Alert 3.

I hope this works for you, and if this has already been mentioned somewhere, here it is again :)

Have fun playing! :D

Unfortunately, I have to give this game a bad rating despite it being a C&C game.

The plot is great and I loved it, but the gameplay mechanics are uglier than Diego Maradona in his underwear. Very few units, no economic system, the combat is as tough as Diego Maradona visiting the Casa Rosada (the presidential palace), but above all, the online system is completely neglected...

A shame for a series that brought us more joy than Diego Maradona.

PS: Starting the game can cause serious problems because the launcher malfunctions when creating an account.

column8:
I loved Command and Conquer 3 + Kanes Wrath. I loved Command and Conquer Generals. I loved Red Alert 2 and 3. 

It's why it hurts me so much to say I absolutely hate this game. I hate what this game represents, it was an attempt to try something new by EA, it failed and then the shareholders a EA screamed and said "IT DIDNT MAKE MONEY DONT DO IT AGAIN".  And then we never got another Command and Conquer game...
The failure of this game permanently damaged and scarred command and conquer series.
The cutscenes are awful, not cheesy like the previous games but solid cringe, i struggled to sit through them. The female "wife" character is incredibly painful to bear witness too. And the gameplay....o boy. Removing base building from a command and conquer game?  REALLY EA? REALLY?

Vote with your wallet. Do not purchase this game. Go and buy Command and Conquer 3 or Kanes Wrath instead. You will have an amazingly better time.

Don't be fooled by all the reviews saying the product key doesn't work. You simply need to register the key through the EA website instead of the game client. And you can easily get the key by right clicking the game in your library, going to MANAGE, and then CD KEYS. The following link is to redeem it.

https://myaccount.ea.com/cp-ui/redemption/index

Game works fine. Quality of the game is a different story entirely, or lack there of. Not recommended for die hard C&C players.

column8:
Well I thought I'd try this game out even though I'd basically written it off as soon as I saw the gameplay and graphics in the run up to its release, plus just about every review is so negative.

In summary, its trash, this is a complete waste of time and money and should be written off, cemented into a wall somewhere and forgotten about.

You have to have an internet connection and EA account to even play the single player mode, simply annoying and I do have an account.

The graphics are laughable, when ever you highlight a unit it gives it a big green border so all the edge details are completely hidden, who's bright idea was that one :-)

The game play is just not C&C anymore either, which is the probably the worst part, no resource gathering or other nice RTS type features, just a quick command points based shoot up.

Even bigger disappointment is that they have taken on-board some of the cool mods out there for tib wars, integrated them and completely ruined them in the process, great job guys, great job!

column8:
First off: you can get the game to work, the solution is by going to EA.com and register the key you get from steam. 

But why bother? This game is an unmitigated disaster even if you don't compare it with the previous titles. 
It's boring, slow and the new mechanics don't work. Even the music is terrible. The story is a travesty and it shows that they weren't bothered to invest in stuff like costumes and sets. The final chapter of the Tiberian saga makes the ending of Mass effect look like Citizen Kane (no pun intended). 

This was a very cynical move by EA to release this as a full C&C title while its obvious that it was designed as a moba-esque online only version which was shoehorned to be a sequel. 

I feel sorry for Joe Kuckan (actor of Kane) that this is his final contribution. He deserved better. 

The Tiberium fps that looked very promising (especially lore wise)  was canceled because EA told us that it didn't meet their "quality standards"  Then they had the nerve to release this garbage?! What a joke.

column8:
Meh. As a huge fan of CnC. This is a worst CnC I ever play.
Although CnC 4 brought back some units from Tiberian Sun: Firestorm, but removing harvesting resources is a worst decision.

On the other hand, the story is a mess. What I thought was EA tried to rush to launch the CnC 4 asap, but it turned out a terrible series.

If any player wants to know the ending of Tiberium story, I prefer you to watch the YouTube walkthrough. 
Not worth the price to get it.

column8:
Este C&C Tiberian es de lo peor, practicamente mando a la basura la magia de un C&C y creo algo que es una porqueria. Los puntos buenos se quedan opacados por estos graves errores.
Pros:
- Graficos "geniales"
- Unidades de anteriores sagas.
- wow eso es todo.

Contras:
- Estilo de juego que olvida todo lo que es un C&C.
- Una historia que es muy "ligera" nada que ver con las otras de C&C
- La necesidad de elegir un solo estilo de juego (tal vez para una partida multijugador esta bien pero C&C se caracterizaba de que podias creear tu base, defender la y atacar. En este toma todo y lo envia a la basura.)

In the time that I've seen all of the C&C games up to this point, most of them were pretty good, the original to probably Red Alert 2 and its DLC being the best out of all of them, with Tiberian Sun Firestorm being my favorite, as I grew up with it and Red Alert 2.

The balls on EA to make such a terrible game truly and thoroughly irks me. This game is, with no due respect, genuine trash, the story is hardly comprehensible, the ending makes no sense, and the gameplay, especially skirmishes, are a total pain to even look at after the other games. I could have seen the game going in several different directions by halfway through the campaign, and none of them came close to what actually happened. IF EA, IF you do make another C&C game, make a beta, consult the PLAYERS of the OG games, recieve feedback and constructive criticism, and do what they say, players like myself have experienced the best, and now the worst, of these games can say with dignity, honesty, and frankness can say that this game is garbage, and we need a new, better one like the old days. Like literally just remake Tiberian Sun into an HD version and you'll make millions. I promise you.

column8:
The end of the Tiberium Saga...

Bland, Generic, and Terrible. The gameplay feels almost MOBA-like. Great for MOBA fans, and terrible for RTS fans.

It's lack of Base-Building and a Campaign that not even Kane can save makes this a terrible C&C entry in general.

Only EVER play this game if it's free. Other than that? Leave it out. Go buy C&C 3 and the excellent expansion, Kane's Wrath!

column8:
When Steam abandons it's customers

Avoid this game, at all cost because I couldn't get it to work after several attempts. my main frustrations point towards Steam as a content provider, after numerous emails to them for support explaining that I just can't get this game to work because the registration code provided just doesn't work. Steam in their infinite wisdom lay the blame on the customer. Furthermore Steam customer service team if i can call it that is absolutely abysmal towards loyal customers.

The cost of the game is almost insignificant when compared to the general cost of games, however the principle remains the same, if  a purchased item albeit software isn't working surely the decent thing to do would be to support your customer so they can continue to enjoy and enhance their experience?

For the more establish gamer's out there, you may not gain much benefit from this warning, however the newcomers may and should be informed of the underhanded methods Steam use to get your money while avoiding the true purpose which is to help resolving issues as and when they arise.

This is not only the worse C&C game I had the displeasure to waste money on this is one of the worst RTS games overall. The only reason people should own this is if they got the whole collection on a sale. If you are looking for a good C&C game either play C&C 1, Tiberium  Sun,Red Alert 1 and Yuri's revenge for free on CnCNet or buy Red Alert 3 and Tiberium Wars,trust me you will have a better time with those games. Oh also as an added "Fuck you" from EA you need to make an Origin account to play this game and it need's online connection all the time.

Absolute trainwreak.  Want a RTS?  Want what every RTS should have?  Well you arent getting it here.  NO base building.  NO unlocking all the units and tech in one run.  NO being able to counter everything.  This game has for some reason base building removed and instead replaced with mobile basically carriers that build your units.  Sounds like the newer Homeworld game right?  Wrong.  Homeworld does it right.  This game has three different type of units you choose at the start(air, ground, or sea(i believe dont remember completely due to it being so forgettable)).  And your mobile carrierer builder, tech tree, and abilities are centered around that concept the entire match and no changing.  This gets -10k stars in my oppion for being such a horrid RTS.

column8:
Just because something is different doesn't mean it's bad. 

That being said, this is bad. The cinematics are bad, and the camera work is shakey. The units have very little detail considering the games that came before. It looks like it's trying to be a kids' cartoon. 

The plot is corny, but all C&C's are so that's fine. 

What kills me the most is how CHEAP everything feels. This has a very "tiny developer trying (and failing) to punch avove its weight. I cannot express how cheap everything feels. 100% AVOID, unless it's to complete a collection...maybe? This game is terrible. 

If you want to compare this to other C&Cs... oh boy. It's even worse. Uninstalling by the 3rd mission.

column8:
10/10
Game Review No. 33
Game: 
Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight
...
About & Plot: 
This is the end to the Tiberium canon universe, Kane and Tiberium leave together, but before that happens you must help either GDI or NOD to get the outcome, the outcome is the same no matter who you side with, really, and there's no bonus nor hidden ending from what I can tell nor find either,
...
Story & Spoilers:
Tiberium has evolved and is spreading at such a rate that the whole planet is expected to become uninhabitable by 2068. Humanity is on the brink of extinction. The player takes the role of Commander Parker, a GDI military officer who receives an optical implant after his battle wounds have caused him to lose his eyesight. The player is presented with the possibility to aid either Colonel Louise James's GDI extremists or Kane's Nod Loyalist forces in the Fourth Tiberium War. After the final battle for the Threshold 19, Kane is about to leave Earth using the Scrin tower. He convinces Commander Parker (the player) to activate it for him with the optical implant. The player is shot by Colonel James but nonetheless succeeds in activating the portal. In both campaigns, Kane enters the portal. In the ending cut-scene, news channels announce that the Tiberium growth has receded following the complete activation of Tiberium Control Network and all the Nod followers have entered the Scrin tower and disappeared. Kane and Nod are no more and Tiberium follows suit slowly, thus closing the book to the Saga.
...
Strategy, Gameplay, Mechanics and Statistics:
The time to take you to beat both campaigns is mmm 3-18 hours depends on how you go about doing it, and highest level is level 20 (GDI) level 20 (NOD) so Max is level 40 witch can take you 3-8+ hours grinding, the best way to grind in skirmishes is medium vs brutal with you on the brutal side and trying to speedrun to 4000 points in the best shortest replay moves, if you play average or are a casual person it can take you 3-5 hours to Max both sides, if you are a pro or an expert at game mechanics or very enthusiastic in "speedrunning to Lv40" it can take 1-4 hours and playing the story at max can take 2-5 hours to beat both campaigns so if you tried or wanted you could be New to completing the whole game in under 6-12 hours.
...
The Good and Pro:
-RPG RTS
-5v5 w/A.I
-Short Story
-End to a Saga
-Awesome Music
-No Bugs
...
The Bad and Cons:
-Original intentions for online only
-Adding story and campaign to the game last in development
-Required EA account
-Required one time use access key for the pc
-Requires to be signed in in order to play
-No extra content or hidden content for 100% in the game
-No reward for beating or completing the game
-Both campaign endings are exact with no differences.
-A poorly shoehorn motivation involving your wife
-Cutscenes and Gameplay in campaign refers your wife to get you motivated and have purpose but you're only introduced to her for existing and being like "this is your wife" and then dying immediately soon after and is an annoying reminder that's shes a shoe horn into the plot to motivate the player making the story seemed rushed when shes brought up especially how they do it in GDI campaign
...
...
...
CONCLUSION:
I recommend this game, finish and end a book that's just the Tiberium series, the Final Chapter to the Canon Tiberium universe, to have a short game you can complete it in 1-3 days or in 6-12 hours, just ignore the existence of your wife when she is brought up for motivational plot convenience and you have a very nice endgame pages to look at, its got great music, there is no extra stuff for 100% it so you can get it to cross off your list so you don't have to come back to it ever if you don't want to.

column8: è™½ç„¶å„æ–¹é¢ä¸åŠå‰ä½œï¼Œä½†ç©è¿˜æ˜¯æŒºå¥½ç©çš„

Do you like base building?  Then this isn't the game for you.
Do you enjoy collecting tons of resources and feeling rich?  Then you're in for a big disappointment. 
Do you love building a massive, unstoppable army and crushing the enemy beneath your boot?  Too bad.
Do you think there would at least be an epic story rich with lore building on the decade plus of previous C&C games?  HAHAHAHAHA.

Command and Conquer defined an entire genre of games and personally was a huge part of my childhood, but this flaming sack of garbage manages to remove virtually every good feature and replace them with cancerous, fetid lumps of absolute trash.  I knew it wouldn't be good, it's been out long enough and I've seen the reviews, but I felt obligated as a fan to play it eventually.  I even played through the first three again just to refresh my memory and get me psyched up for the end, but it only enhanced the pain.  If you attempt the same, which I don't recommend, here's about how it will go.  First you'll tear your hair out just trying to install the thing and get it running with the atrocious DRM and mandatory online login. Then if you want to play the campaign you'll quickly realize they completely retconned the end of C&C 3 because they wanted to put it at the end of this pitiful excuse for a game instead, which it won't take you long to reach because both NOD and GDI combined can be completed in less time than it takes for Kane to wax his head in the morning.  Don't even attempt multiplayer. 

EA has committed a lot of sins, but the brutal rape, murder, and dismemberment of the Command and Conquer franchise is, in my mind at least, their most heinous.

I liked this game when it came out in 2012 because I was a kid. After years if you think about it it is not good tiberian but it could be good game if it has different name. What I cannot stand is optiomalization and missing self keyboard managment and also keyboard does not work unless it is windowed. Grafics looks pretty nice, models are garbage but it could be playable if it was fixed which is not even now... Buy on your own risk and remember that this is not "Tiberian".

column8:
This game has faulty and over the top DRM that made it impossible for me to play the game.
First i required me to create an EA account and login into it before launching the game itself (which I did successfuly) but then when already in-game immediately informed me that I was disconnected, any attempt to login back in was met with instant failure for as long as the game is running.
This is especially painful since I am only interested in single player mode but some genius decided that without active internet connection you cannot even get to the start menu.

Don't waste your money on something that may not work because the publisher is happy to screw the legal owners of the game with their broken DRM.

If you are looking for a Command & Conquer game then go get your C&C 3 Tiberium Wars cds out of your closet and reinstall the old game...this one is not worth your money / time! 
No base building at all, thats about all you need to know and to avoid this title which totally broke with the great C&C history!

0/10

very sad indeed
