column8:
My review is based on my personal experiences and with the background of having played and enjoyed Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars right before purchasing this game. It is to be said that this game and its dynamics, even the approach to it all, differ fundementally from the previous installment. The game is rather based on having mobile bases, not only encouraging of establishing only temporary bases, but even forcing you to hastly settle down only to for the most urgent actions and to move on in a giant caravan of units and your mobile command/construction building in order to survive. In the sense that [spoilers!] the planet is a Tiberian wasteland invaded by an Alien species in this installment, it gives off this nomadic post-apocalyptic feeling, which might be quite matching but hurt the gameplay experience in my opinion. Everything feels less permanent, rather like an action-packed campaign mission where your goal is not to build up a base and start offensives from there, but to utilize the little you have to outsmart your (in this case, also) mobile enemy.
I personally love building up a base and having the responsibility of using terrains to defend its chokepoints and entrances. I was surprised and rather disappointed after playing the third installment just before this one. The graphics are less realistic and although this might have been the intention of the developers to return to the 'semi-comic'-feel, it felt sloppy and like being let down after CnC 3: Tiberium Wars.

column8:
Make sure you come in to this with some background reaserch under your belt, This is nothing like the command and conquer franchise you have played before. admitidlly they have tried something new but it hasnt worked. to much has been taken away from the core gameplay of a real time stratagy to make it worth your time.
Always online DRM
No base building
No rersource managment
Low unit cap
No tactical advantage to any units
its boring repetitive and wont make you thing the way this genre of game is supposed to. if I could give it back I would
here is my opinion - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7eKPHBPnBXY

column8:
It is not often that I am disappointed and depressed by a video game but unfortunately C&C4 has got to be one of the most awful games I have ever had the misfortune to have played.  Before I start the criticism of the game, I feel that it would be fair to mention the one redeeming feature because there is only one and that is Joe Kucan reprising his role as Kane, about the only thing satisfying for a long time fan of the series such as myself.  Now on to the downsides.

1. The complete lack of base building and resource gathering.  How you can even label this game as an RTS without these core elements is beyond me, instead of the staples of the RTS genre, units cost a certain amount of "Command Points" and that's it.  No tiberium, nothing to be gathered or collected or used tactically, just a limit placed on you at the start of the game and boom click a button, create units up to the limit and that's it, that's the extent of resources in the game.  And as for base building, much the same applies, you have a power limit so you place down a certain number of defensive turrets up to the limit and that's really all there is to it - on both fronts a complete lack of anything in-depth, evidence of a second rate game aimed at a minor market being shoe-horned into something much bigger than it actually is intended to be.

2. The units/maps/graphics.  The units provided at the start of the game are weak and ineffectual so in order to obtain more units you level up and then unlock them which sounds like a fairly simple concept, that is until you realise that exp. for leveling up is difficult to come by.  The lack of exp. becomes apparent after still not being awarded any after completion of the third mission in the story meaning that in order to progress your tech, hours of play time is required to unlock even just mostly mid-range units.  The weakness of initial units isn't alleviated by the fact that you can make large numbers as the Command Point limit applies so you are restricted to small squads of units, not the massive armies you expect from an RTS game.  To go with the theme of a small number of units, the maps which battles are conducted on are best summed up as tiny, cramped arenas with very little room for manouvere meaning it's goodbye to any tactical thinking and hello to comabt which feels scripted and unintelligent.  As if the unit/map situation was not already bad enough, this steaming mass of disappointment is served up in a graphical style more akin to a comic book setting, gone is the sleek, futuristic, powerful look of C&C3, it is instead replaced by  out of place, chunky, Megablocks style units, which completly destroys any sort of serious mood the game intends to create.  The graphical style of C&C4's units is so far removed from C&C3's that they're not even in the same universe, nevermind the same page.

3. The story.  It's fairly obvious that the story is terrible from pretty much the word go as one of the first scenes has you, as commander, greeted by your wife.  Yep, that's right, your wife because that's just what an RTS story needs, a bullshit love interest forced into the game.  From then on the story goes rapidly downhill, not aided by the dire acting of all those involved (with the exception of Joe Kucan) and then ends with the equivalent of "And they all rode off into the sunset and lived happily ever after."  Seriously? After having fought now at this time 4 Tiberium Wars, having battled across the globe and faced all manner of foes whilst still wondering about the mystery of Nod and Kane and what the ultimate goal could be, it ends with "Kane and all of Nod travel through the alien tower and leave GDI behind on a tiberium-free Earth having left them peacefully".  I have to wonder what it is with EA and their amazing ability to consistently screw up epic storylines and disappoint faithful fans of a beloved genre because that ending is just utter horseshit and reeks of a rushed writing crew being forced to pull something out of their asses.

So to conclude, C&C4 fails to deliver on all fronts: from dreadful mechanics and weak units, to poor acting and a storyline that could arugably have been concieved by a 5 year old, C&C4 smacks of poor quality, despiration and coporate greed.  A truly disappointing end to a great series, something that should not have come to pass.  I cannot urge you strongly enough, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

Oh and one last thing... EA please if you would kindly go fuck yourselves bloody with a rusty sword that would be greatly appreiciated, you cunts.
column9:

The units provided at the start of the game are weak and ineffectual so in order to obtain more units you level up and then unlock them which sounds like a fairly simple concept, that is until you realise that exp. for leveling up is difficult to come by.  The lack of exp. becomes apparent after still not being awarded any after completion of the third mission in the story meaning that in order to progress your tech, hours of play time is required to unlock even just mostly mid-range units.  The weakness of initial units isn't alleviated by the fact that you can make large numbers as the Command Point limit applies so you are restricted to small squads of units, not the massive armies you expect from an RTS game.  To go with the theme of a small number of units, the maps which battles are conducted on are best summed up as tiny, cramped arenas with very little room for manouvere meaning it's goodbye to any tactical thinking and hello to comabt which feels scripted and unintelligent.  As if the unit/map situation was not already bad enough, this steaming mass of disappointment is served up in a graphical style more akin to a comic book setting, gone is the sleek, futuristic, powerful look of C&C3, it is instead replaced by  out of place, chunky, Megablocks style units, which completly destroys any sort of serious mood the game intends to create.  The graphical style of C&C4's units is so far removed from C&C3's that they're not even in the same universe, nevermind the same page.

3. The story.  It's fairly obvious that the story is terrible from pretty much the word go as one of the first scenes has you, as commander, greeted by your wife.  Yep, that's right, your wife because that's just what an RTS story needs, a bullshit love interest forced into the game.  From then on the story goes rapidly downhill, not aided by the dire acting of all those involved (with the exception of Joe Kucan) and then ends with the equivalent of "And they all rode off into the sunset and lived happily ever after."  Seriously? After having fought now at this time 4 Tiberium Wars, having battled across the globe and faced all manner of foes whilst still wondering about the mystery of Nod and Kane and what the ultimate goal could be, it ends with "Kane and all of Nod travel through the alien tower and leave GDI behind on a tiberium-free Earth having left them peacefully".  I have to wonder what it is with EA and their amazing ability to consistently screw up epic storylines and disappoint faithful fans of a beloved genre because that ending is just utter horseshit and reeks of a rushed writing crew being forced to pull something out of their asses.

So to conclude, C&C4 fails to deliver on all fronts: from dreadful mechanics and weak units, to poor acting and a storyline that could arugably have been concieved by a 5 year old, C&C4 smacks of poor quality, despiration and coporate greed.  A truly disappointing end to a great series, something that should not have come to pass.  I cannot urge you strongly enough, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

Oh and one last thing... EA please if you would kindly go fuck yourselves bloody with a rusty sword that would be greatly appreiciated, you cunts.

column8:
I do not like writing negative reviews but sometimes it has to be done I guess.
If you know your C&C games, one of the first things that will come to mind is usually building a base. Unfortunately this game does not really have it. In my eyes, it just doesn't quite stand up to any other C&C game. Though I didn't put too many hours into it so maybe I didn't give it a good enough chance?

Put simply, this would have been a much better game if the name "Command and Conquer" was not part of its title. Since it is not like the other games in its series, it isn't what people expect to get when they pay.

column8:
Behold disciples of Nod, for the end is soon upon us. Electronic Artsâ€™ award-winning and best-selling Tiberium saga is coming to a powerful conclusion with Command & Conquer 4, which will introduce a multitude of innovations to the classic fast and fluid Command & Conquer gameplay, while retaining the core compulsions that fans have come to love over the seriesâ€™ history.

It is the year 2062 and humanity is at the brink of extinction. Tiberium, the mysterious, alien crystalline structure that has infested Earth for decades and served as the primary reason for years of relentless conflict between the Global Defense Initiative (GDI) and the Brotherhood of Nod, is close to rendering the planet uninhabitable. Mankind is on the verge of extinction when Kane, Nodâ€™s prophetic leader, emerges from seclusion to deliver GDI the message that he has developed a system that could control Tiberium and harness its power. But he cannot build this "Tiberium Control Network" without GDIâ€™s cooperation. Thus, the two opposing factions â€“ GDI and Nod â€“ inevitably find themselves in desperation for the same cause: to stop Tiberium from extinguishing mankind.

After 15 years, the network is nearly complete, Tiberium is under strict control and our revitalized, newly terraformed planet is on the cusp of a new age of prosperity and progress. It is then that the worldâ€™s citizens begin to seriously ponder why Kane chose to help, and what will he want in return. These questions and more lead to the dramatic final act of the Tiberium saga.

With a multitude of innovative new features to the fast and fluid C&C gameplay, Command & Conquer 4 offers players an entirely new way to play C&C. An all-in-one mobile base, persistent player progression across all game modes that is constantly updated in a real-time online profile, a 3-class system for each of the two factions, co-operative play, and a 5v5 objective-based multiplayer mode that promotes teamwork and social interaction, make Command & Conquer 4 unlike any other C&C experience.

Behold disciples of Nod, for the end is soon upon us. Electronic Artsâ€™ award-winning and best-selling Tiberium saga is coming to a powerful conclusion with Command & Conquer 4, which will introduce a multitude of innovations to the classic fast and fluid Command & Conquer gameplay, while retaining the core compulsions that fans have come to love over the seriesâ€™ history.

It is the year 2062 and humanity is at the brink of extinction. Tiberium, the mysterious, alien crystalline structure that has infested Earth for decades and served as the primary reason for years of relentless conflict between the Global Defense Initiative (GDI) and the Brotherhood of Nod, is close to rendering the planet uninhabitable. Mankind is on the verge of extinction when Kane, Nodâ€™s prophetic leader, emerges from seclusion to deliver GDI the message that he has developed a system that could control Tiberium and harness its power. But he cannot build this "Tiberium Control Network" without GDIâ€™s cooperation. Thus, the two opposing factions â€“ GDI and Nod â€“ inevitably find themselves in desperation for the same cause: to stop Tiberium from extinguishing mankind.

After 15 years, the network is nearly complete, Tiberium is under strict control and our revitalized, newly terraformed planet is on the cusp of a new age of prosperity and progress. It is then that the worldâ€™s citizens begin to seriously ponder why Kane chose to help, and what will he want in return. These questions and more lead to the dramatic final act of the Tiberium saga.

With a multitude of innovative new features to the fast and fluid C&C gameplay, Command & Conquer 4 offers players an entirely new way to play C&C. An all-in-one mobile base, persistent player progression across all game modes that is constantly updated in a real-time online profile, a 3-class system for each of the two factions, co-operative play, and a 5v5 objective-based multiplayer mode that promotes teamwork and social interaction, make Command & Conquer 4 unlike any other C&C experience.

column8:
I have so many mixed emotions about this game.

One of my biggest beefs with this game is that it's just plain short.  There are only 7 GDI missions,  7 NOD missions, and 3 common missions.  I finished it all in 14 hours.  Not much room in there for story.  The story they did have, and the cutscenes, seem very low budget and thrown together.  No Hollywood actors this time around.  The final cutscene in each campaign is literally the actors standing in front of a white sheet with a drawn picture.  If they had doubled the number of missions, I would be recommending this game.  It seems like they're trying to bring a lot of focus onto multiplayer, but I'm only interested in the single player aspect.

One thing that took a little while to get used to is that they changed the gameplay style.  Previous C&C games have had the formula of building/defending/expanding a base, managing your economy and power, and trying to push out as many units as you can.  In this game, you have a fixed number of points that can be redeemed for units, another set of points for structures, and third set for skill upgrades and expanding your tech tree.  There are no power plants, harvesters, etc.  And if a unit is killed or a structure is lost, you get your points refunded, and can build it again.  A key strategy is to continually move your MCV forward, towards the goal.  This makes most of the maps very linear.  Once you can get past the dramatic difference in play style, the game actually gets enjoyable.  Though some of the time, it just feels like you're filling up your build queue so you can spam the enemy.

With the new all-in-one MCV style, they added something that I thought was not well executed.  Instead of just one kind of MCV, they now have three:  offensive, defensive, and support.  Offensive is mostly for making units.  Defensive is for setting up structures like cannons and bunkers.  Support was totally useless to me, as it's for making repairs and setting up airstrikes.  The reason why this wasn't well executed is that you could only have one MCV at a time.  So you can't be defending a structure and attacking the enemy's MCV at the same time.

another terrible rendition of what was an awesome game. i dont think there has been good one in a long time. retalition was defo the best one for me. Generals was not bad either. holding command posts, and unit caps that are far to law cripple this game. just a couple of missions in where you have to ensure the safety of a civ convoy, although one or two slip through until completion of the level, the entire thing feels like a losing battle until you "win" all because of an overwhelming amount of enemy units against your measly 10 units. i miss the days of having massive armies of tanks and men. unit caps has ruined these games for me.

column8: WARNING WARNING WARNING WARNING. If you have actually played ANY Command & Conquer game in the past, this is a WARNING to you. This game is completely different from any other Command & Conquer game. If you played any other C&C and you enjoyed the way it flowed, loved the way it played, and loved the concept, you most likely will not like this game at all. This game 100% resembles an old mobile game that was only on phones that had a SLIDING KEYBOARD. Think about that. THIS GAME IS BASICALLY JUST A PORT FROM A MOBILE GAME FROM SLIDING KEYBOARD PHONES. And how do i know that this is true? Because i had one of those phones and i bought the mobile game. even for $4.99, the mobile game wasn't worth it. i only slightly enjoyed it because i literally had NOTHING BETTER TO DO, and you can believe me when i say that i am a die hard C&C fan and lover. Ive played every single C&C game to date, and for once, this is a C&C game i regretted playing and wasting $20 on. So i will repeat. DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME UNLESS YOU ARE 200% OPEN MINDED TO SHITTY IDEAS. THIS GAME IS COMPLETE AND UTTER CRAP. DO NOT BUY.

column8:
This game is just a grind.  You have to work to permanently unlock things that you would generally unlock and upgrade every game in previous installments of the game, so if you play online you're guarenteed to get steamrolled by someone who has played longer.

The game offers different spawn ships that only allow certain units to be built with each and are supposed to follow certain playstyles but ultimately just end up limiting the game and the amount of fun it could have offered.

I love the C&C series, but this game has had some horrible decisions go into it.  If you want an RTS, I'd reccomend picking up either C&C Tiberium Wars 3: Kane's Wrath, or C&C Red Alert 3, as both are top notch games from the same series, and infinitely better than this waste of code.

column8: Let's go kick some scrin butt! What? They're not in this one?! Why in the world would you introduce a new race and then the next game just steal it away?! Okay, Pros and Cons. Pros: Nothing. Cons: Everything. Believe me when I say this game is complete.. er.. poop. It completely takes away the drain based economy that everyone loves and replaced it with unit population and too rare tiberium crystals for upgrades. You cannot construct buildings unless you choose the defender MCV. That's another thing! Different MCVs, and multiple lives for them! Well, I hope some people agree with me, bye.

column8:
Rinnovare un gioco porta quasi sempre dei benefici, ma anche molti rischi.
Farlo in una saga cosÃ¬ importante e nel suo capitolo conclusivo, inoltre, non Ã¨ stata la scelta vincente.
Togliere completamente la gestione della costruzione della base ed eliminare la raccolta delle risorse in favore di un maggior dinamismo, poteva essere un buon punto di partenza, ma visto il risultato troppo approssimativo, questo quarto capitolo farÃ  storcere il naso anche ai fan meno incalliti.
In Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight l'attenzione del giocatore non Ã¨ piÃ¹ rivolta verso la fortificazione di un luogo sicuro da cui far partire i propri attacchi, ma viene diretta verso la gestione di poche unitÃ  e di una base mobile andando cosÃ¬ a cambiare radicalmente il modo di giocare rispetto al passato.
Il fatto di non doversi piÃ¹ preoccupare di perdere la propria base principale ha portato pesanti modifiche anche nel sistema del gioco online lasciando cosÃ¬ spazio a modalitÃ  piÃ¹ vicine alla freneticitÃ  degli sparatutto piuttosto che agli strategici, portando cosÃ¬ il giocatore a lanciarsi negli scontri con il proprio arsenale spianato, anzichÃ© a ragionare e attendere il momento giusto per evitare di vanificare i preziosi momenti passati ad accumulare risorse e soldati come avveniva in passato.
Per fortuna non tutto Ã¨ andato perduto; i video di intermezzo mantengono il carisma che da sempre caratterizza la saga del tiberium e la storia vi stupirÃ  con diversi colpi di scena.
Interessante anche il fatto di poter giocare la campagna in modalitÃ  cooperativa nonostante questa sia di scarsa durata. Discorso a sÃ© per il multiplayer che a causa dei livelli di esperienza e di alcune combinazioni di unitÃ  aeree dei GDI inarrestabili, si rivela unâ€™esperienza online troppo sbilanciata.
In conclusione questo era un prodotto con le potenzialitÃ  per divenire un must, se solo si fosse limitato a essere Command & Conquer e non un titolo che ne mantiene solo il nome sulla copertina ma che ne modifica profondamente lo stile di gioco, non ottenendo i risultati desiderati

column8:
I can only recommend this if your a true fan of the sries and want to see the last of the Tiberium Saga.  While its not a bad game in its own right it defies a lot of typical conventions that C&C has had since its inception in 1995.    

However if we forget that this is a C&C game and judge it on its own merits.  I'll say this, first its a fast paced game and unlike  previous C&C games it requires you to think about using your units right as each unit now has a strength/weakness mechanic more so in this title.

Graphics wise its visual fideltiy is pretty impressive for an RTS game and even though the ammount of units you can have is limited the battles do in fact feel big, which is a plus.  

As this is a C&C game you can expect well acted real time cutscenes and these are the most impressive I'vse seen so far.

Now for problems.  

One of the major issues is that players can level up outside multiplayer and then take that rank/level into multiplayer, meaning there's no sense of progression and someonne can just anhilate you in multiplayer because you've not unlocked all the units/upgrades.

Bottom line this can be a fun title if you can forget it has anything to do with Command and Conquer, but it also appeals to true fans.  Generic RTS fans may want to avoid this title.  Which is the only reason I can recommend this title.

Shocking that this can even be called a Command & Conquer game. I heard about how bad it was, but decided to buy it since it was on sale for $5. It is atrocious. All the base building aspects are gone, instead you are given a "crawler" which you can set up and produce certain units and structures/abilities depending on if you chose offense, defense or support. I only suggest buying this if you hated previous C&C games since this is the complete opposite of past games. I plan on finishing the campaign, on easy to get it done with faster, and to never play it again.

EDIT: You may enjoy the game if you liked World in Conflict's multiplayer aspect. The whole game plays like it, where you are forced to pick a strategy and stick with it. However, it is more limited because in World in Conflict you could still make most units, however in this game you are forced to only make what your strategy allows. There is no overlap at all.

column8: A disgrace to the C&C series. Do not buy it! Even if they offer if for a free weekend, the price is too high for its worth. What made this game so crappy? The gameplay, the story, and the idea of taking away the concept of base building and resource gathering. Every fan knows the story of GDI vs NOD. GDI's purpose is to contain the Tiberium and stop NOD from using it as a tool. NOD wants the tiberium to claim it as the next step in human evolution while informing the world that GDI are a bunch of fascists that care for the rich and abandon the sick and poor. BUT C&C4 throws that all away when Kane uses the Tacitus, the item that the 2 factions fought so hard to obtain and unlock the secrets of it, to ally with GDI and destroy the Tiberium that infested the earth. I bought it because i love C&C from the start of playing red alert. After Westwood was gone, it all went down the drain. C&C3 was good, but aliens?! blah! I would have loved to see CABAL come back, but EA made up for it with Kane's Wrath. But this...this is like a giant middle finger to all the C&C fans from EA.

column8: what is the code pls

The first... IDK.. Dozen or so games were great.  Red Alert was the first game I ever played all the way through as a kid.  Once upon a time C&C was selling a first decade collection, those are all great games.  But the franchise lost something in the last... well since RA2, whenever that was, that was the first C&C I got bored with before the end.  And this one... Trying to turn it into some sort of mmo hybrid?  Why does every game have to me open to be played with the world now, needing help from strangers to make progress?  I suppose this game could be fun to play as a LAN party, but I don't see any other way to make this game remotely fun.

My first C&C game was tiberian sun. With that I followed the C&C series closely and have played every single one ever made including the ones that were on console. This...this is the worst C&C to ever be created in the history of mankind. all the years following the story, all the years of playing, all the years that I put into this game and waiting to finally see the ending chapter to the Tiberium wars, And this is what we get? EA has taken the game and twisted into something so horrible that words are incapable of ever describing the disust I feel.

This isn't a C&C game. This is utter garbage and other words so foul that they don't even exist. There are no words that exist that can describe how utterly putrid this "thing" they call a game is. Do not buy this. Under any circumstances, do not buy this. Do not even pirate this game. It is a waste of your life and you will thank me later.

column8: This game really makes me sad just knowing that with most other games only get better and better while this one actually managed to go backwards. The AI is pathetic, the story doesnt really seem to fit along with all of the other tiberium related Command & Conquer games, and dont forget about the DRM on this game to, the game has you unlock units by leveling up, no you cant go to skirmish and have access to all units, you have to play a metric crap ton of skirmish and the campaign to unlock all the units, and even then you can only use a third at a time due to the fact you have to pick one of the three types of "Crawlers". This game is so terrible it almost isnt worth writing the review for it.

column8: As a long time fan of the series, I have to say that this is the most disappointing game in the series. Sure the unit are very creative and the soundtrack are awesome but those are the only bright spots in this game. Otherwise, the story is confusing and seemed to be rushed, the unit cap is frustrating, and the resource gathering system is both alien and laborious. IMAO, this game will never touch Red Alert 3's level..unless it is returned to the RTS roots that made hte series famous Keep the level of technology, I love it.
column9: As a long time fan of the series, I have to say that this is the most disappointing game in the series. Sure the unit are very creative and the soundtrack are awesome but those are the only bright spots in this game. Otherwise, the story is confusing and seemed to be rushed, the unit cap is frustrating, and the resource gathering system is both alien and laborious. IMAO, this game will never touch Red Alert 3's level..unless it is returned to the RTS roots that made hte series famous Keep the level of technology, I love it.

column8: good

I tried really hard to like this game, as it's the final C&C game that it looks like we're getting in a long time - could even be the last the way EA is heading with their BS. This game shows a fantastic idea, a fantastic concept, something that could have worked out great - IF IT DIDN'T HAVE THE LABEL AS A FULL ON SEQUEL TO THE TIBERIUM UNIVERSE C&C GAMES. As a spinoff, this game would have been mediocre, but as the official sequel and ending to the C&C storyline, this game is abysmal in every way possible.

Not a single thing feels C&C about this game - theres a tiny population cap, there's no base building, there's no resource collection, maps are small, the campaign is abysmal with a terrible storyline and cutscenes that don't just look bad - they are legitimately stuff someone likely recorded with their iphone camera and slapped into the game! Just watch any sections that involve the "public" speaking rather than paid actors. The only saving grace in the storyline is Joe Kucan, who as always takes the role of Kane and makes an extremely badass villain until a terrible ending that's the same regardless of which faction you go with - AN ENDING THAT'S THE SAME REGARDLESS OF WHICH FACTION YOU GO WITH. Let that sink in.

The progression system is terrible - yes, there's a progression system. This game revolves around collecting tiberium crystals INDIVIDUALLY and using them to upgrade your MCV to higher tiers to unlock better units and such. However, when you start, you are level 1 and have access to absolutely NOTHING. Only after you level up several times will you unlock the 2nd tier of technology which at first is completely worthless without a single thing used for it. Everything has to be unlocked through progression and this BLATANTLY makes anyone who's a higher level than you stronger than you with no workarounds based on how good of a player you are or anything, PERIOD. For example, you have to pick a class - offensive, defensive, or support. If you go defensive, at the beginning of the progression scale you only have access to 3 infantry units. No vehicles of any sort, period. While these infantry units CAN be used to counter other infantry, vehicles, or aircraft, they're all infantry and can be MUCH MORE EASILY COUNTERED by a diverse enemy army.

This is a game that again, has a fantastic concept that was soiled by something that clearly had the goal of being made with the least amount of funding possible, the least motivation possible, and the smallest amount of time necessary to produce it - probably so EA wouldn't have to pay people to work on this game any longer than they would have to before it was BARELY functional as a game and could be pushed out the door, which is exactly what they did.

And what sucks is, if everyone is maximum level on progression, the multiplayer can actually potentially be fun. It feels like the game was designed for that, but it was just unfinished, so to pad the length of the game and make people play it longer, they slapped progression in to make you grind to be level 20 (the cap).

Do not buy this game. If you want a good C&C game from recent times, go with Red Alert 3. Just don't expect any multiplayer options since this is the ONLY C&C GAME to not run on Gamespy and the gamespy servers are going to tank here in a month.

As a fan of the original Tiberian Sun C&C game I expected this remake to be at least as good as the original.  It is TERRIBLE!!!!  The fun in C&C games, because they seem not to have understood it,  is to be able to build strong defenses and large bases, outposts and a solid economy ?!? With the machanics of this version, it is absolutly IMPOSSIBLE to accomplish, at all!!!  This thing with the crystals to gain access to slight advantages absolutly sucks.  You need to play many hours before gaining access to 50% of the units available using only boring to play and weak mech_infantry units.  From my point of view, they would rather keep the unit layouts and apply the game mechanics of the provious version...  At least it would be playable.  What a rubbish!!!  DO NOT BUY THAT, unless 1-2$, very frustrating game!!!

column8:
Words cannot describe how much this game is terrible.

I could forgive the All-in-One base thing they were doing with the Crawlers because the Concept was cool, but THIS is not how to do it. It would've worked with World in Conflict if they made a Futuristic Sequel...and if it had better controls.
I wish that it was C&C 3 that ended the Tiberium Saga, That was how it was intended at first...then EA's Unquenchable Greed fucked it in the ass without lube.

But, its EA, What do you expect. I am surprised that this game did not come with a DLC that allows you to have better units, units that would be essential to win the game and units that you'd HAVE to have in order to win the game.

Ich empfehle euch das spiel NICHT zu kaufen! 

Die VorgÃ¤nger von C&C waren um einiges besser. EA scheint wohl nur noch schnell Geld verdienen zu wollen. Nach einer Anmeldung in Origin (wobei das sehr unverstÃ¤ndlich fÃ¼r mich ist da das Spiel in Steam ausreichend geschÃ¼tzt ist) bin ich dann ins Game gekommen.

So misserable war noch kein anderes C&C. Mit nur einer Spielmodi (Herrschaft) wird es schnell langweilig. 

Wer Wert auf groÃŸe Schlachten und langes SpielvergnÃ¼gen setzt sollte dieses Game meiden!

Eins vorweg: Ich spiele C&C seit 1995, habe jeden Teil mehrfach durchgespielt, auch auf den hÃ¶chsten Schwierigkeitsstufen und diverse Online und Lan Matches hinter mir. Kenne mich dementsprechend mit der Materie aus.

Kurzfassung

Ja, man kann das Spiel, wenn man es wie ich im Angebot kauft durchweg spielen, sollte es jedoch NICHT zu C&C zÃ¤hlen, dann macht das Spiel durchaus SpaÃŸ, auf wenn man egal mit welchem Crawler, einer mobilen Einheit die Ã¤hnlich der mobilen Waffenfabrik von Tiberian Sun ist, man eigentlich nur vor die gegnerische Basis fÃ¤hrt und den Gegner mit Einheiten totwirft.

Langfassung

Kampagne: Neben dem, schnellen und recht lustigen Multiplayer ist die Kampagne ja das eigentliche Augenmerk, leider wurde hier viel verÃ¤ndert. Der Spielcharakter ist mal wieder namenlos, hat diesmal eine Ehefrau in den Cutscenes die ebenfalls nicht mehr die Klasse anderer Teile erreichen. Die Charaktere sind, zumindest fÃ¼r mich unbekannt, flach, Ã¼berspitzt kitschig und mit fÃ¼r mich unbekannten Schauspielern besetzt. Storyline mehr als flach, aber ich will hier nicht spoilern.

Grafik

UngefÃ¤hr auf hÃ¶he von Tiberium Wars, somit immer noch die GenerÃ¤le Engine, die trotzdem irgendwie "eckig" wirkt in sachen Einheitenbewegung und Crawlerplatzierung, Ã¤hnlich Alarmstufe Rot 3.

Sound

Durchaus okay, bekannte Sprecher, EVA von der gleichen Person gesprochen wie in Tiberium Wars. Leider fehlt knackiges GeschÃ¼tzfeuer.

In eigener Sache

Leider wurde mal wieder einiges geÃ¤ndert, abgesehen vom Crawlersystem. C&C 4 sollte eigentlich ein Onlinespiel nur fÃ¼r den Asiatischen Raum sein und somit Starcraft ebenbÃ¼rtig werden. Die Kampagne kam erst im nachhinein, das erklÃ¤rt viele LogiklÃ¼cken. Die typischen C&C Waffen wurden durch realistische wie z.B. P90 in Cutscenes geÃ¤ndert, die HintergrÃ¼nde sind nur blinkende ComputerwÃ¤nde, Ã¤hnlich Carters Versuchslabor bei Stargate SG1. Die GDI Uniformen wurden ebenfalls gegen realistische Uniformen getauscht. Zwar haben beide Seiten wieder SciFi Einheiten wie man es in der Zukunft auch erwartet, doch komsicherweise haben alle Leute scheinbar einen totalblackout, da scheinbar keiner mehr weiÃŸ das Schallwaffen Tiberiumkristalle zerstÃ¶ren. Die Liste geht noch um einige Punkte weiter, aber ich denke man versteht was ich sagen will.

Fazit

Nettes Skirmish/Multiplayerspiel, mit Online und EA Registrierungszwang, aber 0 Storyline. Ironischerweise sind die Entwickler teilweise jÃ¼nger als ich selbst, vielleicht liegt bei der u20 Generation die akzeptanz fÃ¼r Action statt Story hÃ¶her.

7,5 von 10 Punkten

Terrible. Absolutely the worst C&C game ever made, without a doubt, I don't know how EA could make C&C 3 so incredibly amazing and then do a couplete U-turn and make this. This may well be the worst game I have ever had the misfortune to play. I paid under Â£5 for this and it was still too much. I feel like EA should be paying us to play this.
The "always-online" that EA has a big hard-on for lately is a nightmare.
The only reason I bought this was to concluce the CnC tiberium storyline and even that was terrible. Did you know there's no more tiberium in this game? Literally, it's pretty much all gone. No base building, no harvesting resources. You can train units without any cost but only up to a very, very limited unit cap. I'm talking REAL limited. Like you can only train enough units to have a decent attack force or a decent defense force. Not both. I expect that kind of limit on a console RTs but not PC.

DO
NOT
BUY

column8: this is the WORST C&C yet, a HUGE emberassment, the textures and graphics are like EA went back 7 years in graphics (seriously, compare these graphics on maximum to C&C3's graphics, C&C3 had best graphics of the series) you liked your regular Riflemen and Militants? TOO BAD! they're gone and replaced with robots with lasers, adding onto that EVERYTHING HAS LASERS you need internet connection JUST TO PLAY, liked making complete custom bases and liked making other bases around the map? NOPE you get a small circle, I could barely play 20 friggen minutes of the game W/A being utterly disgusted on how the Nod, the GDI, and the ENTIRE GAMEPLAY was BUTCHERED, and if your only buying it for the story etc, you may aswell watch the cutscenes on youtube. Another thing in the story it says Tiberium is EVERYWHEREcomplete BS btw cause on all the maps I BARELY saw any tiberium)  NOT RECOMMENDED

column8:
The only reason to buy a copy of this utter travesty of a game is to burn it. If you're a fan of the Command and Conquer series, if you remember them fondly from your youth, if you've played any other RTS, no matter how bad, all this will do is make you die a little inside. 

One copy needs to be saved to act as a warning from history. An example of things that must never be repeated. I'm sure EA will keep one somewhere. Burn the rest and delete anything digital. Please.

For anybody who loved the older Command and Conquer games: STAY AWAY! Command and Conquer 4 strays so far from the original Command and Conquer formula that it is virtually unrecognizable as a Command and Conquer game. Gone is the base building and resource gathering, replaced with a "mobile crawler" and a rather stifling hard "population cap" as well as a need to gather experience to unlock other units. What Electronic Arts was thinking when they put this one together is beyond me, and while it may have been a good game on its own, it's not a Command and Conquer game.

column8:
Don't listen to the people who say this game sucks. C&C4 is a legitimate step forward in RTS mechanics, distilling the fun of what you used to call "base building" in the game's offense/defense/support crawlers. 

I picked Defense and played through the campaign. Guess what, it's anything but "Defense." If you could call crawling up in the enemy lines, plopping down defense towers and bunkers next to their shit, and letting your therefore heavily shielded infantry tear everyone up, "defense." 

The game shows that there is pretty much no need for RTS games to go through the traditional stages of build-up and then push. In this game, you just push. Or get pushed. All day. Can't take it, well, there's Starcraft for you people who like having to memorize tons of bullshit before actually playing the game.

See, there's a reason why people enjoy games like DOTA-like games. It's because they took the fun parts out of the RTS and put them in a game by itself. Give C&C4 some credit for doing the same thing but for base building, army composition, and micro. In time you guys are going to look at games like C&C4 as the first (though mis-advertised) baby steps toward actual computerized strategy games where it's easy to pick up and play but the strategy is really deep like chess and Go.

column8:
This game killed all that C&C have built up over the years. Thay took all that C&C stand for and trow it away.
No base building, no resource gathering and Scrin whas gone even if i whas not that huge fan of them geting in Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars. But taking out the main core of the game and re-build the game to have walkers making units for you and tiberium nodes and crystals that give you upgrade points. The lvl system for unlocking units and upgrades is not good for a singelplayer or multiplayer.

I do not recommend that anyone buy this game even if thay are a C&C hardcore fans.

column8: This game is everything that is wrong with the C&C series. Ever since the closing of Westwood Studios the entire franchise has been plummeting to it's death brought about by a starvation for innovative game play that remains true to the original series. Tiberian Twilight proves that there are no new good ideas left and C&C needs to be put to bed or have the reigns handed off to someone more responsible. This game ended up being one of the worst RTSs I have ever played and the person who bought it for me felt the need to apologize for the rotten pile of progamming that sits in a place of dishonor amongst my Steam games. Do not buy this and do not play it.

column8: I have been a lifelong CnC fan, but this game really screwed up the formula rather than innovate it. The lack of base building or resource gathering means that the game is just a mad rush to build as may units as possible, throw them at the enemy, and repeat. Only one of the classes can build defenses. the leveling up system means that you are grossly underpowered in multiplayer matches until you grind up to the top. This complelety destroys the balance as you could only have access to tanks while your opponent is using Mastadons. Also, the story and the acting is awful. It's college level bad.

Tiberian Twilight does not deserve the Command & Conquer title. It's a chugging slow C&C wannabe with kindergarten storyline, irritating and clumsy interface, and a huge learning curve even if you've played the series from day 1. Also dont expect to be able to play AT ALL if for some reason you're unable to connect to the internet. 

While C&C3 kept me busy for hundreds of hours, this one made me feel complelled to leave mid mission, before my first hour was up. I'll need to be seriously drunk or delirious to try this one again.

If your looking for the same awesome RTS experience as the previous Command and Conquer Tiberian titles, then do not get this game. Playing this game literally depressed me. I am such a huge fan of the C&C Tiberian franchise and this game is terrible. There is hardly any strategy, no base building, and you don't have to obtain resources anymore!! I have no clue what EA was thinking when they made this game it is so beyond god awful I just don't know how else to describe it. The camping is boring, i find that I pretty much have to force myself to play it. In the other installments of C&C I couldn't leave my computer because it was just so addicting. This game is a disappointment and a waste of money to even the most hard core fans.

To say this is Command and Conquer is a fucking joke, Supreme commander 2 wasn't this dumbed down. Don't even get me started on the ending, if you must watch it look it up on youtube. If you are looking for a mindless unit spamming simulator, this is the game for you.

column8: I disliked - no, hated this game. As a concept it may have worked, but certainly not as a command and conquer game. They took most of what i loved about the other games and tossed it in a blender. No base building, No creation of giant forces, and no tiberium mining. Plus to worsen the game more they threw the story into the blender as well, the story was short, stupid, and made a terrible ending to the tiberium seires of command and conquer. Spoilers - the tiberium just vanishs along with all of nod. Dont buy this game. Just dont.

Fakt ist, man kann sein MBF am besten gleich neben dem Gegner MBF parken ... denn wer das Lotto der Units besser mischt, zerstÃ¶rt das MBF ... aber man kann ja ein neues holen.

Unterm Strich heiÃŸt das:

column8: If you are a C&C fan from the early days, and didn't jump on the band wagon around the release of Red Alert 3, then do not touch this game with a 50ft barge poll. It is the biggest waste of time and the multiplayer is horrifyingly painful to even look at. I love C&C for its base building with very little restriction, the units and the stroyline, this game has none of that. The ending of the story was a disaster as well. If you were like me and were dying to see the end of the Tiberium story line, just watch the GDI and NOD endings on YouTube and you'll save yourself the time and pain of it all.

Pretty much as bad as you have heard. The campaign is a very brief set of 17 missions, 3 tutorial and 7 each for GDI/Nod. The story is on par with a cheesy Sci-fi Channel movie and is largely the same for both factions. Gameplay's not terrible once you get used to it, but it's pretty boring.  The main challenge is the incredibly small unit cap which in turn leads to an incredibly small army. This is exacerbated by the bonus units found on most maps which are counted in the cap and can put you over the cap. So if a crucial unit like the repair Engineer is lost you can wind up in a situation where you have to self-destruct 2 or more units to replace 1 that was destroyed. You also have to "level up" in order to access the higher tier units even in the single player, though in practice most of the bonus units are the powerful tier 3 so this is more inconvenient than anything.
column9: Pretty much as bad as you have heard. The campaign is a very brief set of 17 missions, 3 tutorial and 7 each for GDI/Nod. The story is on par with a cheesy Sci-fi Channel movie and is largely the same for both factions. Gameplay's not terrible once you get used to it, but it's pretty boring.  The main challenge is the incredibly small unit cap which in turn leads to an incredibly small army. This is exacerbated by the bonus units found on most maps which are counted in the cap and can put you over the cap. So if a crucial unit like the repair Engineer is lost you can wind up in a situation where you have to self-destruct 2 or more units to replace 1 that was destroyed. You also have to "level up" in order to access the higher tier units even in the single player, though in practice most of the bonus units are the powerful tier 3 so this is more inconvenient than anything.

column8: Command & Conquer Tiberian series. Possibly the best RTS games ever made. Deep and compelling story, Unique units and factions, Balanced, easy to learn and loads of fun. Very few people can say anything bad about the Tiberian series. Then there is this ball of rot. Looks bad, terrible story, horrible voice acting. Is this even a Command & Conquer game? People used to say C&C Generals was bad. I doubt anything could be as bad as this game. My advice? Don't buy this game, and if it's free....don't even bother taking it. Just say NO.

Do not get this game. It's an awful, terrible, extremely sad neuterization of the C&C series.

Given that you still think you may like it, consider this: In order to actually do anything (multiplayer) you must unlock units. You start with a whopping 3 total uinits: light infantry, light vehicle and tank. All of which are completely worthless if you play against someone who has, for some reason, put time into the game. And that is just scratching the surface of the problems!

Even if this product is on sale for 90% off, avoid it at all costs.

EA screwed up big time on this one. 
They failed the developers who had built an moderately interesting fast-paced RTS game that really had nothing to do with C&C and slapped the brand name on it, hoping it might sell to some hardcore C&C fans. The game itself never got the chance it might have deserved, because it could never be judged on its own merits but always as "The Conclusion to the Tiberium Saga".
They failed the fans of the previous games, because they delivered something that did not understand the value of the gameplay of all the previous titles and threw out time-honored traditions just for the sake of cleaning house.
They even managed to fail the brand itself. If EA has to send out an email that ensures "fans" that they have brought back resource harvesting, removed unit caps and similar basic fundamantals, then it is very clear that the brand itself have lost tremendous value and C&C4 almost solely bears that whole responsibility.
Overall this game fails, not because of what it is, but for what it sets out to be.

a poor rendition of a command and conquer game, and this is coming from a hardcore fan.

the campaign is extremely short, far from engaging and the story line is lacklustre. it lacks the depth of its predecessors and i believe has fallen foul of the trend of many games as of late

they have spent far too much time trying to make it look nice that they have forgotton what C&C is about

i would recommend red alert 2 any day of the week as still being the best command and concquer game

column8: trop pourri le mode de jeu multi

Took over an hour to get the game started, not counting download time. First attempt resulted in computer rebooting during NET.framework installation. Second time involved a 20min wait while NET.framework installed, then half an hour chasing round for account details, the login screen's link led to an endless loop of entering an email and a code, never once saying 'By the way, you already have an account under that email, you're wasting your time.'

Once all these hoops have been jumped through to the games satisfaction, navigating a somewhat awkward setup menu to start a simple 1v1 skirmish with the ai, to get accustomed to the game. It would seem by default a section of the HUD is missing, map for instance is cut off at about 2/3, only showing the middle and right third. Also lack of a menu button, unless mapped to something suitably awkward, or possibly on the cut off section of the display made exiting to alter settings very awkward.

A ctrl+alt+delete, 5 end task and 1 terminate process later, we come to the third attempt, resulting in entire system locking up and the plug being pulled.

Net result, I want a refund, but terms and conditions state that's not going to happen, so here's to a waste of money.

column8:
My overall rating 4 out of 5 stars

Honestly i don't understand why this game got such bad reviews. At no point are you ever forced into multiplayer, like one of the previous reviews said. I've been playing the campaigns and did a few skirmish maps with the AI to level my profile. Which does lead into one partial negative. That being the near necessity of playing one of the campaigns before you start skirmish modes. Apperently the unlocks are tied to yoru profile rank which is persistant in the campaign and skirmish. 

Game play's not really that aweful as some have described. It's more of a elite squad based kind of strategy take on C&C. That may be off putting to some, but you do have a "base building" option with the defense crawler. Just don't expect massive bases like in C&C3. I did find myself useing the offensive crawlers a little bit more than i would have liked.

So the story lines a little anti climactic. Sadly given that it's the end of the series, it would have been near impossible to have actually finished it properly for the majority of the fan base. So i can't fault it for that, though i do find fault in how the cutscenes follow through. It's like there are parts missing. That being said, if you run both campaigns, you'll get alot of the plot holes filled in by the opossite campaign.

I haven't tried multiplayer yet, but when i get a chance, i'll add that review.

column8:
I'd give this game 1/5 stars.

In all fairness, the gameplay is a completely different concept from the previous games. As a concept it's... unique and might have some potential, but they certainly didn't pull it off. If you're looking for a steroidal version of Tiberian Sun and Tiberian Wars, this isn't it. If you're looking for closure to the series, then the end of the storyline is worse than the books following Ender's Game and Ender's Shadow. The story is stupid, the acting is worse, and more immature and childish than Red Alert. Do you really want to know how this series ends? Fine, here it is: Kane makes peace with GDI for free, and in both the GDI and NOD campaigns you are protecting Kane on his quest to cross the portal to join the aliens. The end. Horrible game, total waste of time and money, horrible end to an otherwise great story.

column8:
An utter abomination of a game that only earns the right to use the C&C logo because of the live action story involving Joe Kucan as Kane.  Seriously, C&C4 completely abandons every core element of what made the Command and Conquer identity in the first place.  #1) Battles take place more in arena venues than true story dictated maps.  #2) Your unit count is so small that you can forget building an army #3) You cannot build base fortresses and your production capabilities are easily lost and recovered meaning you've got nothing important to defend and no ultimate goal in smashing your opponent's key structure. #4) The ingame economy is so simplified and anemic that it removes any remaining strategic decisions so that it becomes impossible to out-produce your opponent. #5) Progress is slow and boring since you must tediously earn experience points in order to unlock better units. #6) The visual language of the unit designs is no longer clear making it very hard to understand why one unit is superior to another, and not only that but all the units are extremely wimpy with little ability to decisevly break through enemy forces.

C&C4 started out as an experimental idea for a cheaply made free-to-play RTS game and was then forcibly upgraded into a C&C game.  The live action story moments are the only thing worth mentioning about this game to anyone with a passing care about the Command Conquer franchise and for that just go to Youtube where you can see it all for free.  

What a terrible, unforgiveable waste of time and resources this game is.

column8:
Fraudulent. A mockery.

This game isn't as bad as they say it is ... it's worse!!! :( Like me, you might think "It's C&C. how bad can it be?" Answer: world-class bad. A complete corruption of the art form by people who don't understand the first thing about what made C&C cool and different from other RTSes, and have ruined the franchise. Highlights: no more concept of "economy" or "base-building"; plodding, ineffectual units; linear "progression" of uninspired unlocks, meanwhile each faction can build fewer units -- not to mention structures -- than ever before; and of course a laughable "story".  C&C has "wives" in it now, did u know?

Overall, it just exudes that particular EA-Games flavor of disgust. $5 I wish I had back, and the bottom line: wherever you may rate this game on the scale from "just plain" bad to "seriously I can't believe how bad it is" bad, your time is most assuredly better spent elsewhere.

Disclaimer: I never met a C&C I didn't like. ( .................... up until RA3 which, questionable as it may be, is still infinitely more playable and "C&C" than /this/ POS.)

column8:
Out of all of the Command & Conquer games I've played, this is the only one I've ever regretted buying. As it's shown through gameplay, it does NOT resemble the traditional build-up-your-base-and-army aspects seen in most of the previous games (Renegades is an FPS game). There's a limit on how much units you can use at one time. It's also not a destroy-the-enemy-base game anymore as it's more like a hold down points of the map type of game.

However, the biggest disappointment I found would be the online portion. First, an internet connection is required at all times even if you're not playing online. Second, because there's a level up system which determines how much you can use (and both factions have separate level progresses), it limits a player's choices within the first hours or days of playing. Lastly, playing online can match people unfairly (players may have considerably large level gaps), leading to games where a new player doesn't have the units a higher level player does, especially powerful ones.

If you're a player who has played CnC games throughout the years, it's likely you'll be disappointed with the change in gameplay mechanics. I really don't think this game is worth playing, but that doesn't exactly mean I'm saying "don't buy it". Buy it if you want, I'm just saying it's not worth it.

column8:
Command and Conquer what happened to you. You used to be the king of RTS. Your cheesy live action cut-scenes were the stuff of legend and we eagerly anticipate your every release.
Now what have you done to yourself? No resources, no armies, no bases? What is this? A shadow of what used to be?
YOU ARE NOT COMPANY OF HEROES!
Why can't you stay the way you used to be? We all loved you and cherished every memory of you? Why do you have to cheapen what we have?
Why? WHY? WHY?!

It is difficult for me to articulate my feelings about Command & Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight. All I really know is, I don't like it.

In some misguided attempt by what I can only assume is an ill-informed marketing department somewhere deep in the bowels of the EA mega structure this installment of the Command & Conquer franchise changes everything about the previous games. They even went so far as to remove the live action cut-scenes that, despite being where B-movie stars go to die, had become a benchmark in the industry.

You no longer build bases or harvest Tiberium, instead you get allocated a number of points that can be spent on units, when a unit die you get your points back and can try a new combination. It takes what used to be a very balanced RTS experience and turns it into an entirely micromanagement experience, and not a terribly good one at that.

This is not unlike what you might see in the later Dawn of War games but where Dawn of War balanced it with RPG elements making each unit seem important here you are just sending mindless, faceless entities towards a bunch of other mindless, faceless entities in the hope of beating the map objective before you mind rots from the monotone boredom.

Command & Conquer might be viewed by many as the classic simple RTS, but it was the one that monopolized the best on that approach and it was the franchise that more than any other made the real time strategy genre a force to be reckoned with.

Now it is nothing more a boring mediocre clone of a game, trying to do with all the other cool new RTS's are doing but not doing it nearly as well and losing what made the game special in the first place in the attempt.

It is a sad end for what was once such a proud franchise. The older Command & Conquer games will forever hold a special place in my heart but this makes me hope the series will die before another abomination is released.

Build expansive bases and construct your limitless fortress of fantastic in this epic sequel? No? TRUE fans of the series will not be disappointed.

One of the games where every match feels different to the last. Implements a really revolutionary new building mechanic that's truly unparalled in the RTS universe of today . If you thought RTS was good when you COULD build bases...You're wrong...

Buy it now otherwise your life will possess a Command and Conquer 4 shaped whole that only drugs and meaningless sex could fill...And we all know which option we would prefer.

column8: Command and Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight (C&C4) is the lackluster follow up and conclusion to the beloved Tiberium storyline of the Command and Conquer series. While crucial for story-enthused players, C&C4 breaks up the traditional base building and attempts to create a rank-based multiplayer game. The constant mobility leaves you feeling that every mission is a commando-based offshoot and fails to satisfy classic real-time strategy fans. The ranked multiplayer makes most matches feel unbalanced, but  there are opportunities for co-op gameplay. All in all, C&C4 leaves much to be desired in every aspect, but the game still holds the conclusion to the series.

column8: The C&C franchise has always had quality games but they really dropped the ball on this installment. As the last game in the Kane saga, you would expect the story to be the best out of all the previous games. Unfortunately, the story is extremely short, confusing, and just plain boring at times. The game mechanics has also gone through a complete overhaul, but this change is not for the better. The gameplay is just too simple now that they've taken away building structures, resource mining, and the removal of some staple units. The new interface will probably throw off a lot of old C&C players as well. The biggest issue for me was with the balance of the game. You can build any unit extremely fast and since resources are gone, you aren't punished that much for losing all your forces. The only thing that made the game bearable was the co-op. Other than that, this game deviates too far from the series and I'd only recommend getting it for cheap and if you want to see how it all ends.

column8:
In this sci-fi baldpunk RTS, you play as Commander Married to Giant Forehead: The Woman. After getting your eyes replaced with plot devices, you must decide between siding with Kain, Grand Poobah of the Brotherhood of Mod, many of them have been lead astray by such evils as skyrim JRPG mods. However, Commander Crazy Black Lady refuses to see the good MOD can bring to humanity so she kills your wife after you agree to side with her to ensure your loyalty.

So after you fail to pay your phone bill so you can't call your homies at PDA to tell them to stop shooting, you kill them and then regardless of whichever path you take, Commodore Baldington says "F*** this shit, I'm going into space" and then he goes into Space, the end.

column8:
I'll be honest here, I've not played this game much. I spent maybe five minutes in a skirmish game then quit; it does not stay true to the original Command & Conquer games, which is why I've not given it much time. Basebuilding is minimal and there's something about capturing points alike Company of Heroes, World in Conflict or Dawn of War 2, who all seem to have done it better than this game.

Though, as I said, I'm being honest when I say I've not played this; if you see it cheap and want to complete your C&C collection, then you'll be no worse than me. How much time you spend actually playing it is up to you. 

I appreciate comments on my recommendation if you've played this after being a fan of the originals, let me know your thoughts; I'm simply too biased to spend another minute playing this.

column8:
Unfortunately, this game is worse than its critic reviews indicate.

This game reeks of a rush job, as if EA was hurriedly seeking to close out and move from the CNC franchise. To call it underwhelming and disappointing is an understatement. Stay away unless you really feel compelled to complete your CNC collection.

GAMEPLAY
In one word: boring.

Harsh limits on the number of units you can control makes this feel like a tactical game, with none of the visceral satisfaction often seen in those games. The game is heavily based on counters/hard counters, but even in disparate matchups by this system, the  encounters take forever to finish.

Combine this with how easy it is to replace lost units, and missions quickly become a slog.

The singleplayer is a total dud in all aspects. Missions are linear and short, and there aren't many of them. The cutscenes show a similar lack of dedication, being completely forgettable and doing little to actually wrap up the Tiberium universe story.

The multiplayer was occasionally entertaining, but given that is rarely the reason I play an RTS, it was immaterial for me.

GRAPHICS/AUDIO
Technically speaking, they aren't bad. However, the cartoony visuals are at odds with the rest of the Tib universe (including CNC3), and unit designs are both bland and uninspired. Much of the same can be said about the audio.


No franchise deserves an end like this.
column9:
Unfortunately, this game is worse than its critic reviews indicate.

This game reeks of a rush job, as if EA was hurriedly seeking to close out and move from the CNC franchise. To call it underwhelming and disappointing is an understatement. Stay away unless you really feel compelled to complete your CNC collection.

GAMEPLAY
In one word: boring.

Harsh limits on the number of units you can control makes this feel like a tactical game, with none of the visceral satisfaction often seen in those games. The game is heavily based on counters/hard counters, but even in disparate matchups by this system, the  encounters take forever to finish.

Combine this with how easy it is to replace lost units, and missions quickly become a slog.

The singleplayer is a total dud in all aspects. Missions are linear and short, and there aren't many of them. The cutscenes show a similar lack of dedication, being completely forgettable and doing little to actually wrap up the Tiberium universe story.

The multiplayer was occasionally entertaining, but given that is rarely the reason I play an RTS, it was immaterial for me.

GRAPHICS/AUDIO
Technically speaking, they aren't bad. However, the cartoony visuals are at odds with the rest of the Tib universe (including CNC3), and unit designs are both bland and uninspired. Much of the same can be said about the audio.


No franchise deserves an end like this.

column8:
If you liked earlier Command & Conquer games, then stay the F away from this one.
They took all that was good and tossed it away.
This game shouldnt even have "Tiberian" in it.
I mean, there is barely any tiberium in this piece of shit (well, except the intro video..)

And the story is complete shit. Let me sum it up, spoilers ahead:
Kane has glowing ball, ball makes tiberium behave, GDI and Kane has built tiberium-pipelines together. And on every map, every side has a reason to kill you somehow.
It ends with Kane going home thru portals, and your reward for that sucks. Always.

But its a RTS right?? Well its a RTS-Unit spamfest game. Not much thinking besides having as many units as possible alive at the same time.

The only good thing is the ability to play cooperative with another poor soul (friend).
So there is no need to play this shit alone/singleplayer...

In short: Do not buy it. (unless you get it for free, or from a friend) :D   (Thanks mate!) )

UPDATE: Gamespy is down, multiplayer/coop may not work. +DRM can prevent re-install.
Nominated game for the "You ruined the franchise! GOD DAMN YOU ALL TO HELL!" -award.

column8:
So, I was in the break room at work one day, and there's this car insurance commercial on the television. Two co-workers are watching it, laughing to themselves over the absurdity that each insurance company claims to be the single best provider. "They can't all be the best at the same time," says one. I agreed, adding that it's much like how each religion insists that it is the only true belief. I'm met with a look and, "Well, I know I have the one true Word and the one true God." I shrugged and said, "Oh, I have State Farm."

Long story short? Never, ever play C&C4:TT. It's more awkward than discussing religion at the workplace and rarely ends with such a quippy anecdote.

Command & Conquer 4 is enjoyable for gamers who loved World In Conflict. Tiberian Twilight steers well clear from the original gameplays of its predecessors. Instead, it adapts a domination-style capture control point mode which is widely seen in World In Conflict, Dawn of War, and Company of Heroes. The visuals are from an upgraded version of the RAGE engine and performs well in the fast-packed crawler multiplayer rush battles.

This game is alright if you do not judge it but the game play found in the older games. This is much more about fewer stronger units, than base and army building. That considered, the game modes given offer a challenge and it is neat to work to unlock units. It is not fun however to play online against players who already have very unit unlocked and know the quickest way to win. The single player portion of the game has a some what corny story that manages to be legitimate and includes with it some live action cinematics, with familiar characters, that are of similar quality. I would say though its a great effort and you are not there for the cinematics any way so it's easily forgiven. 

Overal its an alright game but multilayer is not for the casual gamer unless it's among friends.

column8: As an avid RTS player CnC 4 strays from traditional RTS games and focus's on action.  The game has some RPG elements to it which you can cap within 10 hours of non stop playing.  The dev's did away with base building and resource gathering instead you get a crawler similar to a command center which is mobile.  It creates all your units.  You get 3 crawlers to choose from either side.  Support, Offense and Defense each class has it's own unique unit's and abilities.  At first I enjoyed this game.  But removing resources and base's takes away a huge elemnet of why enjoy RTS games to begin with.  No economy to manage and no real "home" to protect 2 factors which add depth to RTS's.  Being able to manage those and your army add's alot to the gameplay and I miss it when playing this game.  If you don't appreciate those things in RTS's and prefer to get right into the action then this game is for you.  But not so much for me.  I bought it mainly to see the conclusion to the storyline. 6/10

column8: To anyone who respects this series.... DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. I understand that EA was trying to inovate the classic RTS and went in with the best intentions; but they butchered it. Missions feel generic and bases are non-existent. I like the idea of the mobile bases, which has already been done in C&C2; but I feel as though I'm playing Dawn of War 2 rather than a C&C game. I played through a few skrimishes and about 8 missions. The learning curve is incredibly steep even on normal difficulty and the computer is unforgiving even in the first campaign missions. Lastly the game is more about how many units I can produce rather than using group tactics and formations. Do yourself a favor and go buy C&C3 kane's wrath. It is a much better game with a better structure of gameplay.

NOT C&C!!  STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME!!!

September 2020 UPDATE:

Still a horrible mess of a game. The only thing that resembles C&C in this title is Kane, and even that is lackluster at best. 
The mechanics that made the C&C genre great are all missing from this. A complete waste of time and money.
This is a sad, lame version that almost no one can find anything redeeming about.
If you want to play the best C&C game then go find the original C&C here on Steam. It has been remastered and runs great on modern PCs. 
You'll be glad you did!
